DOC.HEAD: South Korea, Soviets to Open Airline Service
DOC.TEXT: South Korea and the Soviet Union have agreed to start passenger air service between each other's capitals next month, the government announced today. The agreement marks a major step toward improving relations between Seoul and Moscow, which have no diplomatic relations but recently have expanded economic and non-political links. The Transportation Ministry announced that it has approved an air accord that Korean Air concluded with the Soviet state airliner, Aeroflot, in Moscow on Wednesday. The agreement will allow KAL to start its European service by way of Moscow on March 25. All European-bound KAL flights now take a longer route through Anchorage, Alaska, and the North Pole. Under the new agreement, one of KAL's 10 weekly European flights will be allowed to stop over in Moscow, with the other nine passing through Siberia and Moscow on their way to European cities. The agreement also will enable Aeroflot to launch two weekly flights to Seoul beginning on March 26, the officials said. Reports said China and South Korea, which also have no diplomatic relations, are negotiating to conclude an air accord this year.

DOC.HEAD: Uncertain Political Future Looms After Japan's Election
DOC.TEXT: National elections Sunday will likely leave the government in the throes of the current legislative gridlock _ regardless of the winner, analysts say. Some say the paralysis could leave Japan without strong leadership to bargain with the United States on trade disputes. Japan's leadership has been hamstrung in recent months by opposition control of the upper house of Parliament and power struggles within the governing party. Six political parties with widely differing agendas are contending for the 512 seats in the lower house of Parliament in an election expected to set the tone for Japan in the 1990s. The lower, more powerful part of Japan's two-chamber parliament passes the budget and appoints the prime minister. All the party leaders speak of the need to negotiate to resolve the legislative crisis after the election, but ``they agree on little else,'' said an analysis in today's Yomiuri Shimbun, a conservative national daily. Polls in the final week before the election predict the governing Liberal Democratic Party will hold its majority, but political analysts have not ruled out upsets because 30 percent or more of voters were undecided. The conservative Liberal Democrats, in power since the party was formed in 1955, lost control of the upper house last year after it leaders were battered by a series of sex and bribery scandals and an uproar over a new sales tax. Sunday's election is critical for Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, who lacks a firm power base within his own party. He became leader of the governing party last summer after two prime ministers were forced to step down because of scandals. Here are three possible scenarios in the post-election political scene: _ If the Liberal Democrats come in short of a majority, Kaifu will step down immediately. Former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe is the widely favored candidate to replace Kaifu, but the opposition camp is likely to try to appoint popular Socialist leader Takako Doi as prime minister. Liberal Democrat Secretary-General Ichiro Ozawa said his party will turn over the government to the opposition if it fails to win a majority. ``As we are already short of a majority in the upper house, I must admit the people's decision not to give us control of the lower house would have an immeasurably important significance,'' he told The Associated Press. ``If we lose in this election, we have no choice but to turn over the government.'' That would mean Japan could have a leftist-led coalition government for the first time in more than four decades. But the Socialists and centrist opposition parties failed to resolve policy differences before the election, and it is uncertain whether they could agree on coalition terms. Socialist Secretary-General Tsuruo Yamaguchi has said the opposition camp will unite quickly if the parties win a majority in the lower house. _ The Liberal Democrats may manage to stay in power by attracting conservative independents even if the party itself falls short of the 257 seats required for a majority. This would increase pressure on Kaifu to step down to take reponsibility for the electoral loss, and the power struggle within the party would probably intensify. _ If the Liberal Democrats win a clear majority, Kaifu is expected to form a strong government of his own, unlike the present one, which reflects the will of party elders. The first challenge for Kaifu will be to pass the budget by April 1. The Liberal Democrats are committed to change the widely unpopular 3 percent sales tax, while the opposition parties are united in saying it should be abolished. The tax logjam in Parliament, in the end, may also force Kaifu to step down. ``I would not be surprised if someone other than Kaifu ends up going to the summit meeting in Houston in July,'' said Masaya Ito, a political analyst. ``Either way, without strong and stable domestic leadership, Japan will have a troublesome time in trade negotiations with the United States, whose demands are expected to toughen after the election,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Artist Known for Cartoon-like Drawings Dies of AIDS
LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: Keith Haring, whose cartoon-like drawings appeared in public spaces from New York City's subways to the Berlin Wall, has died of AIDS. He was 31. Haring, who had been diagnosed with the AIDS virus more than a year ago, died early Friday in his downtown Manhattan apartment, said an assistant, Margaret Slabbert. Active in AIDS fund-raising, Haring returned from a European trip a month ago and fell ill soon after. Haring's work, characterized by human and animal figures in an energized setting, was admired worldwide and brought him a lucrative business. Some in the art world denigrated the commercialization of his art through T-shirts, posters and in advertising. But Haring said that was part of the point. ``If commercialization is putting my art on a shirt so that a kid who can't afford a $30,000 painting can buy one, then I'm all for it,'' Haring said. ``Art is nothing if you don't reach every segment of the people.'' His critical reputation never matched his popularity. ``Keith Haring's work is obviously very seductive and immensely attractive to a lot of people,'' said New York Times art critic Michael Brenson. ``But there never seems to be any edge to it...I don't care for it at all.'' Haring's motifs _ a glowing baby, dancing figures, pyramids, creatures with TV heads, barking dogs _ first appeared on blank advertising space in New York's subways about 10 years ago. By 1983, Artnews was calling his work ``provocative, far-reaching and uplifting.'' Others called it the visual equivalent of rap or hip-hop music, popular but not necessarily serious. Newsweek's Mark Stevens once called Haring's work ``fast food. ... It's a good time. It's boogeying on Saturday night. But great _ no.'' In 1986, he painted a 300-foot mural on the Berlin Wall of a chain of red and black human figures on a yellow background _ incorporating the flag colors of East and West Germany. His other murals include those at Children's Hospital in Washington, D.C., Grady Hospital in Atlanta, Necker children's hospital in Paris and the maternity ward of Princess Grace Hospital in Monte Carlo. He did a great deal of work for free, including posters for the anti-apartheid movement and anti-crack murals. One anti-drug mural in East Harlem overlooking the FDR Drive on Manhattan is seen by thousands of commuters each day. In 1986, Haring opened the Pop Shop, a store in the SoHo section of Manhattan that sells products bearing his art, including T-shirts, refrigerator magnets and inflatable toys. ``My shop is an extension of what I was doing in the subway stations, breaking down the barriers between high and low art,'' he said. His projects included painting rock star Grace Jones' entire body for a poster and collaborating on a poster of model Brooke Shields with photographer Richard Avedon. Haring was raised in Kutztown, Pa., and learned to draw from his father, a supervisor at Western Electric. His formal training consisted of two years as a handyman at the Pittsburgh Center for the Arts, and two years at New York's School of Visual Arts. Andy Warhol was his mentor. Mayor David Dinkins said Haring's ``death deprives the art community and the city-at-large of a great creative force. In his effort to bring art to communities throughout the city and, indeed, around the world, Keith Haring demonstrated the openness of spirit and commitment to creativity that defined his art.'' A private cremation was planned, with a memorial service to be scheduled at a later date.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Demand Talks for Release of Two Americans
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas demanded negotiations for the release of two U.S. citizens they kidnapped this week to protest President Bush's visit to Colombia, a news report said. One other American was also reported captured by the guerrillas to protest Bush's one-day visit Thursday for a regional drug summit. Authorities said they had no word on the third American, a Roman Catholic priest from Rochester, N.Y. Parishioners prayed for his return. The television program 24 Hours said Friday night that relatives of James Donnelly, one of the captives, were contacted by the abductors. It said they demanded a committee be formed to negotiate the terms to release Donnelly and fellow captive David Kent. The abductors did not provide details on the conditions they would put forward during such talks, the report said. It also was not clear who the abductors wanted on the committee. Donnelly, a 65-year-old mechanical engineer from Detroit, and Kent, a 40-year-old school teacher from Indianapolis, were separately kidnapped in the northwestern city of Medellin on Tuesday. The pro-Castro National Liberation Front made public Friday night a communique claiming responsibility for their abductions. Officials also blame the group for kidnapping the priest, the Rev. Francisco Amico Ferrari. He was abducted Thursday in the southwestern city of Cali. The guerrillas said the summit in the Colombian resort city of Cartagena between Bush and the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia was part of a design for ``the military control of our (Colombian) territory.'' The summit approved a joint fight by the four nations against drug trafficking. A police spokesman contacted in Medellin by telephone said the police knew nothing of the guerrillas' demands. Roman Catholic Church bishops in Cali issued a statement calling for the abductors to release Amico. The bishops also condemned guerrilla bomb attacks Thursday at two Mormon temples run by American pastors. Damages were estimated at $12,000, but no injuries were reported. Medellin and Cali are homes to the drug cartels named after them. The cartels are blamed for more than 80 percent of the cocaine entering the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Seizes National Guard Armory to Ease Overcrowding
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff fed up with months of overcrowding at the county jail commandeered a National Guard armory and said he will temporarily house prisoners there ``to keep the peace.'' Richard McCarthy, spokesman for the Hampden County Sheriff's department, said the action taken Friday by Sheriff Michael Ashe was ``a last resort. It's an extreme action to deal with a more dangerous situation.'' McCarthy said he expected the 15 minimum-security prisoners taken to the armory's drill hall would be housed there at least through the holiday weekend. State Secretary of Public Safety Charles V. Barry said Ashe was notified that housing prisoners in the armory was illegal. He said Ashe was subject to prosecution for criminal trespass and that he would pursue legal action Tuesday if the prisoners were not removed. State offices will be closed Monday for Presidents' Day. ``This is no way to do business,'' Barry said. ``If you would come to us to discuss the problem, we would see what we could do to accommodate you.'' In a directive sent to the brigadier commander of the Massachusetts Army National Guard Armory, Ashe said, ``It appears ... there is an imminent danger of a breach of the peace due to insufficient prison space in this county.'' ``Reasonable and prudent steps must be taken in order to preserve the peace and quell such danger,'' he said. McCarthy said the move was not symbolic and that Ashe believes the armory could become an effective temporary prison, housing about 100 prisoners. All 15 prisoners at the armory have less than two months to serve, McCarthy said. ``This action is within my inherent power to keep the peace. I take full responsibility for this action to protect my fellow citizens,'' Ashe said. Friday's action followed a week of turmoil at the jail, which had reached maximum capacity. The jail was built to hold 279 prisoners and is under federal orders to house no more than 500 inmates. Two deputy county sheriffs were detained for most of Wednesday by Westfield District Judge Philip Contant after they refused to take a prisoner back to the Hampden County Jail in Springfield on Ashe's orders. Ashe didn't want the prisoners sent to the jail because it had more than 500 inmates. Contant said Ashe was doing an admirable job under trying circumstances, but insisted he would pursue contempt charges if prisoners were denied entry to the jail. McCarthy said early release, late sentencing and sending prisoners to other jails had failed to relieve congestion at the jail. A new jail has been approved in nearby Ludlow, but that is expected to take two to three years to build. State Sen. Brian Lees went to the armory, described as the size of a large gymnasium, and said it was unclear whether Ashe had the authority to take over the building. ``We're waiting to see if this is legal and whether it falls under the guidelines of the constitution,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans to Allow Unchecked Travel Through Brandenburg Gate
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germany will tear down a 600-foot section of the Berlin Wall near the Brandenburg Gate and allow completely unhindered passage between the two sides of the city there, West German television said. Since November, the East Germans have created numerous passage points through the Berlin Wall but have retained nominal checks of passports or identity cards. The section at the Brandenburg Gate will be the first section without any official controls. ``The Berlin Wall at the Brandenburg Gate will be torn down,'' the ZDF television network said Friday. ``East German border troops will start the work on Monday.'' ``There will then be unhindered passage between East and West from the Reichstag to the Brandenburg Gate. There will not be a fence there as originally planned.'' The wall, for years a symbol of the division of Europe, was built in 1961 to prevent East German laborers from leaving. A popular uprising in East Germany last fall toppled the hard-line leadership and forced the opening of the wall in November.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Leader Meets With Authors of Hong Kong Charter
DOC.TEXT: Senior leader Deng Xiaoping of China today met with the authors of Hong Kong's proposed constitution for Chinese rule and called their work ``a masterpiece of creativity.'' Many Hong Kong residents fear the new constitution will not force China to keep its promises of allowing the capitalist system to remain for 50 years after the 1997 takeover and of letting Hong Kong exercise a high degree of autonomy. Confidence in China's pledges dropped dramatically after the June 3-4 military crackdown on Beijing's pro-democracy movement. The protests were widely supported in Hong Kong, a British colony on China's southwestern coast. The 51-member constitutional committee, appointed in 1985 by the Beijing government, completed the final draft of the document this week. The plan, known as the Basic Law, now goes to China's legislature, the National People's Congress, for approval. ``This is a historical event, not just for the present but for the future, not just for the Third World but for all of mankind,'' Deng said. ``Such a document is a masterpiece of creativity.'' Deng met once before with the drafting committee _ in April 1987, just after pro-democracy student protests of the winter of 1986-87. During that meeting, he emphasized the need for stability and warned that after 1997 ``if (people) try to turn Hong Kong into a base of opposition to the mainland in the name of `democracy' .... we will definitely interfere.'' He also said general elections and ``Western democracy'' were not suitable for Hong Kong, while ``keeping certain power for the central government will benefit Hong Kong and bring it no harm.'' Under the Basic Law plan, only 20 of the 60 seats in Hong Kong's legislature in 1997 will be directly elected in Hong Kong. That number will increase to 30 by 2003. The plan includes clauses that allow China to declare a state of emergency and ban contacts with foreign political groups. At today's meeting, Deng was accompanied by Premier Li Peng, Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin, President Yang Shangkun and congress chairman Wan Li. They did not speak. Ji Pengfei, chairman of the drafting committee, said in his closing remarks later in the morning that the plan ``reflects the great thinking of (the) one- country, two-systems'' policy. He added that the task before the drafting committee now was to ``make the Basic Law a part of the popular feeling in Hong Kong.'' In Hong Kong on Friday, news of passage of the final Basic Law draft was greeted with renewed demands for rapid democratic change. About 1,500 students chanting pro-democracy slogans and carrying placards marched to the Chinese diplomatic mission in protest. The government has announced plans to increase the pace of democratic change next year.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
LaserPhoto CX4
DOC.TEXT: A mass of molasses oozed through two blocks of Colorado's ``Sweetheart City'' after a storage tank ruptured, forcing a kindergarten to close and blocking the entrances of several businesses. Before the syrupy mess was identified, authorities took precautions against what they thought was a potentially dangerous chemical spill. No one was injured by the leak in the city of 30,000 about 50 miles north of Denver. Word of the mess reached authorities early Friday after a car spun out of control on a slippery substance and ran into a ditch. City manager Mike Rock said two young men were in the vehicle and ``one of them told me it was like hitting glare ice. His windshield was so splattered with the stuff he couldn't see.'' The molasses was steaming when it escaped but quickly thickened in temperatures of 5 degrees below. It flowed down a busy street, into an industrial park and on into an irrigation ditch where it ran for another half-mile, said police Cpl. Al Sharon. ``It gives a whole new meaning to the term Sweetheart City,'' Sharon said. ``We have engineers on the scene trying to determine the best way to clean up the spill,'' said Jack Fulton, director of government relations for Western Sugar Co., owner of the molasses, which is used as an animal-feed supplement. Fulton estimated 582,000 gallons of molasses had spilled. Rock said of the cleanup effort, ``maybe we need to bring in a big bunch of pancakes.''

Madras, a 300-pound white Bengal circus tiger in Florida for the winter, had human-style root canals after breaking his two lower fangs while gnawing on a bone. Bill Richardson, a DeLand dentist, had only worked on people before, but was eager to aid the 2-year-old tiger's teeth. ``One interesting thing about this is when I was in dental school, they'd say to you, `We're not going to teach you how to do everything. We're going to teach you how to figure out how to do everything,''' Richardson said. He performed the root canals outdoors Thursday, using a slab of wood as an operating table. The cat was anesthetized and Richardson, assisted by eight people, used forceps to remove the dead tissue from inside the fangs. He filled the teeth with a cement mixture and filed them with a buffer. Trainers with the Clyde Beatty and Cole Bros. Circus called the dentist because they feared the cat would get an infection. Madras woke up about 30 minutes after the 50-minute operation a little groggy but feeling no pain, Richardson said.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Second Live-Donor Liver Transplant Recipient Returns Home
DOC.TEXT: An 18-month-old girl who was the nation's second live-donor liver transplant recipient is back home in Tennessee. Sarina Jones' departure was delayed twice by snowstorms, but on Friday she finally flew from Chicago to Memphis. She had received a portion of her father's liver Dec. 9 to correct a potentially fatal disorder. Doctors at the University of Chicago Hospitals said when she was released about a week ago that her recovery was coming along fine and that she could expect to grow normally. After her discharge, she was staying at a Ronald McDonald House during a transition period before returning to her Millington, Tenn., home. A couple of weeks before Sarina's surgery, doctors at the University of Chicago Hospitals performed the nation's first live-donor liver transplant, this one on 21-month-old Alyssa Smith of Texas. She, too, has returned home.

DOC.HEAD: Researcher: Teen-age Childbearing Can Combat Poverty
DOC.TEXT: A study presented at a prestigious scientific gathering challenges the commonly held view that teen-age pregnancy is a scourge of the poor. The researcher, Arline T. Geronimus of the University of Michigan, said Friday that pregnancy can lead to economic improvement for teen-age girls and increase their chances of having a healthy baby. The Children's Defense Fund, a research and advocacy organization in Washington, D.C., disputed the finding and said it would continue to battle teen-age pregnancy. ``If a 15- or 16-year-old becomes pregnant, there's no way that's a smart thing,'' said the organization's Ray O'Brian. Early motherhood locks poor women into poverty and poor academic performance, he said. But Geronimus said in an interview: ``I think women in poverty know what they're doing. There are social realities in the poor that those of us doing research are unaware of.'' Among her findings, presented at a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science: _Infants in poverty-stricken communities are healthier if their mothers are in their teens rather than their 20s, because poor mothers are healthier when they are younger. _Teen-age mothers form alliances with the fathers' families _ even if they are not married _ that improve the mothers' economic positions. _Teen-age mothers are free to earn a living in their 20s, because their children are old enough to be cared for by other family members. _The elevated death rate for children of poor black mothers would become even higher if the women were encouraged to delay childbirth. ``I would like to go on record today in opposition to the view that teen childbearing is self-destructive, irrational or anti-social behavior,'' Geronimus said. In a separate study, researchers reported that teen mothers were no more likely to drop out of school than their childless classmates. ``Simply altering the fertility patterns will not guarantee social and economic well-being for young mothers,'' said the researchers, Dawn Upchurch of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore and James McCarthy of Columbia University in New York. Geronimus bases her findings on health statistics and on anthropological investigations of poor rural and urban communities. She said she has conducted extensive interviews with poor women in a rural area in North Carolina and in Boston. She has also built on the work of anthropologist Carol Stack, who found that poor teen-age women who have children get help, including financial help, from the families of their children's fathers. Stack also found that poor young women have been widely exposed to child rearing and thus arrive at motherhood with realistic expectations. The young women also receive help caring for the children. Geronimus has shown that the health of poor black women deteriorates much more rapidly than that of middle-class women. By the time poor women reach their 20s, they may be in menial, stressful jobs and are more likely to smoke and consume alcohol, both of which are hazardous during pregnancy. She thinks the same is probably true for poor white women, but she said those studies have not been done. Geronimus found that infant mortality was not increased among the children of teen-age mothers.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Wants to Play Down Aquino Spat
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Updates throughout
DOC.HEAD: Precede SEOUL
By SUSANNE M. SCHAFER
AP Military Writer
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today said he plans to play down his highly publicized spat with Philippine President Corazon Aquino and focus on ``the things that unite us'' during his critical talks next week in Manila. ``I would hope that any unpleasantness is minimized,'' Cheney said during an interview aboard the U.S. Air Force jet carrying him to this British colony from Seoul, South Korea. Cheney's schedule today included lunch with Hong Kong Gov. Sir David Wilson. He planned to meet Sunday with the U.S. ambassador to the Philippines, Nicholas Platt, before traveling to Manila on Monday. Cheney last week decided to shorten his Philippine stay by a day after Mrs. Aquino announced she would refuse to see him because of anger over negative U.S. press coverage of her government and U.S. payments for the use of six military bases in the Philippines. Cheney is on a two-week tour of the Pacific rim to reassess America's military role in the region. He was expected to inform the Philippine and Japanese governments that they can expect a 10 percent to 12 percent cut in U.S. troops based in Asia over the next three years, and that Congress is unlikely to keep paying as much for their support as in the past. ``Clearly we have a major interest in the Philippines and the region. It's an important stop,'' Cheney said of the Manila visit. The defense secretary pointed out that his discussions come at a crucial juncture in the U.S.-Philippines relationship with talks expected to open next month on renewal of the leases for Clark Air Base, Subic Naval Base and several other military posts. ``We've got major negotiations about to begin with the Philippines on the bases,'' he said, adding that he doesn't intend ``to be in the business of negotiating a new base agreement'' during his stay. Instead, he indicated he'd work on improving relations. ``I think the things that unite us, that we've got in common, are a good deal more significant than any momentary stress in the relationship,'' Cheney said, adding, ``I would expect to focus on and emphasize those things _ (such as) the historic ties between our two countries.'' Cheney said he deliberately ``tried to respond in a very low-key fashion to Mrs. Aquino's decision not to receive me. ... I think the president has tried to keep all of that on an even keel as well.'' President Bush issued a rare public rebuke to Mrs. Aquino for refusing to meet with his defense secretary, saying in an interview that ``she can learn a great deal from Dick Cheney about the way we view the very important U.S. presence in the Pacific.'' Cheney said he intended to stress that despite the rumblings from Congress for troop cuts and sharply reduced Pentagon budgets, ``our interests in the region will continue.'' He added, ``The message I emphasize is, we're not talking about a radical departure of U.S. policy. It`s a matter of readjustment, but it's also a matter of reaffirmation'' of long-term American ties to the region. In recent weeks, U.S. officials have expressed mounting concern about Aquino's leadership and her ability to withstand the unrest inside her government that has resulted in a half-dozen coup attempts. Mrs. Aquino's snub of Cheney shocked many because of the support she'd received from the Bush administration, in particular the president's decision to authorize U.S. F-4 Phantom Jet Fighters to pin down rebel planes at the height of the Dec. 1 coup attempt. Some analysts have viewed Mrs. Aquino's rejection of Cheney as an attempt to bolster support inside the Philippines in the face of charges that Bush's help made her beholden to Washington. The two-year leases on the Philippine bases expire in 1991 and even though Pres. Reagan pledged in 1988 to pay more than $481 million for their use, Congress has refused to cough up the full amount, a sore point between the two governments.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Pesticides Can Linger in Homes for Years
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Deletes extraneous words in lead.
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency says pesticides may become trapped in homes for years and some say that could be cause for concern by the public. ``These findings call into question some of the fundamental assumptions we have made about the safety of chemical pesticides,'' Rep. James Scheuer, D-N.Y., after release of a government indoor air study on Friday. Scheuer is a co-sponsor of legislation that would call for additional research into indoor air quality problems. EPA spokesmen characterized the chemical levels found in samples of air in homes in Florida and Massachusetts as ``uniformly low'' and not great enough to pose a health concern. The report concluded that ``no risks of major concern were identified.'' The study by an EPA consultant examined indoor air in 259 homes in Jacksonville, Fla., and the Springfield-Chicopee area in Massachusetts to determine the residue levels from 32 selected pesticides. Air monitoring devices were placed inside and outside the homes over a 24-hour period on three occasions in 1986 though 1988 in a search for traces of the pesticides. Many of the chemicals have been commonly used for years in household products such as bug or flea sprays or for termite control and others normally are used in agriculture. Some of the chemicals have been banned by the EPA for a number of years because they are carcinogenic. Some of the chemicals were found in the houses at levels much greater than outdoors, sometimes at levels 50 to 90 times the levels detected with the outdoor monitors at the same locations, the study said. But the EPA characterized the concentrations as ``very low levels'' and not surprising because many of the chemicals have been associated widely with household use. ``We characterize the risk as low to negligible,'' said Michael Firestone, an EPA chemist. ``These are not figures that we didn't expect to find.'' But Janet Hathaway, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council who over the years has focused on pesticide issues, said the study involves an area ``that has tended to be completely ignored by the EPA.'' Government regulators have focused on pesticide residue levels on foods, but have paid little attention to the risks posed by these chemicals in the air, especially indoors, she said. ``I think the study is being underplayed by the EPA.'' Ms. Hathaway said the findings for a number of the chemicals suggest cancer risks from airborne exposure possibly being greater than the 1 in 1 million ``minimum risk'' level the government uses in food residue calculations. The study, conducted by Research Triangle Institute in North Carolina, made no specific risk assessment except to say that ``both cancer and non-cancer risks were evaluated...(and) no risks of major concern were identified.'' Some of the highest airborne levels found inside the houses involved chemicals that over the years have been commonly used to control termites. Other chemicals have long been associated with various household products from flea sprays for pets to bathroom disinfectants and for a variety of garden uses.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Finish Review of Massive Acid Rain Report
DOC.TEXT: Scientists from around the globe have had their chance to review and comment on 15,000 pages of research from the most comprehensive study of acid rain ever conducted. The challenge now, participants said, is to take the individual reports and pull them together in an integrated document to provide planners with a yardstick for gauging the impact of policy decisions. ``Now that we have done the detail, we need to come back to a universal,'' said James Mahoney, the director of the National Acid Precipitation Program. About 700 scientists from 35 nations on Friday finished a week-long meeting held to review preliminary reports compiled in a $500 million study by Mahoney's program. ``The sense of development in the science ... has been to eliminate the two extreme views about acid rain effects,'' Mahoney said. ``There was one extreme that there were no effects that were really important and nothing is documented _ the other extreme was that we have an absolute disaster and we're burning up the forests and the lakes,'' he said. Mahoney said the project is the largest study of acid rain ever conducted. The scientists reviewed 26 draft studies compiled over ten years. Those documents, the work of about 1,000 researchers, focus on the topics ranging from effects of acid rain on aquatic life to impacts on forests and building materials. Acid rain is a combination of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and other pollutants that can fall to earth as rain, snow, sleet, fog or dust particles. The studies indicate the pollution can make lakes and streams acidic and kill aquatic life. The studies also link acid rain to declines in certain types of trees and damage to stone buildings and statues. The scientists' comments will be taken into consideration as the unified report is written. Scientists were told there may be no quick answer to some questions about acid rain. The research into forests indicated acid rain may have contributed to the mortality of red spruce trees in the northern Appalachians. But David Radloff said of the U.S. Forest Service said while it's possible to gauge impacts on individual trees, larger forest systems are too complex. ``It may be impossible for a long time to prove acid rain is impacting forest ecosystems,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Reschedule Polish Debt to Aid New Government
DOC.TEXT: Showing support for Poland's struggling non-Communist government, 17 creditor nations agreed to reschedule nearly a fourth of the country's $40 billion foreign debt and suspend payments over the next year. The agreement Friday, the most generous so far by the Paris Club group of creditor nations, lets Poland postpone paying principal on its debt for eight years, said Jean-Claude Trichet, chairman of the group. It allows Poland to reschedule $9.4 billion of its $27 billion debt to Paris Club nations, including $3.4 billion of arrears. That debt, which was due March 1, 1991, is to be spread over 14 years. All payments will now be suspended until March 1, 1991. The agreement, reached after two days of negotiations, reflects Western backing for the government and its radical plans for adopting a market economy, Trichet said. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki took over in August, ending four decades of Communist rule in Poland. Since then, hard-line Communists have been ousted in East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Romania. Macowiecki sent messages to creditor governments Feb. 9 asking them to suspend principal and interest payments for 1989 and 1990 on the entire $40 billion Poland owes and to consider freezing the debt, or even reducing it. Mazowiecki said the debt was the greatest threat to Poland's dramatic attempt to switch from a centrally controlled economy to a free-market system. A deputy government spokesman, Henryk Wozniakowski, said in Warsaw that the agreement will reduce payments to the West by about one-fourth. Janusz Sawicki, head of the Polish delegation, said Friday's accord was the best Poland could obtain and should be viewed as a response to the Mazowiecki's appeal, the Polish news agency PAP reported. The Paris Club agreed with Mazowiecki's suggestion that consultations also be held on reducing the debt in cooperation with the International Monetary Fund, the Polish PAP news agency reported. Two weeks ago, the fund approved Poland's economic restructuring plan, which involves eliminating a huge budget deficit by cutting subsidies to unprofitable state-run industries and attracting foreign investment by establishing a convertible currency. Elimination of price controls and subsidies created 78 percent inflation for January alone. The World Bank estimates ending industrial subsidies will cost 1.7 million jobs _ nearly 10 percent of Poland's work force _ this year. Poland's foreign debt is the largest in Eastern Europe. The partial payments it was making consumed nearly all its hard currency earnings, leaving little to rebuild its obsolete industry. Most of the debt was accumulated during the 1970s when Edward Gierek was Communist Party chief. He spent borrowed Western money on ill-conceived projects and consumer goods in an effort to win public support.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Team in Vietnam for MIA search
DOC.TEXT: A team of U.S. specialists arrived in northern Vietnam to search for American servicemen missing there since the Vietnam War, the U.S. Embassy said today. Spokesman James Williams said the group of 14 U.S. technical experts would concentrate in Son La Province to the northwest of Hanoi and the area around the northern port city of Haiphong. They arrived in Hanoi Friday to start the 15-20 day mission in cooperation with Vietnamese search teams, Williams said. The U.S. team comprised a forensic team, a recovery team and two investigation teams from the Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the U.S. Army's Central Investigation laboratory, both of which are in Hawaii, Williams said. The forensic teams included anthropologists and experts specializing in the analysis of dental remains, Williams said. In the past, searches have included the excavation of sites where U.S. warplanes crashed and field expeditions in which investigators have asked villagers about crashes they witnessed. Vietnam last returned the remains of U.S. servicemen in September 1989. The three sets of remains handed over then are currently undergoing analysis in Hawaii, Williams said. A total of 2,309 U.S. servicemen remain missing in action in Indochina. Of that number 1,683 are missing from the Vietnam War, which ended in a 1975 Communist victory over the U.S.-backed South Vietnamese government. Last year, Vietnam agreed to work on ``discrepancy cases'' involving the loss of some 80 Americans. Such cases include people whom the United States believes were captured, but not freed when U.S. involvement in the war ended in 1973. Vietnam said it now has no U.S prisoners.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Unions Oppose Elections Under Avril
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Haiti's biggest labor unions said they oppose any elections organized by Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril's government, which they said is not committed to a transfer of power to freely elected civilians. Virtually all political parties, angered by a crackdown on government critics in January, also have refused to take part in presidential elections scheduled for October. ``The present state, based as it is on the will and interest of a small group of men, is unable to hold democratic elections,'' the country's six largest unions said in a joint statement Friday. The unions urged all democrats to set aside their differences and work for the establishment of ``a state of law.'' They did not elaborate. During the crackdown, more than 50 activists were rounded up, and many later said they were beaten while in police custody. Avril also sent seven prominent opposition leaders into exile. After protests from the United States, France and the European Community, he said they could return, but most have refused to come back. Friday's statement was signed by the Autonomous Union of Haitian Workers, the Confederation of Haitian Workers, the Federation of Unionized Workers, the Organization of Independent Workers, the National Confederation of Haitian Teachers, and the Union of Electric Utility Workers. In opposing elections under Avril, opposition leaders have cited the government's failure to punish soldiers for human rights abuses. A Radio Metropole reporter, Ertho Zamor, was severely beaten by soldiers Wednesday and said a prominent officer, Maj. Isidore Pongnon, took part in the beating. Radio Cacique reporter Willie Paul also was beaten by police while covering a demonstration last week, and Jean-Andre Destin, a well known Radio Cacique satirist and critic of Avril, was gunned down in January. In November 1987, Haiti's first free general elections since independence from France in 1804 were canceled after thugs protected by soldiers massacred at least 34 voters at polling stations. Avril, a former adviser to ousted dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, had promised free elections and an end to human rights abuses when he replaced Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy in a September 1988 coup. Namphy had taken power as part of a transitional government after Duvalier fled to France during a popular uprising in 1986. Namphy later took over as a military ruler.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Returns to Florida for Polo, Conservation Talk
LaserPhoto XVB1
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles didn't score, but his team won the first of two polo matches the heir to the British throne played before a crowd swelled by royalty watchers. Nearly 2,000 people came out to see the 40-year-old Prince of Wales and his Windsor Park teammates defeat Canada's Maple Leaf squad 11-7 Friday at the Windsor Park Polo Club, 10 miles north of Vero Beach in the community of Orchid. The prince arrived in Vero Beach earlier in the day under the watchful eyes of British and U.S. security officers. The polo match was his first public appearance in a weeklong visit to the United States. Wearing a cream-colored uniform with red letters, Prince Charles failed to add any points to his team's effort but played hard enough to break the top off his mallet. Justin Fletcher, 18, of Vero Beach was working at the match and got to keep the mallet when the prince had it replaced. ``I think I'll frame it,'' Fletcher said. In Friday's first match, White Birch _ featuring Gonzalo Piernes, rated by many as the world's top polo player _ defeated Ponte Vedra 12-10 to advance. The prince's team will play White Birch on Sunday. The teams are competing for the Prince of Wales Cup, which the prince's team won 10-7 last year over Greenwich at the Windsor club. Before Sunday's match, the prince is scheduled to appear at a $250-a-plate lunch and watch a display of wild and endangered animals, including a baby cheetah and an aardvark. He will speak to 550 guests at the luncheon on wildlife conservation. No public appearances were planned for the prince today. He was expected to remain at the mansion of friends Geoffrey and Jorie Kent. Forty workers reportedly spent months renovating a wing of the mansion for the prince, who is traveling without his wife Diana or their children. Balconies were added to the prince's room and on the third-story observation tower, which offers a vista of the Atlantic Ocean and Indian River. The prince's bathroom has a marble tub and several heated towel racks. Round-the-clock security arrangements for Prince Charles are elaborate, with at least 150 bodyguards, State Department officials and local police officers. During Sunday's polo match, a special ambulance will be ready exclusively for the prince, said Indian River County chief paramedic Jim Judge. Sections of the coastal Route A1A will be closed to traffic and pedestrians, said security coordinator Jerry Burr. On Monday, Prince Charles is to visit the Kennedy Space Center before flying to Charleston, S.C., for an international business conference. Later, he travels to Washington to meet with President Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Mild Quake Jostles San Bernardino Area
DOC.TEXT: A mild earthquake jostled San Bernardino County, causing no reports of damage or injuries, officials said. The temblor measured 3.4 on the Richter scale when it hit at 7:46 p.m. Friday, said Hall Daily, spokesman for the California Institute of Technology, where a seismology lab records quake data. The epicenter was located about 6 miles north-northwest of Lake Arrowhead, Daily said. A county sheriff's dispatcher said the jolt prompted no calls about injuries or damage. The Richter scale gauges the energy released during an earthquake by measuring the ground motion. A quake of magnitude 3.5 can cause slight damage. Every increase of one number on the scale means that the ground motion is 10 times greater.

DOC.HEAD: Husband and Wife Candidates Debate Political Reform
With PM-Japan-Election
DOC.TEXT: Playing down their differences, a husband and wife both running for election to Parliament today debated how to reform Japan's scandal-ridden politics on the last day of campaigning. Confronting each other from separate campaign trucks set along the boundary of their respective electoral districts in this Tokyo suburb, Takujiro and Makiko Hamada argued how the country should revive trust in Japan's flagging political system. ``I am fighting from the stance of the Liberal Democrats and will reform the Liberal Democratic Party from within. Makiko Hamada is fighting from the stance that reform must take place from outside the party. But what we are aiming for is the same,'' said Takujiro Hamada, a three-term lawmaker. Japan, controlled for 34 years by the Liberal Democrats, has been beset by a series of scandals that have shaken faith in the conservative party. It lost its majority in Parliament's upper house last year, and voters are expected to vote out several of its members in elections Sunday for the more powerful lower house. Mrs. Hamada, a former flight attendant for Japan Airlines, emphasized her candidacy as an independent was meant to help talented politicians such as her husband, who were constrained by power politics in the governing party. ``I believe from my heart that Takujiro Hamada is a very good politician, a serious politician, a politician who Japan needs. But is the Liberal Democratic Party really making good the type of policies Takujiro Hamada is proposing, the great forecasts the party is making?'' she asked. Pausing periodically during her speech to thank her husband for his support and apologize to irate motorists blocked by the rally north of Tokyo, Mrs. Hamada said she intended to work toward creating a second conservative party to revive competition in Japan's political system. ``To realize your ideals'' of bringing better government to the people, she said, addressing her husband, ``I want to start building a new conservative party based among the people.'' Mrs. Hamada, 47, announced her candidacy two months ago over the wishes of her husband, also 47, and to the surprise of many in this country where wives have traditionally been expected to follow their husbands' bidding. Her husband has been linked to a scandal in which the information conglomerate Recruit Co. has been accused of trying to buy influence with many of Japan's most influential politicians, bureaucrats and business executives. The 13-year political veteran told the small group of supporters and journalists at the rally that the Liberal Democrats were still on the right track, although the party needed thorough internal reform. Following the 30-minute rally, the Hamadas shook hands and hurried off to continue campaigning in their adjoining districts.

DOC.HEAD: Mondale Expresses Cautious Optimism on Prospects for World Peace
DOC.TEXT: Former Vice President Walter Mondale says he's cautiously optimistic about the prospects for global peace in the light of recent political upheavals in Eastern Europe. Mondale told a peace forum Friday that, while prospects for world peace are as good as they've been in his lifetime, he sees dangers in power struggles in countries such as Romania and Bulgaria and increasing anti-Semitism reported in the Soviet Union. ``I want to be optimistic, but I'm very concerned about these trends,'' said Mondale, 62, a Minneapolis attorney. ``I'm not sure we've won the whole thing yet.'' Mondale is moderator of the two-day Peace Prize Forum at Augsburg College. The forum, in its second year, is intended to promote discussion of peace issues and features as speakers Nobel Peace Prize laureates, diplomats and other leaders. The forum continues today. Also participating in the forum are former President Carter; Yelena Bonner, a longtime human rights leader in the Soviet Union and widow of the late Andrei Sakharov, the prominent Soviet dissident and Nobel Peace Prize laureate; and Peter Duffy, chairman of the international executive committee of Amnesty International. Mondale said the Bush administration should be responding more enthusiastically to the changes in Eastern Europe. ``The day (Soviet leader Mikhail S.) Gorbachev announced a multiparty system, our president was running around asking for more money for the military,'' Mondale said. ``I think people were wondering what our president was doing. ... Here's a tremendous development, and I wish we could get more enthusiastically and energetically involved. We seem to be more like bookkeepers now, checking the books.'' Mondale suggested that President Bush offer Eastern Europe's fledgling democracies money and know-how, especially about setting up democratic institutions. He said the money could become available if military funding were cut to match the shrinking threat to national security. Bonner opened the forum by saying that Gorbachev is a power-hungry politician who has an overblown reputation as a reformer. ``Gorbachev has shown himself as a very strong leader in the struggle for his own power and his own survival,'' Bonner said. ``Is he only interested in personal power? Or is he interested in the rights of the people?'' Gorbachev's actions have been widely misinterpreted by Western countries, Bonner said. She said that revolts for democratic change in the Soviet bloc have been brewing for a long time and Gorbachev deserves credit only for not stamping them out. ``He behaves that way not because he wants them to proclaim their independence from the Communist Party, but because he could not stop it,'' Bonner said. ``He had no way of influencing events in Eastern Europe.'' The forum is sponsored by five Midwestern colleges of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. It is held in cooperation with the Oslobased Norwegian Nobel Institute, which awards the Nobel Peace Prize.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Police Officers Killed in Ambush
DOC.TEXT: About 50 armed men ambushed and killed a police commander and eight of his men today and then fled with the slain officers' guns, a local leader said. There was no immediate word on the identity of the attackers. But the military considers the southern village of where the ambush took place to be a stronghold of Communist guerrillas. In other violence, three gunmen shot and killed the chief security officer of the National Bureau of Investigation inside a passenger jeep in Manila, investigators said. A woman passenger was also reported wounded in the attack. The identity of those attackers was also unknown, but one investigator said robbery was possible. In the attack at the southern village of Margos, a surviving policeman wounded some of the assailants, according to Leo Zaragoza, vice mayor of nearby Kapatagan town, about 500 miles southeast of Manila. Zaragoza, interviewed on radio station DXBB, quoted police investigators as saying the victims were responding to a report of a Friday night robbery. He said about 50 armed men positioned along the highway fired at the policemen's jeep as it passed through Margos, killing the nine men. Among those killed was station commander police Cpl. Artemio Traiga. The military has identified the town as being infiltrated by the Communist New People's Army. The attackers took the slain policemen's M-16 rifles and pistols and fled carrying some of their own wounded comrades, the vice mayor said, quoting a village leader. Today's violence came as a leftist umbrella group called on the President Corazon Aquino to order dismantling of U.S. military bases in the Philippines and enter into new peace negotiations with the rebels. In a statement released to news agencies, outlawed National Democratic Front renewed a pledge to declare a unilateral cease-fire if the Aquino government announces it will remove the U.S. bases by 1991, when the current agreement on the facilities expires. The rebel front's statement came two days before U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney arrives for a meeting with Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos. Ramos has said he will discuss with Cheney unfulfilled U.S. aid commitments to the Philippines and regional security. The military has been put on alert for leftist disturbances in connection with Cheney's two-day visit beginning Monday. Troops in Central Luzon, where the U.S. bases are located, are reported bracing for attacks against American servicemen. The communists are waging a 21-year-old insurgency against the national government. In the Manila attack, security chief Restituto Masilungan was shot in the face inside the jeep on a bridge in Manila, homicide investigator Police Cpl. Rodolfo Janer. Janer said the three men may have planned to rob the passengers but noticed Masilungan's gun and instead ``beat him to the draw.'' The gunmen fled after the shooting, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Superintendent Files Lawsuit; 180 White Students Leave School System
DOC.TEXT: The city's first black school superintendent has filed a $10 million lawsuit against the white-majority school board, which sparked racial turmoil when it voted not to renew his contract. Meanwhile, almost 200 students, mostly whites, have decided to withdraw from the Selma school system, which reopened this week following a student sit-in to protest the decision not to extend Norward Roussell's contract beyond June, when it expires. Roussell's lawsuit, filed Friday in U.S. District Court in Mobile, claims his contract was not renewed for racial reasons and that the board's decision was based, in part, on his ``complete dismantling'' of a student placement system known as leveling. Critics of the system say it was designed to segregate students and keep blacks in lower-level classes. According to the suit, Roussell's decision to end leveling served as the catalyst for removing him because ``for the first time in the system's history, black students were given a fair opportunity to compete in advanced academic classes.'' About 15 blacks demonstrated at Selma City Hall on Friday to protest city education policies, chanting ``Do the right thing'' and other slogans intended for white Mayor Joe Smitherman. The protesters have been holding rallies and sit-ins at the building to press their demands that Roussell be rehired for another three years, that changes be made in student placement policies, and that the city go to an elected, rather than appointed, school board. The 11-member school board, which has six white members, voted along racial lines in December not to renew Roussell's three-year contract. Roussell said nearly 12 percent of the white students in Selma's 6,000-student public school system have withdrawn since the schools reopened on Tuesday under heavy security. ``I'm sure they've left because of the tense situation we're facing,'' Roussell said, ``but I think that when we get out of this situation and resolve our problems, people will begin to come back.'' Since Tuesday, 199 students have left the system, 180 of them white, Roussell said. That leaves about 1,500 whites in a system that is 70 percent black. Smitherman, who was in office during the racial turmoil of the 1960s, said the withdrawal figures were ``very saddening.'' He said continued withdrawals could turn into ``chaotic situations in surrounding counties.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Not a single word is said publicly about the great internal questions of how to educate millions of people who have lived under an oppressive regime and have been cut off from the real world for more than 40 years, and how to prevent their ignorance of the past from negatively affecting the course of the future.'' _ Rabbi Marvin Hier, of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, in a cautionary letter about German reunification sent to West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Premier Hans Modrow.

``It has been a historic week. Just think, 10 years from now I'll look back and say I worked for Drexel Burnham. And that firm no longer exists.'' _ Kathleen Camilli, a Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. money market economist who was one of thousands of employees laid off after Drexel's parent company filed for protection from its creditors.

``If commercialization is putting my art on a shirt so that a kid who can't afford a $30,000 painting can buy one, then I'm all for it. Art is nothing if you don't reach every segment of the people.'' _ Keith Haring, New York City subway doodler turned successful international artist, who died of AIDS Friday at age 31.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Deny Report of Riots in Ancient Uzbek City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with denial of unrest in Uzbeckistan. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party chief in Samarkand today denied a report by state-run Radio Moscow that rioting in Soviet Central Asia had spread to his ancient city in Uzbekistan. The broadcast said members of the Moslem majority fought ethnic Armenians. The report aired on Radio Moscow's international English-language service late Friday followed a week of unrest in the neighboring Soviet republic of Tadzhikistan, where 20 people were killed and 568 wounded by Interior Ministry count. Nasyr Yakubov, the first party secretary of Samarkand, told The Associated Press by telephone his city was quiet, there were no riots and no curfew was imposed. He said the city's 12,000 Armenian residents live in peace with members of other ethnic groups. Asatyulo Yusupov, a duty officer at the Interior Ministry office in Samarkand, also denied the radio report. Radio Moscow reported Friday that the Interior Ministry sent troop reinforcements to Samarkand and ordered residents to remain in their homes after dark. Despite those measures, the radio said, rallies and demonstrations continued. It cited the Interfax news service, a joint venture affiliated with Radio Moscow, as the source of its information. No other state Soviet news outlet carried the report, which did not mention casualties or damage in Samarkand, a city of colorfully tiled buildings, domed mosques and oriental bazaars. The ancient city is about 1,700 miles southeast of Moscow and has a population of 390,000, mostly Moslems. The Armenian refugees are mainly Christians. Asked about Yakubov's and Yusopov's denials, an editor at Radio Moscow's central newsroom in the Soviet capital acknowledged today the radio had not been able to independently confirm the details of the Interfax report. The report was sent via facsimile to subscribing Western news organizations in Moscow. Interfax, created last year, has been a usually reliable source on developments in the Soviet Union and even broke the news of what would be in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech on political reforms to the Communist Party leadership earlier this month. Tass, the official news agency, reported Friday that inflamatory leaflets were being circulated in areas of Uzbekistan bordering Tadzhikistan. They demanded ``the immediate eviction of Russians from Central Asia'' and denounced the alleged resettlement in Uzbekistan of refugees, presumably Armenians, who fled Azerbaijan, Tass said. Tass said a man identified as Kh. Saidov was arrested in Samarkand for carrying 30 anti-Armenian leaflets, and the Siab district court fined another man, I. Guseinov, 500 rubles ($830) for advocating the eviction of Armenians and using force against them. Tadzhikistan, 1,600 miles southeast of Moscow, was the latest in a string of republics torn by ethnic strife since Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power five years ago and relaxed central controls. He has repeatedly warned that the turmoil threatens his reform program. The strife in Tadzhik capital, Dushanbe, was touched off Feb. 10 by rumors that Armenian refugees were arriving by the thousands and receiving scarce apartments. Interfax said authorities brought Dushanbe under control Friday, halting a week of bloodshed. Izvestia, the government daily, said the central part of Dushanbe, a city of 600,000 people, was being guarded by special Soviet army commando units. Tadzhikistan's top three officials, including Communist Party chief Kakhar M. Makhkamov, offered to step down Wednesday because of the rioting. But the resignations were rejected Friday at an emergency session of the policy-making Central Committee of the republic's Communist Party. The committee decided that ``while there is such a difficult situation in the republic, its leaders do not have the right to resign,'' Mansur Sultanov of the Gostelradio state broadcasting authority said from Dushanbe. Sultanov said he had not heard the rumors of an impending massacre cited by Interfax. But he said an unauthorized demonstration was scheduled today. At previous demonstrations, held in defiance of government orders, Tadzhiks demanded the ouster of their party and government leaders. Ethnic Russians, who make up 10 percent of Tadzhikistan's population of 5 million, are worried about the unrest but so far are not leaving, Sultanov said. The scarcity of housing in Uzbekistan, which like Tadzhikistan has one of the Soviet Union's highest birth rates, seemed to be fueling nationalist sentiments there. The Presidium of the Tadzhikistan Supreme Soviet formed a special commission to investigate how people died in the week of violence, said Boris K. Pugo, a non-voting member of the ruling Politburo visiting Dushanbe.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested For 1946 Murder of Miami Cop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Milledge was ...' to CORRECT to `Overtown,' sted `Overton'; picks up 16th graf, `The Milledge ...'.
DOC.TEXT: When detectives arrested a man for the 1946 killing of a Miami police officer, they said he was expecting them, that he knew it was only a matter of time before they would arrive. But the arrest of 61-year-old Leroy Strachan on Thursday in lower Manhattan left the arresting officers from Miami with mixed emotions _ proud at solving an old case but bothered that the suspect apparently led a life untarnished by crime in New York. In the years since the slaying, Strachan got married, had three children _ one of them is a state corrections officer _ and worked for 21 years as a freight elevator operator. Miami Detective George Cadavid said the arrest was ``a great ego booster, no doubt. Not only was a human life taken but another police officer's life was taken. But here's a person who is now 61 years old and was 17 years old when the incident happened, and as far as we can tell, he's never been arrested.'' Strachan was arrested thanks to an anonymous tip eight months ago from a conscience-stricken witness, authorities said. Police said Strachan admitted to Miami detectives in late January that he had shot the officer. The victim, Officer John Milledge, was one of Miami's first black police officers. He told detectives he had been waiting to be arrested since they had talked to him in late January, the detectives said. ``He knew us,'' Cadavid said. ``He said, `Are you going to arrest me?''' and asked to call his attorney in Miami. ``He has admitted shooting the policeman and there is other evidence,'' Cadavid said. Strachan did not express any remorse over the shooting, the detective said. The suspect had several thousand dollars on him at the time of his arrest, leading police to think that he was about to leave the city. Strachan, still wearing his dark brown work uniform, looked nervous as he refused to waive extradition during a brief arraignment at Manhattan Criminal Court on Friday. Strachan's lawyer, Alan Mass, told Judge Bruce Allen the fact that Florida allowed capital punishment played a part in Strachan's decision. ``No way if it's within our power that Mr. Strachan is going back to Florida,'' Mass told reporters outside court. The judge ordered Strachan held without bail pending a March 14 hearing. Milledge was fatally shot Nov. 1, 1946, while on patrol outside a football game in the Overtown section of Miami, after he had chased and beaten several teens who tried to sneak into the game, Cadavid said. The Milledge case was reopened by the department's ``cold case squad'' after an anonymous July 1989 tip to Crime Stoppers from a woman who had seen a youth with a .22-caliber rifle running from the shooting scene. ``The reason she never came forward was because her husband was very good friends with the shooter,'' Cadavid said. The woman's husband died a few years ago ``and her conscience was bothering her,'' he said. Cadavid called a New York City detective, who ran a check and located Strachan. In late January, the Miami detectives talked with Strachan in New York. ``He told us what had happened, we went back to Miami to do some more investigation, to corroborate some of his story, we found witnesses. We found one witness that he had confessed to that same night,'' Cadavid said. Strachan said that the night of the slaying, Milledge had hit several youths. According to police, Strachan said he got a rifle from a friend, told everyone to step aside, fired one shot at Milledge, then ran. The next day he left for New York.

DOC.HEAD: Fruit Juice Pulled From Shelves in Canada
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen brands of fruit juice made at a local plant and shipped throughout much of Canada were being recalled after a chemical that causes cancer in laboratory animals was found in samples. Sundor Canada Inc., which is owned by Cincinnati-based Procter & Gamble Co., announced Friday it is recalling all its 48-ounce cans of juice made from concentrate. The juice is shipped primarily to Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec and Atlantic Canada. Health and Welfare Canada said the contaminated juices do not present a major health threat but the company had been asked to recall the products as a precaution. The company said juice not made from concentrate is not being recalled because it is processed without adding local water. The water has been found to be contaminated with the chemical N-nitroso dimethylamine, or DMNA. Also excluded from the recall are products in glass or plastic bottles and drinking boxes. The following brands are affected: Martins, Bright's, A and P, Dominion, IGA, Food City, Cavalier, Timothy's, Calbecks's, Pantry Shelf, Red Label, Sunshine, and Libby's Pineapple Juice. Tests taken from October to December found DMNA at levels reaching five parts per billion. The government's guideline for DMNA in drinking water is 0.014 parts per billion. DMNA is a waste byproduct in the manufacture of some agricultural and rubber products. It has been found in emissions from a Uniroyal Chemical plant in nearby Elmira. The province ordered the chemical plant shut down earlier this month after the DMNA turned up in nearby wells. Sundor Canada Inc., formerly known as Martins Foods Company, is owned by the Procter & Gamble Co. In a statement released Friday night, the company said: ``It is difficult to predict what level of DMNA would be potentially harmful'' given the varying amounts of juice that people drink. ``However, Sundor believes it is a prudent course of action to recall all these products until it has a better analysis of the risk involved.'' Barry Pipes, a company spokesman, said the recall involves ``thousands of cases'' of juice. Each case contains 12 48-ounce cans. The company did not specify what types of juice were affected. Pipes said the tests were performed because the company was concerned about local water quality. Earlier this week, about 160 million bottles of Perrier in 120 countries were being removed from shelves after the cancer-causing chemical benzene was found in some of the water. Perrier officials said some shipments of the bottled water were contaminated by a dirty filter at the company's underground spring in Vergeze, France. The filter is designed to remove naturally occurring benzene from the carbon dioxide gas that gives Perrier its distinctive bubble.

DOC.HEAD: More Snow in West, Plains, Northeast; Rain Near Gulf
DOC.TEXT: A storm lingered in the mountains of the West today after dumping as much as 3 feet of snow on the northern Sierra Nevada, while swollen rivers spilled over their banks in the Southeast following up to a foot of rain. ``I don't ever recall seeing this much rain in this short a period,'' said Carl Parker, a 30-year National Weather Service veteran in Fort Payne, Ala., site of 8 inches of rain in under 24 hours. Showers soaked Los Angeles, southern Texas, the Gulf and parts of Florida. Winds from the northwest cooled the Eastern states, although afternoon highs were likely to remain 10 degrees or more above normal from the eastern Carolinas to Florida. Parts of Utah and Wyoming braced for Pacific moisture and gusts up to 50 mph. Snow closed nearly 80 miles of Interstate 80 in northern California on Friday, dumping up to 3 feet of fresh snow on the mountains, with 2 feet recorded at Placerville and 18 inches in Auburn. Snow continued across the southern Great Lakes, on the Washington coast and in Northern Plains. Arctic air, flurries and sub-zero temperatures were expected by tonight in New England and upstate New York. Gusts of up to 45 mph buffeted Syracuse, N.Y., today. Thousands of customers were without power Friday in the Midwest and Northeast after snow and ice storms. Thunderstorms spawned tornadoes and heavy rain in the Southeast on Friday, triggering widespread flooding. Rising waters forced hundreds to evacuate in parts of Georgia, Tennessee, North Carolina, and Alabama. Tornadoes touched down at Carrollton, Ga., Irmo, S.C., and Chilton County, Ala. Wind gusted to 63 mph during a thunderstorm at Robins Air Force Base, Ga. Advisories for strong winds and wind chills near 60 below were posted for Montana's northwest passes. A winter storm watch was posted for the northwest valleys and for the mountains of northern Utah through tonight. Blinding snow postponed the sled dog races scheduled for the weekend in Truckee, Calif. Snowfall between 1 p.m. and 7 p.m. EST Friday included 10 inches at Reno, Nev., and 5 inches at Marquette, Mich. Record high temperatures set Friday for the date included 74 in Cape Hatteras, N.C.; 86 in Columbia, S.C.; 88 in Lakeland, Fla.; 58 in Mansfield, Ohio; 77 in Norfolk, Va.; and 63 in Youngstown, Ohio. DOC.HEAD: Report: Trump Considering Reconciliation
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump is considering reconciling with his wife, Ivana, because of the effects a divorce would have on the couple's three children, a published report said. The Daily News today quoted an unnamed source close to the billionaire developer who said Trump is thinking of ``dropping the whole thing'' for the children's welfare. The annonymous source told the News the immense publicity the planned divorce has generated has enabled Trump to ``test the waters of public opinion, and the results seem quite clear.'' The Trumps' children are Donald Jr., 12, Ivancka, 8, and Eric, 6. Word of the divorce was reported last Sunday and news about the couple's break-up has been splashed across the front of New York's three tabloids, including reports on purported Trump girlfriend Marla Maples. Trump's fortune is an estimated $1.7 billion. His major assets are the Trump Tower in New York, the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City, N.J, and the Trump Shuttle. The couple has a divorce agreement which was updated four times during their nearly 13-year marriage. It reportedly would give Ivana $25 million, a Connecticut estate and custody of their three children.

DOC.HEAD: Four Former Palace Guards Executed For Roles in Failed 1965 Coup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One name correct for Suharto, Sukarno, Solaeman
DOC.TEXT: Four members of former President Sukarno's palace guard have been executed after serving nearly a quarter century on death row for their involvement in a failed coup, a government spokesman said today. In Washington, the human rights group Asia Watch today asked President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to condemn the executions by firing squad, which it called ``an act of cowardice.'' Brig. Gen. Nurhadi Purwosaputro, an armed forces spokesman, confirmed that Solaeman, Noor Tohayana, Satar Suryanto and Yohannes Surono had been put to death Tuesday. All were arrested shortly after the abortive Communist coup on Sept. 30, 1965. They were charged with kidnapping and killing Gen. Achmad Yani, the army commander. They were convicted by a military tribunal. Officials gave no reason why the four remained on death row for 24 years, but delays in carrying out earlier executions were said to have been made to allow time for the accused to divulge information about their activities. The government executed nine former members of the banned Indonesian Communist Party in September 1986. The party was accused of planning the coup. In addition to Yani, five other army generals were killed in the coup bid, which was crushed within 48 hours by troops led by then Maj. Gen. Suharto. He is now president. In the bloodbath that followed the coup, an estimated 450,000 to 500,000 people were killed by anti-Communist forces. More than 500,000 also were detained following the uprising, among them some of the nation's best-known writers, poets, educators, journalists and intellectuals. Sukarno relinquished power to Suharto when calm was restored in March, 1966. Asia Watch sent messages to Bush, Gorbachev and other heads of state declaring that ``to spend a quarter century waiting to be killed is cruel and inhuman punishment by any standard.'' It also said the four guardsmen were sentenced by military courts after trials ``lacking any semblance of fairness.''

DOC.HEAD: China Faces Environmental Crisis, Conference Says
DOC.TEXT: Hazardous wastes have contaminated Chinese food, water and air far beyond international safety standards, causing ``significant damage'' to the health of millions of people, an international conference said today. The conference, organized by the Chinese government and the U.N. Development Program, also warned that water resources are fast being depleted. During the first three decade of Communist rule, pollution was considered a problem confined to capitalist countries. In recent years, China has passed an environmental protection law and laws on controlling water and air pollution, but it has lacked the money and personnel to reverse the steady deterioration of the environment. The 44 Chinese and 14 foreign experts at the five-day conference ending today called for ``urgent action'' to strengthen regulations and penalties, improve factory efficiency, and take steps to better manage the environment. Deng Nan, director-general of the Social Development Department and daughter of senior leader Deng Xiaoping, said ``significant damage is now occurring to the health of both urban and rural residents mainly due to economic constraints and rapid economic development.'' She said industrial wastes are destroying water resources and that the burning last year of 1 billion tons of coal _ about a ton per person _ has exacerbated respiratory diseases. The workshop said many factories, particularly small rural enterprises, lack any pollution control equipment and emit wastes and air pollutants directly into the environment. Poorly maintained equipment causes leaks, there is often little incentive to run factories efficiently, and managers lack information about how to protect the environment, it said. Ms. Deng said China must charge more for water and coal to encourage recycling and efficient use, invest in sewers and sewage treatment plants, and improve the quality of its coal so its combustion produces less ash, smoke and sulphur dioxide. The workshop also recommended that China put more effort into industrial planning, training of environmental experts, water conservation and enforcement of water pollution policies. Qu Geping, head of the National Environmental Protection Agency, said China now spends about $2 billion a year on the environment. That amount is 0.7 percent of its gross national product. He said his agency hopes to increase that amount to 1 percent of the gross national product by 1992, which would be one of the highest rates in the developing world. But he acknowledged that ``just to control today's level of pollution, it shouldn't be lower than 1.5 percent of GNP.'' The gross national product is a measures of the total worth of goods and services produced. Qu said a study made five years ago estimated pollution causes $12.8 billion in damage to the economy and the health of the nation every year.

DOC.HEAD: Police: VD Test Results on Day-Care Center Owner Are Negative
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents
DOC.TEXT: A day-care center owner accused of possessing child pornography tested negative for a veneral disease found in three children who attended his preschool, the police said. The attorney for John W. Shaver, who currently is free on $75,000 bond, said test results released Fiday indicate that either the children were infected by someone else or test results from the children were incorrect. ``I think the state should go back to the drawing board if they have three children who are testing positive for gonorrhea because, to me, it means that there may be someone else out there they should be looking for,'' said lawyer J. David Bogenschutz. Police spokesman Ott Cefkin said police are confident the test results are accurate. ``The Health Department told us they were absolutely positive in their findings,'' Cefkin said. Shaver, 56, faces charges of possessing child pornography and using pictures of children to create pornographic images. On Tuesday, police added 24 counts of procuring the sexual performance of a child. A venereal test given to Shaver as part of the conditions for his release from jail showed he did not have the sexually transmitted disease, police said. Shaver was tested after health officials discovered gonorrhea in throat cultures of three children who attended Shaver's Rainbow Learning Center. The new charges involve allegedly pornographic photo montages found in Shaver's home that combine pictures of children with nude pictures from magazines. Bogenschutz has entered an innocent plea on behalf of his client. About 200 children have attended Shaver's preschool since its opening in 1985. County officials closed it down this month as the police investigation widened.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Cast Ballots in Election for Moslem Government
DOC.TEXT: Voters in Moslem-dominated southern provinces went to the polls today to elect their first autonomous Moslem government, despite a wave of bombings, political brawls and ballot theft. The elections are being held under a plan by President Corazon Aquino to meet popular demand and blunt a Moslem insurgency in the region by allowing more local rule. Four candidates were running for regional governor, seven for vice governor, and 137 for 21 assembly seats in four Moslem-dominated provinces in the south, according to Commission on Election records.
