The four provinces _ Lanao Del Sur, Maguindanao, Tawi-tawi and Sulu _ voted to join the regional government in a referendum covering 13 southern provinces and cities in November. A bomb exploded on the eve of the polls, and another blast occurred an hour before polling stations opened today at 7 a.m. in the town of Jolo, 600 miles south of Manila, said Maj. Hermogenes Esperon, a spokesman for the military's Southern Command. An exploded grenade was also found, he said. No one was reported injured, and no one has claimed responsibility for the bombings. ``We hope that with the assurance of the armed forces ... this election will be a clean and credible one,'' said Commission on Elections Executive Director Vicente Delima. He was interviewed by a local radio station from Cotabato city, 530 miles southeast of Manila. Esperon said unidentified armed men snatched five ballot boxes in the town of Buldon in Maguindanao province. He gave no details, but local radio reports from the area said the men were followers of one of the candidates and pursuing soldiers killed as many as three of them. Meanwhile, 12 men were hurt in a brawl among followers of opposing candidates in the town of Marantao in nearby Lanao Del Sur province. No arrests were reported. Local radio reports also said armed men seized ballot boxes, and firefights occurred in the Maguindanao towns of Matanago, Buluan and Barira. Balloting was canceled in the village of Gata. Critics have questioned the viability of the autonomous region, saying that the four provinces are among the poorest in the country, lack adequate communications and transportation, and are not even contiguous. The regional government will control its own police force and take responsibility for taxation, natural resources, economic development and education. Responsibility for foreign affairs, defense and customs remains with Mrs. Aquino's government. The Moro National Liberation Front, a Moslem guerrilla group, has opposed the plan as inadequate and vowed to continue its nearly 20-year rebellion to secede.

DOC.HEAD: New Attorney Claims Imelda is Wrongly Prosecuted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT `compared with' to `compared to.' Other minor editing.
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos' new attorney, trying to repair the image of the former Philippine first lady, asks that people compare her to Nancy Reagan. ``Suppose Mrs. Reagan were abducted from her home in California and taken to the Philippines and charged in the Philippines with crimes she allegedly committed in the U.S.,'' the attorney, Gerry Spence, said Friday. ``How do you think Mrs. Reagan would feel?'' Spence made his remarks after a federal court hearing on the racketeering indictment that charged Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, Ferdinand Marcos, with embezzling more than $100 million from the Philippine treasury to buy art and Manhattan real estate. They also were charged with defrauding banks of $165 million in loans. Marcos died in exile in Hawaii on Sept. 28 at age 72. Spence of Jackson Hole, Wyo., who had represented the family of Karen Silkwood, was hired by Mrs. Marcos as part of changes in her defense team that included the dropping of two other attorneys. Mrs. Marcos' trial had been scheduled to start March 13 but at the hearing, U.S. District Judge John Keenan delayed it a week, until March 20, to give Spence more time to prepare his case. In his statement to reporters, Spence said, ``I hope you take the opportunity to view this case from the perspective of a woman instead of a queen because women have rights whether they're a queen or not.'' He claimed the case was a political prosecution. Spence, who has written several books including ``And Justice for None,'' gained prominence when he tackled chemical giant Kerr-McGee in 1979 to win a $10.5 million jury award for the heirs of Karen Silkwood. A federal appeals court reversed the award and the family later settled for a smaller amount. Silkwood, who worked at a Kerr-McGee plutonium plant in Oklahoma, was killed in a car crash in 1974 on her way to meet a reporter to talk about alleged workers' exposure to plutonium. The two attorneys leaving Mrs. Marcos' legal team are Richard A. Hibey of Washington, her former lead counsel, and Sandor Frankel of New York. Spence would not comment on why the two were leaving, but Hibey had been named in a possible conflict of interest raised by prosecutors, who said they intended to call one of his law partners as a witness. Spence said Mrs. Marcos had become distressed when he discussed the possible conflict with her.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Fighting Shifts to Helicopter Base
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE casualty figures, new quotes. Pickup 5th graf, `The short...'
DOC.TEXT: People emerged from their bunkers today and showered rice on troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun as the soldiers rumbled through two devastated neighborhoods captured from a rival Christian militia. ``Long live the army! Long live Aoun!'' weary residents shouted from balconies strung with Lebanese flags. ``We lived 17 days underground. It's so good to breathe fresh air again!'' a woman shouted as she and others sunned themselves on a pockmarked balcony overlooking a burned armored personnel carrier. For many, however, there was little to celebrate after 18 days of fighting for mastery of Lebanon's 310-square-mile Christian enclave. The battle has killed 615 people and wounded 1,829. ``My poor children. What has happened to your father?'' a mother sobbed in Ein Rummaneh as she hugged her two kids. Her husband was a militiaman for Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces, pushed out of the residential district on Friday after a savage, two-day attack. Aoun's command, in a communique, said the Lebanese Forces mounted an attack at dawn today against the helicopter base at Adma in the Christian heartland of Kesrouan province. The short communique, broadcast by Aoun's Radio Lebanon, said the 500 commandos in charge of defending the base were ``confronting the gunmen.'' It did not elaborate. The base is the only military facility that remains loyal to Aoun in Kesrouan province, the power base for Geagea's militia. Aoun's radio said the attack started ``behind a fierce artillery and rocket barrage.'' It did not disclose further details. Military sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 12 of Lebanon's 18 French-made helicopter gunships are at the Adma base. Today's attack came a few hours after 900 soldiers from Aoun's 19,000-member army, advancing behind 36 U.S.-made M-48 tanks, dislodged Geagea's militia from Ein Rummaneh on Beirut's southeastern edge in a savage, two-day attack that wrecked the residential district. At least 75 people were killed and 54 wounded in the assault on Ein Rummaneh, police said. A carpet of glass shards and debris covered the narrow alleys of Ein Rummaneh. Smoke continued to billow today from hundreds of gutted apartment buildings. Pieces of furniture blown out of shelled apartments were scattered in the streets. Water from blasted rooftop tanks drained into underground shelters. ``The people of Lebanon are subjected to the ugliest wave of annihilation in their history at the hands of Gen. Aoun .... Silence is a crime. All available means must be used to save Lebanon,'' Geagea said in his appeal, which was repeatedly broadcast by the Christian Voice of Lebanon radio. His reference to the ``legitimate authority'' was a call on Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi to intervene to dislodge the rebellious general from his command headquarters at the shell-wrecked presidential palace, which he has refused to relinquish. Geagea's mention of ``available means'' appeared to be a signal that the chieftain of the 6,000-member Christian militia would not object to an intervention by the 40,000 Syrian troops deployed in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. The leftist Beirut newspaper As-Safir, which is close to Hrawi, reported ``movements'' by Hrawi's troops and Syrian soldiers in Moslem west Beirut and the southeastern mountains overlooking the Christian enclave overnight. There were no details. Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic like Aoun and Geagea, was elected Nov. 24 under a peace plan brokered by the Arab League. The plan was designed to end the country's nearly 15-year-old civil war and provide more power to the nation's Moslems. Aoun, who was serving as head of an interim Cabinet, rejected the peace pact and the government of Hrawi. Aoun, who refused Hrawi's order to quit as army commander, has criticized the peace plan for not laying out a timetable for a complete withdrawal of Syrian forces. Geagea has recognized Hrawi, but he has been vague on the peace agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Adviser: No German Unity if West Insists on NATO Membership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with top Gorbachev adviser saying there won't be German unity if the West insists on NATO membership. Pick up 17th pvs, `West Germany's...'
DOC.TEXT: A top-ranking adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today ``there won't be any unification'' if the West insists on NATO membership for the combined German states. The issues of NATO membership and the German military stance have become increasingly important as plans for German unity advance. ``If the Western alliance sticks with its demand for a NATO membership of all of Germany, then there won't be any German unification,'' said Valentin Falin in an interview with Saarland state radio. Falin, in addition to serving as a Gorbachev adviser, is the head of the international section of the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee. He is a former Soviet ambassador to West Germany. Falin called on Western nations to use the opportunity of German unity to ensure peace in Europe. ``We are talking about doing away with the military factor in Europe overall,'' he said. West German officials, pushing ahead with plans for German unification, have proposed a 16-state united Germany with NATO membership but left open the possibility that Soviet troops might remain in the eastern sector. ``Defense obligations are indivisible and cannot be weakened for a whole Germany,'' Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg of West Germany said Friday, adding that military integration will be an initial step. Stoltenberg said defense officials of East and West Germany will meet after the East German elections March 18 to work out a joint security policy and that the continued presence of Soviet troops in what is now East Germany was open to discussion. He raised the possibility of a ``transitional phase'' in which the West German and East German armies would cooperate while retaining their own command structures, but also said: ``We are not going to have two different armed forces in a united Germany for long.'' The Soviet Union has been insisting that a united Germany be neutral, while Western allies want it to remain in NATO. The push for quick unification is worrying some countries that suffered occupation by Nazi Germany, such as Poland. Poland has asked to be included in talks on German unification between the two German states and the four World War II allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. On Friday, East German Premier Hans Modrow endorsed the Polish request during a visit to Warsaw. West Germany's foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who has rejected the Polish request, said Friday that immediately after East German elections next month, the two governments must declare that they will have no territorial claims against their European neighbors after reunification. ``This applies especially for Poland,'' Genscher said. He said German unity will enhance European stability. An international Holocaust awareness organization said victims of the last united Germany, which produced Hitler and the Nazis, have ``great fears'' of the rush toward reunification. Letters to Kohl and Modrow from the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles said the fears stem in part from the fact that the Germans have not consulted thos victims about reunificiation. ``Not a single word is said publicly about the great internal questions of how to educate millions of people who have lived under an oppressive regime and have been cut off from the real world for more than 40 years, and how to prevent their ignorance of the past from negatively affecting the course of the future,'' said Rabbi Marvin Hier in a letter dated Feb. 9 and released Friday. Hier proposed education programs, oversight committees, strong ties to Israel and establishment of Holocaust memorials and Jewish cultural exchange programs.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Nepali Leaders Placed Under House Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with government sources confirming arrests, note that Sunday is National Democracy Day. Pickup 7th graf, `On Tuesday...'
DOC.TEXT: The government today put three main opposition leaders under house arrest on the eve of their planned launch of a pro-democracy movement in the Himalayan kingdom. The arrests follow the detention of the leader of the United Left Front and hundreds of other activists who demand an end to Nepal's 29-year-old ban on political parties. Police surrounded the home of Ganesh Man Singh, a senior leader of newly formed Nepali Congress Party, and placed him under house arrest, family sources said. Armed police guarded the entrance and did not allow anyone to enter. Government sources confirmed that arrest, and said authorities also put under house arrest Krishna Prasad Bhattarai, the acting president of the leftist party, and G.P. Koirala, the party's secretary-general. The sources described the action as ``preventative detention.'' The party planned to formally launch a popular opposition movement Sunday demanding a multiparty system. It is supported by the United Left, a coalition of the seven factions of the outlawed Communist Party. Sunday is Nepal's 40th National Democracy Day. On Tuesday, police arrested senior United Left officials, including its leader, Sahana Pradhan. Bhattarai on Friday said that more than 2,200 activists, including a large number of students, had been rounded up by the police in a nationwide crackdown on dissent. But the Home Ministry later that day issued a statement saying only 559 persons suspected of involvement in disruptive activities in the movement had been taken into custody. It said further investigations were under way. Bhattarai had said the Nepali Congress would carry out its platform even if its three top leaders were arrested. He said the movement would be peaceful and non-violent, and added ``if anything happens, the entire responsibility lies with the government.'' Although the party is outlawed, it runs an office in a downtown building. The government, a constitutional monarchy, contends that the party is trying to force its own version of democracy. On Friday, the International Press Institute said King Birendra's government seized editions of two weekly newspapers that gave extensive coverage to the campaign for multiparty democracy. The institute, which has offices in London and Zurich, said the editions were seized Tuesday. It issued a protest to Home Minister Niranjan Thapa, calling for an end to ``harassment, fear and intimidation.'' King Birendra, who is seen as a reincarnation of the Hindu god Vishnu, has ruled for 17 years. It is against the law to criticize him.

DOC.HEAD: 18 Countries Say Pressure on South Africa Must Be Maintained
DOC.TEXT: The foreign ministers of 18 European and Asian countries today praised recent reforms in South Africa but said international pressure should be maintained until Pretoria begins dismantling apartheid. The declaration came at the end of a two-day annual conference of the European Economic Community and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. The ministers met after President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa lifted a ban on Nelson Mandela's African National Congress and other groups on Feb. 2, then released the black nationalist leader on Sunday after 27 years in prison. On Friday, the exiled leadership of the ANC said it would send a delegation to South Africa to meet with de Klerk to discuss opening talks on ending the group's three-decade guerrilla war against apartheid. De Klerk wants to negotiate a new constitution that will include the 28 million black majority in the national government. But he opposes a one-man, one-vote system and outright black majority rule, the basic demand of all leading anti-apartheid groups, including the ANC. He envisions some mechanism that will give whites veto power on major policy decisions. ``While welcoming the recent lifting of the ban on the ANC and other organizations and the release of Mr. Nelson Mendela, they were of the view that more needed to be done in order to establish a climate conducive to a meaningful dialogue,'' the ministers' declaration said. It added the ministers' ``common objective was the complete and peaceful eradication of the apartheid system and that, pending evidence of clear and irreversible change to this end, appropriate pressure should be maintained on the South African government.'' A senior official at the talks, speaking on condition of anonymity, said some countries at the meeting even want more pressure put on South Africa to end its system of racial discrimination. The 12 EEC members are Britain, Spain, the Netherlands, France, Italy, Portugal, Luxembourgh, West Germany, Denmark, Belgium, Ireland and Greece. The six ASEAN countries are the Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand, Brunei, Malaysia and Singapore.

DOC.HEAD: Delegate in Mexico Will Now Be Pope's Envoy to President
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican's delegate to the Catholic Church in Mexico will also become the pope's envoy to the Mexican president, the Vatican said today, prompting speculation that formal diplomatic relations will be restored. Overwhelmingly Catholic Mexico has had no formal ties with the Vatican since 1926, when Mexico expelled the papal envoy during a crackdown on Catholic dissidents. ``A significant step,'' read the title of a Vatican announcement. The Vatican said Pope John Paul II and Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari established permanent envoys to allow ``a permanent dialogue about common interest and for contributing to a useful cooperation.'' The pope plans to make his second visit to Mexico in May. On Wednesday, Mexico's interior secretary announced that the president would soon appoint a personal representative. The announcement caused outcries by opposition groups, which accused the government of violating Mexico's constitutional separation of church and state. The issue is a sensitive one in Mexico, where the church was historically linked with landowners and other power groups which resisted social change. Mexican law prohibits clergy from teaching in universities and schools and even bans priests from voting or wearing their collar in public.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Picks New Defense Minister Sought By Army
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6-7 grafs, `Interim President...the officers.' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with the president saying the ousted minister created tension in army. Pickup 8th, ``At its...''
DOC.TEXT: The soldiers who helped overthrow the Ceausescu regime won another victory today when the provisional government appointed a new defense minister of their choosing to replace the one they forced out. Victor Anastase Stanculescu, a lieutenant general who was the economic minister, was named to replace Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru. The appointment climaxed a week-long protest by junior and middle-level officers who demanded the dismissal of 74-year-old Militaru because they said he had not carried out the democratic reforms called for in the December revolution that toppled hard-line Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. On Thursday night, state-run television broadcast a frank but edited tape of talks between Deputy Prime Minister Gelu Voican Voiculescu and 58 officers from 38 units who presented a list of 13 demands including Militaru's ouster. At one point, Voiculescu asked the officers who they would wanted as defense chief and they said Stanculescu. At Stanculescu's installation ceremony today, interim President Ion Iliescu said the new minister ``has prestige in the army and is appreciated by its command.'' Militaru, Iliescu said, ``did not succeed in establishing a real communication with the army's command, aggravating the situation in the army to a point at which it became a source of tension for all of society.'' Iliescu said Romania still faces ``a grave situation of the political, social and economic spheres.'' He did not say who would head the economic ministry. The appointment of a new defense minister defused the first challenge by the military to the government it helped create in December's revolution. At its first meeting Friday, the 21-member Executive Bureau of the ruling Council of National Unity endorsed the creation of a commission to investigate all the officers' demands and expressed hope that the measures taken by the government would calm the situation in the country. Iliescu heads the bureau. Thousands of civilians had flocked to Victory Square in Bucharest to support the officers, whose decision to back the popular uprising in December was crucial to winning the revolution. Similar demonstrations were held in Timisoara and the port of Constanta. The newspaper Tineretul Liber reported today that a big demonstration backing the officers was also held in Brasov, Romania's second-largest city, on Friday. Protesters shouted, ``The army is with us, and we are with the army.'' The newspaper Adevarul said today that before Iliescu's announcement, the national news agency Rompres had received a statement from a committee of the Military Central Command backing the officers' call for Militaru's resignation. The committee called for the ministry to be run by generals and officers ``not compromised during the revolution.'' It also demanded the retirement of all officers, like Militaru, who were recalled to active duty during the revolution. Navy officers from Tulcea in the Danube delta also backed the officers, the newspaper Romania Libera reported.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Disputes China Limitations, But Signs Bill Anyway
DOC.NOTE: EDS: To address issue of line-item veto and possible lawsuit over issue, INSERT new second and third grafs and four grafs after 10th pvs, ``However, Bush ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, in a new clash with Congress over China policy, says he'll ignore parts of a spending package that he considers an infringement on his right to conduct diplomacy. A White House official said today that the action was not an attempt to assert presidential line-item veto powers. ``It's not a line-item veto. As president, he's going to fulfill the role laid out by the Constitution. He is saying he will not recognize parts of the legislation that he thinks are unconstitutional,'' said Stephen Hart, deputy press secretary. Bush late Friday signed a $9.8 billion State Department bill that reinforces sanctions on China and requires that Congress be notified when such secret missions as national security adviser Brent Scowcroft's visit last June to Beijing are undertaken. The president, at his oceanside home for a three-day weekend, signed the bill but voiced serious objections to those sections and several others which he said raised ``constitutional difficulties.'' The Constitution gives the president exclusive power ``to receive and appoint ambassadors and to conduct negotiations on behalf of the United States with foreign governments,'' Bush told Congress. The overall legislation authorizes $4.8 billion for the State Department and related agencies for the fiscal year that began last Oct. 1, and another $5 billion for fiscal 1991. Bush vetoed an earlier version of the legislation, not only because of the China sanctions but also due to an amendment that would have prohibited the administration from seeking third-country financing of insurgent groups, such as the Nicaraguan Contras. Congress dropped that proposal from the current legislation. U.S. support of the Contras was phased out under a bipartisan accord with Congress. The bill writes into law sanctions identical to those Bush imposed on China after last May's bloody crackdown in Tiananmen Square, including a ban on military sales to China and restrictions on trade and loans. Bush declared, ``Legislatively mandated sanctions represent an unwise constraint upon the president's ability to conduct foreign policy.'' However, Bush signed the bill with the assertion he would not follow sections he considered unconstitutional. Some senior White House officials have claimed that the Constitution grants the president the power to veto individual parts of legislation, the so-called line-item veto. Many constitutional scholars dispute that contention. Refusal to follow certain sections of the State Department bill would be tantamount to a line-item veto. The Washington Post, in today's editions, quoted an administration official as saying the administration is considering a lawsuit over the bill to test the issue. An administration official told The Associated Press todaythis was not the intent and there was ``no way'' the administration would initiate such a lawsuit. In Congress, Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., chairman of the House Judiciary constitutional rights subcommittee, has said he would sue Bush if he sought to cast a line-item veto. Bush noted the legislation allows him to waive sanctions on grounds of ``national interest'' and suggested this clause put enough flexibility into the measure to allow it to escape a veto. The sanctions remain in effect for now and Bush has no immediate plans to lift them, said deputy press secretary Stephen Hart. Bush flatly said he would disobey the section of the legislation that would require the State Department to give Congress a full report on any politically sensitive secret diplomatic contacts. The restriction was an outgrowth of the clandestine trip to Beijing last June, shortly after the Tiananmen Square crackdown, by Scowcroft and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. That trip, coming soon after Bush banned high-level exchanges between U.S. and Chinese officials, was roundly criticized on Capitol Hill. ``Such blanket reporting requirements could be read to compel the disclosure of sensitive ongoing negotiations,'' Bush said. Bush's statement is the latest dispute with Congress over China policy. Earlier this year, the Senate narrowly sustained Bush's veto of legislation that would have extended visas of Chinese students studying in the United States. Bush asserted he was affording the same protection to the Chinese students by executive order. The measure he signed also would provide $16 million in start-up funds for ``TV Marti,'' which will broadcast from the United States into Cuba and be a sister station to the ``Radio Marti'' that has operated for several years. Bush and his wife, Barbara, flew to the snow-covered coastal community of Kennebunkport on Friday for the three-day Presidents' Day weekend. The Bushes planned to see how remodeling work is progressing on the family home overlooking the Atlantic. The Bushes are having rooms remodelled as a gift to each other on their 45th wedding anniversary last month. Only two rooms now can be heated in the winter, a bedroom and a kitchen. Hart said the Bushes planned to spend the weekend ``privately relaxing,'' with no planned activities and no guests, before returning to Washington on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Goes to Washington With Message of Change
LaserPhoto PRA1
DOC.TEXT: Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's unconventional president, goes to Washington this week to tell the Bush administration that swift policy changes are needed if America is to retain its standing among the people of Eastern Europe. Although many East Europeans resent the way the West abandoned them to Stalin more than 40 years ago, the United States is widely admired as a beacon of freedom. In an interview at his lunchtime haunt, the Vikarka restaurant inside the sprawling presidential castle, Havel indicated that Washington will have to work hard to keep that standing now that Europe is changing. ``The United States were traditionally seen here as a guarantor of democracy, and (America) may be more popular here than in other countries, and rightly so,'' Havel told The Associated Press last week. ``But that doesn't mean that in a radically changing situation _ the process of disintegration of the Soviet bloc _ the United States will not be called upon to pursue a different policy than to date. ``It is a phenomenon which has to be reflected upon and projected into the future policy,'' Havel said, leaning over the table. ``It is my impression that if the United States does this courageously and quickly, it will be only for its own good.'' Havel is reluctant to give specifics, particularly before he outlines his ideas for President Bush during a hectic three-day visit that begins Monday. He will also address Congress and meet New York cultural figures. Since taking office Dec. 29, Havel has acted decisively to give new style and substance to Czechoslovak policy. Diplomatic relations have been established with Israel and South Korea. Prague has translated the latitude won by the overthrow of Stalinism into a new independence toward Moscow, insisting the Soviets start pulling their hated troops out of Czechoslovakia. Havel was only four days in office when he visited both Germanys and gave guarded approval to reunification, then traveled to Poland to propose that Prague, Warsaw and Budapest pool economic, political and other efforts to ``re-enter Europe.'' In style, Havel has set standards all his own. Donning a suit if necessary for ceremonial occasions, he otherwise favors the dark sweaters and corduroy trousers he wore as a dissident playwright. Several of his advisers _ rock singer Ladislav Kantor, now chief of protocol, personal secretary Vladimir Hanzal, castle artist Joska Skalnik _ have the long hair and beards that complete the 1960s air of this new government. The 53-year-old president has meditated with the Dalai Lama, chatted with American rock star Frank Zappa (Zappa wore the suit), and admitted to traveling castle corridors on a child's scooter. Outsiders may puzzle at such presidential behavior. But Czechs, who have an ingrained appreciation of the absurd, seem to find it refreshing and to feel that they have found a real leader. Posters and lapel pins of Havel are all over Prague. When he leaves the restaurant, schoolchildren gather to applaud and shout, ``Long Live Havel!'' ``Love, desire for understanding, strength of spirit and idea can radiate forever from our country, if we want this to happen,'' he told his compatriots in a New Year's Day address, suggesting they make this ``our very own contribution to world politics.'' ``Let us teach both ourselves and others that politics does not have to be the art of the possible, especially if what is meant by this is the art of speculating, calculating ... and pragmatic maneuvering, but that it also can be the art of the impossible, that is the art of making both ourselves and the world better,'' Havel urged. Discussing the new style of his government, Havel bristled at the suggestion his administration smacks of American hippies of the 1960s. He clearly sees a chance to marry some of the ideas of the 1960s with the sophistication of the 1980s and what Czechoslovaks learned from the repression that followed the crushing of liberal reforms in 1968. John Lennon, Zappa and other heroes of the 1960s became symbols of freedom for Czechoslovak youth through the harsh 1970s and 1980s. ``The phenomenon known as the '60s was indeed a sort of inspiration'' for Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution last year, Havel said. ``But 20 years has elapsed since then, the world is different,'' he added. Hippies, students, Vietnam draft dodgers and others ``were predominantly movements of protest, anti-establishment movements which developed into destructive movements, destroying the ossified old structures but unable to offer something new, something better. ``The inevitable outcome was that the hippies cut their hair, put on their suits and became law-abiding Americans,'' Havel said. ``In our case, especially the younger generation _ which is partly inspired by the nonconformism of the 60s, faces a duty to do it better, to provide a concrete program, to enter politics.'' Feeling that society was calling him to inspire such efforts, Havel agreed during the revolution to become president. He still insists, ``I would much rather be a writer than a president.'' But he is visibly enjoying the job, and there is a widespread feeling in Prague that this unique president is going to be in the castle beyond June's free election, breathing fresh spirit into world and domestic politics for some time to come.

DOC.HEAD: Historic Blue-Collar Neighborhood Faces Eviction
LaserPhoto MI1
DOC.TEXT: There are just 15 houses in the spot on the map known as ``Pigsville,'' but residents say that when the doomed enclave is destroyed next year in a bridge-rebuilding project it will be the end of a close-knit way of life. The fate of one of Milwaukee's oldest and most stable blue-collar neighborhoods has been sealed by the very bridge that has given it an identity the last 80 years. Pigsville, on the bank of the Menomonee River west of downtown, will be destroyed in 1991 when the mammoth Wisconsin Avenue Bridge whose approach forms one of its borders is rebuilt under a $15.3 million project. ``There's a lot of irony in it. It's a unique, special neighborhood that now will be gone, resigned to the history books,'' said Alderman Michael Murphy, whose district includes Pigsville. The 40 or so residents who have lived in the neighborhood _ many for decades _ will be relocated starting in August. They'll be leaving behind the asphalt-tile roofs, limestone basements and creaky stairwells of their century-old homes. They'll also leave behind the smell of hops from the huge Miller Brewing Co. brewery across the river, the sounds of crowds cheering at Milwaukee Brewers games at County Stadium a quarter-mile away and the plate-rattling vibrations of Soo Line trains that pass on the western edge of the neighborhood. But most of all, the residents will miss the camaraderie that goes back decades and the privacy of an isolated neighborhood where crime is rare and friends can venture outside in their bathrobes for an early-morning chat. ``Our biggest fear going somewhere else is neighborhoods don't get his close,'' said Kim Papp, whose family has lived in Pigsville since 1922. ``It's a great place to live. We're all going to miss it.'' Mrs. Papp, 30, her husband, William, a plumber, and two daughters live next door to the two-story house where her husband's father, grandmother and grandmother's sister-in-law still live. ``Our daughters are the fifth generation to live down here,'' she said. ``There's a lot of history. Bill's great-grandfather helped build the Wisconsin Avenue viaduct.'' That viaduct, the main bridge for the main drag leading toward downtown, was completed in 1911, boasting concrete arches that resemble a Roman aqueduct. The bridge is the main symbol for Pigsville, but it is suffering from long-term deterioration and must be replaced. And the replacement project will mean the leveling of the clutch of houses at its base. The river, the railroad tracks and the approach to a smaller bridge to the south form the other boundaries of Pigsville. There's only one road leading in. ``Unless you know where you're going, it's hard to find,'' said resident Sue Wiederstein. ``There's only one way in and one way out. It's like a little city suburb. There's no sidewalks. We don't have driveways or garages. We don't have problems.'' How the area got its name, which dates back to before the turn of the century, is a mystery. One story attributes the moniker to a man who kept pigs, while another holds that the area was named after a dentist named Dr. Pigg. Yet another says it was named for iron castings _ known as pigs _ poured from a smelting furnace at a nearby foundry. While residents throughout the Menomonee River valley often stake claim as members of Pigsville, most agree the 15-home neighborhood of bungalows and cottages at the base of the viaduct is the original Pigsville. Early residents were German immigrants, later supplanted by Slavs. Pigsville has had its share of excitement. Occasionally, the Menomonee is known to rise above its banks with spring rains, sending water through the streets. Roughly once every 10 years, one of the passing Soo Line trains has derailed, sounding a bone-shaking clamor. At least three times, despondent people jumped to their deaths from one of the bridges above. But perhaps the single biggest event was in the early 1980s when neighborhood residents joined together to force the closing of a popular tavern called Fourth Base because patrons sometimes plucked flowers from neatly kept gardens or urinated in the road. The final chapter is at hand. The bridge project is slated to begin in 1991 with demolition of the homes and bridge. The new bridge, which will preserve the original architectural design, will probably take two years to complete. Leonard Bielinsky, 77, a retired shoemaker, reared 11 children in Pigsville. He and his wife, Irene, moved to their 120-year-old home in 1950 and expected to live there until they died. ``We don't know where we're going. We can't do anything till they make us an offer. Thrown out. That's how I feel about it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Eases Curbs on Foreign Visitors to the United States
DOC.TEXT: Anarchists, communists and advocates of totalitarian government will be allowed into the United States under a law signed by President Bush unless officials can find a reason to keep them out that goes beyond their political beliefs. The measure, part of a $9.8 billion State Department authorization Bush signed Friday night, effectively repeals part of a 1952 law that barred visitors with radical views. Nobel laureates Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Pablo Neruda have been excluded under the law in recent years as well as authors Graham Greene, Doris Lessing and Carlos Fuentes, according to a Senate Foreign Relations Committee report. Among others excluded were French actor Yves Montand; former Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith; Hortensia Allende, widow of the Marxist president of Chile, and Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization. ``For a generation and more, these miserable provisions made the United States present itself to other nations as a nation of fearful, muddled, intimidated citizens,'' said Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y. ``The so-called look-out list of excludable aliens maintained by the State Deparment should be purged of the names of persons previously considered ineligible because of political beliefs or associations,'' Moynihan declared. Still subject to exclusion under the new measure are ``aliens who are polygamists or who practise polygamy or advocate the practice of polygamy.'' Polygamy itself, but not advocacy of polygamy, is forbidden by state law in most of the country. Lawyers familiar with immigration could not recall any problems with polygamists visiting the United States, who include many leaders of Moslem countries. The Senate committee report said the new provisions would not prevent the government from barring visitors on grounds of national security or foreign policy. Others still barred under the law _ but not always in practice _ are the mentally retarded, the insane, criminals, pimps, prostitutes, paupers, vagrants, professional beggars, stowaways, drug addicts, chronic alcoholics and those with a dangerous contagious disease or likely to become burdens on the American public. There is also a ban on, but no definition of, those ``afflicted with psychopathic personality, or sexual deviation, or a mental defect.'' Another undefined but excluded group is: ``Aliens coming to the United States to engage in any immoral sexual act.''

DOC.HEAD: Flooding in South Kills 3; Snow Blankets Sierra Nevada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-9, `A few rivers...', with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Smyrna, Ga., fatality; INSERTS 1 graf after 21st, `Snow closed...', to UPDATE with morning conditions, interstate still closed. Picks up 22nd graf pvs, `More snow...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LX1
DOC.TEXT: A storm blanketed the Sierra Nevada with up to 3 feet of snow, stranding motorists and cutting power lines, while a freak warm front in the South brought tornadoes and flooding that drove hundreds from their homes. Snow gave way to freezing rain Friday in an icy trail across the upper Midwest and the Northeast but power outages caused by earlier blizzards continued. ``Hot wires are falling all over the place,'' said police dispatcher Rosemarie Million in Erie, Pa. The Puget Sound area of Washington was hit for the second straight year with unusually heavy snowfalls. Seattle had up to 10 inches of snow by Saturday morning and Olympia, to the south, had an accumulation of 20 inches from snowfalls Wednesday and Friday. The area, noted for its rain not its snow, saw two snowfalls in Seattle last year of about 12 inches each, and Olympia had about half that last year. A few rivers began receding in some areas of the Southeast this morning, but other rivers were still rising after up to 12 inches of rain fell on the region. Flooding has claimed at least four lives since Friday. The Ocoee River jumped its banks, swept away a new bridge and ran 8 feet deep in the streets of Copperhill, Tenn., and across the river at McCaysville, Ga., where about 500 people were evacuated from their homes. ``There are porches from other houses that have been damaged and are coming down the river,'' said Russell Newman, a rescue official. ``I don't know whether you'd call it looting or not, but I saw some guys fishing stuff out of the river as it floated by.'' The Ocoee also swamped a footbridge at a Tennessee Valley Authority hydroelectric dam, flooding the power station and trapping six TVA workers, who were rescued by helicopter. Police in the Atlanta suburb of Smyrna today found the body of a 69-year-old man in a car in a flooded parking lot, where the vehicle apparently stalled and submerged. Churning waters forced the evacuation of up to 1,000 people in Trion, Ga., about 30 miles south of Chattanooga, Tenn. A man drowned when his car stalled in floodwaters. This morning, the Chattooga County sheriff's department said the water receded several feet overnight and main roads were now open, but that authorities were not allowing residents back to their homes yet. Gerald Birdo of the National Weather Service said the flooding in some areas of the South was the worst since 1979. ``I don't ever recall seeing this much rain in this short a period,'' said Carl Parker, a 30-year weather service veteran in Fort Payne, Ala., site of 8 inches of rain in under 24 hours. One of many twisters that tunneled through the Southeast destroyed or damaged 38 homes in Carrollton, Ga. ``Some houses looked like they just exploded,'' said Capt. Robert Lee of the Carroll County Sheriff's Department. ``It looked like a bomb hit right in the middle of the subdivision.'' Tornadoes also were recorded in Alabama, South Carolina and Mississippi. About 80 people were evacuated from a flooded rest home in Cullowhee, in western North Carolina. A man in nearby Transylvania County was swept away by the rain-swollen French Broad River as he tried to save his trout farm. Rapidly rising waters closed dozens of schools and roads in northern Alabama, while tornadoes in the southern part of the state ripped apart mobile homes and shattered trees. At least 200 people statewide had to leave their homes. An elderly woman lost her footing and drowned while fording a flooded creek near her home in Cherokee County, Ala., in northeastern Alabama near the Georgia border, said Leon Smith, the county's emergency management coordinator. Meanwhile, the heaviest winter storm in 74 years blanketed Reno, Nev., with snow that fell at rates of up to 4 inches, and freezing homes were blacked out by a power outage. The snow was so blindingly fast and heavy that even a sled dog race scheduled to begin today had to be be postponed until Sunday. Snow closed nearly 80 miles of Interstate 80 in northern California on Friday, dumping up to 3 feet of fresh snow on the mountains, with 2 feet recorded at Placerville and 18 inches in Auburn. At dawn, I-80 still was closed from Auburn to the Nevada state line, but westbound lanes opened early today for vehicles with tire chains. U.S. 50 was open to vehicles with chains, which were required on all mountain roads. More snow fell overnight in the Sierra Nevada, with accumulations of up to 2 feet expected, the National Weather Service said, but much of the storm was heading east toward Utah and Wyoming. Lyle LaFaver, a spokesman for Pacific Gas and Electric, said tens of thousands of customers were without power late Friday ``and they'll probably be out all night.'' ``We've had problems with very heavy, very wet snow,'' he said. In the San Francisco Bay area, wind gusts to 60 mph downed trees and power lines Friday, and heavy rains caused mud slides and snarle traffic.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Enclave Looks Like Earthquake Zone After Battle
DOC.TEXT: Glass shards crunched underfoot as Red Cross workers removed the body of a Lebanese Forces fighter crushed by his burned-out tank against the wall of a demolished building. Gen. Michel Aoun's soldiers warned civilians not to touch corpses, saying some of them had been booby-trapped by the fleeing Lebanese Forces militiamen led by Samir Geagea. Two other Red Cross workers in bright orange uniforms trudged through a pile of garbage near the Soviet-made T-54 tank in the Furn el-Shubbak neighborhood, trying to slip a metal stretcher under the body of a second militiaman. ``We found the lower part of the body near the garbage. The upper part was 10 yards away,'' said one Red Cross worker as he waved off swarming flies. Parents shooed away youngsters watching the scene. ``Where are the other two bodies?'' one harried rescuer asked his colleague. ``There were four militiamen in the tank.'' An eerie silence hung over Furn el-Shubbak and Ein Rummaneh on Saturday, a day after Aoun's soldiers captured the neighboring districts from the Lebanese Forces after a 16-hour tank assault. At least 43 people were killed and 54 wounded in the attack on the low-income residential districts in Christian east Beirut. By police count, more than 600 people have been killed and more than 1,800 wounded in the 18-day-old showdown for mastery of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. Ein Rummaneh and Furn el-Shubbak looked as if they had been struck by a killer earthquake after the brutal onslaught by Aoun's pre-dominantly Sunni Moslem ``mukafaha,'' or special corps. An acrid stench of incinerated steel mingled with the smell of corpses. Some of the district's densely populated narrow alleys resembled junkyards piled with burned cars, some compressed into thin sheets by tanks that had crushed them. Tanks and armored personnel carriers rumbled through the dusty streets as people emerged from bunkers to take stock of the damage and stockpile food. Many threw rice on Aoun's troops from balconies strung with Lebanese flags as they shouted: ``Long live the army! Long live Aoun!'' ``We have finally seen light,'' said Mary Shammas, a housewife. ``The Lebanese Forces was a germ that was squashed by the army. May God safeguard the army and the general. I'm ready to die for him (Aoun).'' Some young women sunned themselves on a pockmarked balcony overlooking a burned Lebanese Forces armored personnel carrier. ``We lived 17 days underground. It's so good to breathe fresh air again,'' shouted one. The 1,500-yard-long Furn el-Shubbak commercial boulevard looked like a piece of plowed land, strewn with debris, pieces of furniture and window shutters. Aoun's soldiers were defusing mines planted by Geagea's men around the militia's posts and barracks, now decorated with Aoun posters and the Lebanese flag. A soldier who lost his left eye in the latest clashes stood guard at the entrance to one of the Lebanese Forces barracks in Ein Rummaneh. ``There's a booby-trapped backgammon board here. No one can go in. We are waiting for the sappers (bomb squad)'' he said. The troops, stationed in nearly every street in the two areas, warned civilians against touching suspicious-looking objects. ``The dirty militiamen have even booby-trapped corpses,'' said one soldier standing next to a car piled with mines the army had removed from the edges of Furn el-Shubbak. ``We didn't enjoy fighting them but we wanted to liberate our areas from these filthy people. They left us no other choice,'' said another soldier. ``We are taking a small rest now before we attack them in Ashrafiyeh,'' he added. Ashrafiyeh is one of the last two pockets of the Lebanese forces in east Beirut. The other is the low-income district of Nabaa. Reporters and photographers were not allowed to go close to the Kassardjian barracks, the Lebanese Forces' main barracks in the area, ``because the area around it is still being cleared of mines.'' Workers were singing as they collected garbage next to a red Volkswagen containing a body wrapped in a plastic bag. The wife of a Lebanese Forces militiaman, Pierre Helou, sobbed as she hugged her two children in Ein Rummaneh: ``My poor children. What has happened to your father?'' ``She doesn't know whether her husband Pierre has been killed or has surrendered to the army,'' a neighbor said. Long lines of cars crowded the lane leading into west Beirut at the Museum crossing, the only open link between Moslem west Beirut and the Christian sector. Most of the passengers were fleeing Ashrafiyeh in fear of an Aoun offensive. Very few cars were crossing into east Beirut.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas, Opposition Exchange Threats As Tension Rises
LaserPhoto NY15
DOC.TEXT: Campaign rhetoric is heating up as Sunday's elections draw near, with the opposition, government and rebel guerrillas exchanging threats of vengeance and accusations of cheating and planned violence. The campaign had been relatively tranquil since a Dec. 10 opposition rally turned into a bloody clash, but now the tension is showing as the Feb. 25 vote approaches and the result remains uncertain. The tone of the campaign darkened as opposition vice presidential candidate Virgilio Godoy said the Sandinistas would be forced to pay for their past misdeeds and President Daniel Ortega responded likewise. U.S.-supported Contra guerrillas accused the government of planning an armed offensive on election day; the Sandinista government said 2,000 Contras were preparing to disrupt the voting. Both sides denied they planned any violence but said they wouldn't hesitate to respond if provoked. Managua residents assessed the situation and advised each other to stock up on food, water and candles in case there of trouble after election day. ``You never know,'' said one middle-aged woman who did not want her name used. ``It's better to prevent than to lament.'' Two polls last week found about 50 percent of respondents picking Ortega's leftist Sandinistas, with around 30 percent expressing a preference for Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's U.S.-supported United National Opposition, a coalition of 14 disparate parties. However, the accuracy of any poll is difficult to assess. Not only is Nicaragua a rural country with few telephones, but many people are reluctant to express their true feelings after years of civil war and intimidation. Interior Minister Tomas Borge accused the opposition of planning to disrupt voting in an effort to make a Sandinista victory appear illegitimate. UNO representatives denied that and said they expected to win easily, but Godoy said that if the Sandinistas set loose ``turbas,'' or gangs of supporters, the opposition would call out its own supporters. ``We won't let ourselves be intimidated by the government,'' Godoy said. The Sandinistas, who have ruled since the overthrow of dictator Anastasio Somoza in 1979, have an interest in appearing to win fairly because it would put pressure on the United States to reduce sanctions and other pressures on the government. Mrs. Chamorro's campaign manager, Antonio Lacayo, said Friday that UNO would accept a Sandinista victory if international observers confirm the vote is fair. About 3,000 international observers and journalists plan to watch the voting. International observers have asked both sides to control the zeal of their supporters, but over the past week the campaign atmosphere has been more intense. ``We're going to make them pay the bill,'' Ortega told a crowd of thousands at a rally Wednesday in the northern town of Matagalpa. Ortega, who is seeking a second six-year term, used a common Nicaraguan phrase, ``Vamos a pasarle la cuenta,'' an ominous expression that threatened retribution against UNO should the Sandinistas win. ``They will be left without a newspaper, and the house of the lady and that of the vice presidential candidate will be turned into nurseries for children,'' Ortega told the crowd. Mrs. Chamorro laughed off Ortega's threats, even though her newspaper, La Prensa, was shut down for nearly two years because of its criticism of government policies. It was allowed to reopen in October 1988. ``How funny. This poor man is saying that because he's already lost,'' Mrs. Chamorro said. Both Mrs. Chamorro and Godoy pointed to increasingly enthusiastic opposition crowds and said the threats showed the ruling party was becoming desperate. The exchange actually was started by Godoy, who used the same phrase against the Sandinistas in two speeches, saying ``One by one, we will make the Sandinistas pay the entire bill.'' The U.S. State Department expressed concern about Ortega's statements _ but not Godoy's _ and urged Ortega to commit the Sandinistas ``to respect the political, civil and human rights of opposition parties.'' The statement noted that under international agreements signed by Ortega, the elections are envisioned as a first step in a national reconciliation process. The Godoy-Ortega exchange marked a change in tone because most Nicaraguans are hoping for peace after years of civil war, and both parties had tried to exploit that mood. Ortega, for example, bills himself as ``the president of peace'' and urges reconciliation. Mrs. Chamorro says her government would be the only one that could bring peace and reconciliation. She notes the Sandinistas have the largest armed forces by far in the region and she promises to ``dump the weapons into the ocean'' if she is elected.

DOC.HEAD: Hopeful Former Governors Heading Down the Comeback Trail
DOC.TEXT: WILLIAM M. WELCH=

Former governors, hankering for the power they once held and perhaps the trappings as well, are heading down the comeback trail in increasing numbers, hoping to regain the best job they ever had. ``You think you'll like retirement, but after about a year you miss the crowds,'' says Bruce King, who is trying for a second comeback and third term as governor of New Mexico. ``As governor, you're like the director of the symphony _ in Congress, you're more like one of the players of instruments,'' said Rep. Joe Brennan, a Democrat who is giving up his House seat to run for his old job as governor of Maine. At a time when politicians complain that the pressures of money and ethics are driving people out of government, there is no shortage of experienced candidates for the 36 governor's seats up for election in 1990. In at least eight states, former governors are running for governor _ not counting incumbents seeking another consecutive term. And at least three more former governors are considering running or are being mentioned as possible candidates. Some may be engaging in futile gestures or spoiler candidacies, while others have serious shots at winning. Lester Maddox, the one-time segregationist and one-term governor of Georgia, is a longshot in the Democratic primary this year. At 74, he is a symbol of another era. Evan Mecham, impeached in 1988 as governor of Arizona, is a symbol many Republicans in his state would like to forget. But GOP leaders say a crowded field could splinter the opposition and allow him to make a strong showing. Former Texas Gov. Mark White, defeated for re-election four years ago, is a strong Democratic contender and may have recovered from the fallout over the tax increase and no pass-no play high school sports rule he pushed as governor. Other former governors running or likely to run include Republican Richard Snelling in Vermont and Democrats Fob James in Alabama and John Carlin in Kansas. In Alaska, Republican Walter Hickel, who served in the 1960s and was a spoiler independent candidate four years ago, is considering another run, and Democrat Bill Sheffield, who served one troubled term in the 1980s, hasn't ruled out another try. In Nevada, former Gov. Bob List's name is being floated by Republicans looking for a challenger. ``It's the best job in America,'' said Michele Davis, executive director of the Republican Governors Association. ``A U.S. senator _ how many jobs does he get (to fill)? Maybe 40,'' she said, explaining some of the allure. ``A state governor _ we're talking thousands. ... It's pure power.'' Some of the interest in returning to the Statehouse also may be due to disenchantment with Washington. A still-strong congressional seniority system breeds frustration and some say the stalemate over the federal deficit has engendered a sense that little if anything ever really gets resolved in the nation's capital. Brennan was the first former governor in two decades to move to the House, though the Senate has many former governors. But in either chamber, he said, a former governor is acutely aware of the limits of his power compared to what he wielded in his old post. ``There's no question you have the levers of government much more available to you,'' he said. ``You're not bogged down in any seniority system because there is no seniority.'' ``You can make a difference _ you are the chief executive,'' said King. ``Up there (on Capitol Hill), you're just one of 400 and some odd.'' Few have shown more unabashed enthusiasm for the governor's job than King in New Mexico. He first won election as governor in 1970 after serving as speaker of the state House. Barred by law from a second consecutive term, he returned to his cattle ranch in 1975 and planned his comeback. He won another four-year term in the 1978 election. Now 65 and eight years out of the governor's mansion in Sante Fe, King is waging another comeback bid. Davis, who heads the national Republican group that will try to defeat King if he wins the Democratic primary, offers ungrudging professional admiration. ``Bruce King is truly one of the best polticians I have ever seen,'' Davis said. ``He can work a room like nobody _ remember names, everything. But he is the past. Others are the future.'' Now that New Mexico has changed its constitution to allow governors to succeed themselves, King makes no secret that he has two more terms in mind. ``I enjoy campaigning,'' he said. ``I must.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed When Police Fire on Moslem Protesters in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: Security forces fired on hundreds of pro-independence Moslems who tried to grab their guns Saturday, and three people were killed and two were wounded, officials said. A government spokesman for Jammu-Kashmir state, Syed Ghulam Nabi, said the officers of the paramilitary Central Reserve Police Force opened fire in self-defense. The crowd had gathered during a relaxation of the curfew that has been in effect on-and-off in Srinagar since Jan. 20, when the government began a crackdown on the Moslem secessionist movement. Nabi said the violence broke out in the Nawa Bazaar neighborhood of Srinagar, the city that is the focal point of the Moslem independence movement. Curfew was imposed in the area immediately after the noon incident, he said. In the rest of the Moslem-dominated city, the curfew was re-imposed at 6 p.m. as scheduled after a 13-hour break. Nabi said the dead were a woman and two men. He said two people were injured. Witnesses said that a half-hour before the shootings, troops fired in the air at Nawa Bazaar to disperse another group of demonstrators and clubbed some on the head with rifle butts. At least 12 people, including two boys, were injured in the beating, said doctors at a hospital where the injured were taken. Salima, a 48-year-old wool saleswoman who gave only one name, said she was hit on the head by a policeman during the melee. She said she got caught in the violence while walking to the market to sell her wool. Later, a police station in Srinagar was set afire, and police blamed Moslem militants. The blaze spread to an adjoining handicrafts shop, damaging both buildings. Reporters on the scene said some residents tried to stop firefighters from dousing the blaze. Other reporters said a police bus parked outside a police station in central Srinagar exploded and caught fire when suspected militants hurled a bomb at it. The driver, the only occupant, drove the burning bus away from the congested neighborhood to a deserted bridge 200 yards away and jumped to safety, said the reporters who refused to be identified. At least 99 people, most of them Moslem militants shot for defying curfew, have been killed since Jan. 20 in the Kashmir region. Moslem militants in Kashmir had originally demanded either union with neighboring Pakistan, which is Moslem, or total independence, but in recent months they have increasingly campaigned for the status of a neutral country. Kashmir is a part of Jammu-Kashmir state. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslem, making it the only Moslem-dominated state among India's 25 states. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of the 880 million population. Hindus make up 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Donates Jewelery to Aid Economy
DOC.TEXT: A woman donated $15,000 worth of jewelry to the Central Bank on Saturday to help the country's troubled economy. Alia Abu Tayeh, a senior adviser at the Education Ministry, said the donation ``is the least any Jordanian citizen can do to aid her country.'' ``What is the use of me living happily while Jordan is broke?'' she told The Associated Press after discussing her gift with Prime Minister Mudar Badran and Parliament Speaker Suleiman Arar. Ms. Abu Tayeh, whose grandfather fought alongside King Hussein's family in the Arab revolt against Ottoman colonial rule, said the jewelry includes gold and diamond-studded bracelets, necklaces and rings. Last week, deputy Nayef Al-Haddid urged all Jordanians to loan their jewelry to the Central Bank for five years to help it overcome a shortage of foreign currency reserves. Jordan's economic problems started in 1988 due to rising payments on its $8.3 billion debt and declining foreign revenues. There were four days of riots in April 1989 over worsening economic conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Student Body President Arrested on DUI Charge After OKing Alcohol Policy
DOC.TEXT: Clemson University's student body president, who this past week reviewed and approved the school's toughened alcohol policy, has been charged with driving under the influence, authorities said. William Astor Blackwood III, a 21-year-old senior, was arrested early Friday by a university police officer. Blackwood's blood alcohol content registered .16 percent, the police report said. Anything over .10 is illegal in South Carolina. After a 14-member committee of students and faculty agreed on changes in the school's on-campus alcohol policy, their recommendations were presented for approval by Blackwood and the dean of students before the final OK was given by university President Max Lennon. ``Students took this process very seriously and contributed many of the ideas in the final policy,'' Blackwood said Tuesday. Blackwood is scheduled to go to trial March 15.

DOC.HEAD: The State Department's Real-Life `Working Girl'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf pvs, bgng: A self-described, to CLARIFY Mullins' age is 40
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: A decade ago, Janet Mullins, a 30-year-old single mother with a background in retailing and real estate and a recent college degree, took a job typing letters in a Senate office as a first step to a meaningful career in politics. In a meteoric rise that would make the producers of the movie ``Working Girl'' gulp, Mullins was made chief of staff in Sen. Robert Packwood's office _ less than two years after she started working for the Oregon Republican. She more than doubled her $18,000 salary in that time. Mullins quit the job after a year to return to Kentucky, but parlayed the Packwood post into series of plum jobs. And after working in the Bush presidential campaign, she was appointed assistant secretary of state for legislative affairs. A self-described ``Senate animal,'' the 40-year-old Mullins _ a Democrat until she went to work for Packwood _ is the State Department's chief lobbyist on Capitol Hill. She also reportedly is dating one of the capital's most powerful and eligible Democrats: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine, her adopted party's principal nemesis in the Senate. A young-looking, businesslike brunette who says she shies away from profile stories, Mullins said in an interview the secret of her success is simple: ``hard work,'' and an eye for good opportunities. Then again, Mullins hasn't had much time for reflection in the last decade, what with raising her daughter, Shannon, now an 18-year-old college student in Colorado, and routinely working long hours. Luck and timing have also played a role. Take, for instance, her decision to join the Bush campaign. She was ``about two days away from accepting a job'' with the presidential campaign of Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., in 1987 when Lee Atwater ``called and said, `Don't make a decision until I can talk with you,''' Mullins said. Atwater, the Republican National Committee chairman, ran George Bush's presidential campaign. Rejecting the advice of several friends, Mullins went with Bush because ``he was an excellent candidate,'' his campaign organization ``was the A-team from the beginning,'' and the Bush operatives convinced her she would have ``a role that would be satisfying for me,'' she said. Although she was a neophyte in presidential campaigns, she was named executive director of the Fund for America's Future, Bush's political action committee. ``She has a reputation for being tough,'' says a former boss, Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., but he added that Mullins is actually ``more bark than bite.'' He also calls her ``extraordinarily bright.'' Packwood has even cited Mullins in his speeches as an example of how one can succeed quickly by dint of hard work and intelligence. Others describe Mullins as politically insightful, capable and private. So private, in fact, that she refuses to talk about the nature of her relationship with Mitchell, although she doesn't deny it. Mitchell, who was divorced three years ago, also doesn't discuss his personal life, spokeswoman Diane Dewhirst said. ``Rumor? It's not a rumor,'' McConnell said when asked about a Mullins-Mitchell relationship. McConnell hired Mullins to run his successful 1984 Senate campaign in which he upset incumbent Walter Huddleston. Mullins then became McConnell's chief of staff. In a town where two-career couples are common, such separation of personal and professional lives _ Democrat and Republican _ is not unusual. ``It hasn't been a problem for me,'' said Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., the ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ``I like her. She is a charming young lady.'' Mullins' predecessor in the State Department position, J. Edward Fox, said access to the leadership can be a big plus in the job, which he said was ``very tough.'' The administration's foreign policy is a ``good whipping boy'' for members of Congress, he said. While Mullins declines to talk about her social life, she's not closed-month about other aspects of her work. ``The neat part of my job is that I personally represent the secretary's and the administration's point of view. My job when I walk into a meeting is to know what (Secretary of State James) Baker would want ... what the president wants,'' she says, leaning back in her chair in a large sunny office on the State Department's seventh floor. Supervising a staff of 50, Mullins and her team track legislation and advance the administration's foreign policy goals on Capitol Hill, where members often have their own ideas. ``Because the White House legislative affairs office has the entire agenda to deal with, they really rely upon us and the NSC (the National Security Council) to honcho the foreign policy side of things,'' she said. While Mullins gets ``on the phone with members and staff people to the extent I can,'' she usually relies on feedback from staff. She comes to Capitol Hill for big events like Baker's testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. From a professional standpoint, 1990 started off well for Mullins when the Senate gave President Bush a big victory by sustaining his veto of a bill that imposed sanctions on China. The House had overridden the veto. Generally, Mullins and her operation receive good marks, but some members have their gripes. ``Sometimes they do well,'' said Rep. Benjamin Gilman, R-N.Y., a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``Sometimes they come to us late. ... There have been some hot issues, they came to us late in the game.'' Others don't have an opinion. ``Who?'' asked Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., when questioned about Mullins. ``I haven't been lobbied by anyone in the administration,'' said Biden, a leading Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Earthquake Hits Algiers
DOC.TEXT: A mild earthquake hit outside the Algerian capital Saturday without causing any damage or injures, authorities said. The Center of Seismic Studies said the quake struck at 10:24 a.m. and was centered in the town of Blida, about 40 miles southwest of the capital. The quake measured 3.9 on the Richter scale. A earthquake that registered 6.0 on the scale Oct. 29 left 26 people dead and caused widespread damage in the northeastern regions of the North African country. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Sketches of Key Players in Japan's Election
With AM-Japan-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some of the major figures in Japanese politics whose futures may be decided by Sunday's general election for the 512-seat lower house of Parliament. The Liberal Democratic Party, which has governed Japan since the party was formed in 1955, faced a serious challenge to its majority in the lower house, which chooses the prime minister, amid public dislike of a new 3 percent sales tax and criticism of party leaders' involvement in an influence-buying scandal.
DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu
DOC.TEXT: Kaifu, 59, is a 10-term member of the Diet, or parliament, from Aichi Prefecture (state) in central Japan. He was catapulted to the Liberal Democratic Party's top post in August when Prime Minister Sousuke Uno resigned. Kaifu promised to revise an unpopular sales tax and to reform a system dependent on large corporate donations to oil politics, but few measures have been taken. A former education minister without a firm power base in the party, Kaifu has been plagued by rumors that power brokers plan to replace him soon after the election.
DOC.HEAD: Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi
DOC.TEXT: Charismatic Ms. Doi, 61, has been head of the largest opposition party since 1986. She was a law professor before running for Parliament in 1969, and is seeking her eighth term from Hyogo Prefecture in western Japan. She has gained fame at home and abroad as her party encouraged the emergence of women in local and national politics and made impressive gains in the upper house of Parliament last July, with many women winning seats. Favoring an unarmed, neutral Japan, the Socialists oppose the U.S.-Japan security treaty, which places 50,000 U.S. troops in Japan, and support protectionist farm trade policies.
DOC.HEAD: Yasuhiro Nakasone
DOC.TEXT: Prime minister from 1982 to 1987, Nakasone, 71, is seeking his 17th term in Gunma Prefecture, west of Tokyo. He eased Japan into the world spotlight with his first-name relationship with President Reagan. Often criticized as a ``weathervane'' who changed political ties and policies to advance his career, Nakasone declared his guiding principle was that Japan should ``hold a place of honor in the international community.'' Although never charged with wrongdoing in the Recruit scandal, he was forced to testify in Parliament about his links to the scandal last year and resigned from the party. Running as an independent, he hopes for a strong win to be able to return to the party and regain influence.
DOC.HEAD: Shintaro Abe
DOC.TEXT: Abe, 65, a former journalist, has held a series of Cabinet and senior ruling party positions. He is considered a favorite to succeed Kaifu as prime minister. Although he lost his position as secretary-general of the party when Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita resigned over the Recruit scandal last year, he was spared most of the glare of that scandal while recuperating from gallstone surgery. Abe traveled to Moscow to meet with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in January. He is seeking his 11th term from Yamaguchi Prefecture, in far western Japan.
DOC.HEAD: Noboru Takeshita
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Takeshita, 65, is seeking his 12th term from Shimane Prefecture in far western Japan. He served as prime minister from November 1987 to June 1989, when he resigned to take responsibility for the widespread Recruit scandal. He was found to have received some $1.3 million in questionable, though legal, donations from the Recruit Co. and many senior political leaders were also implicated. He remains a powerful party figure.
DOC.HEAD: Sousuke Uno
DOC.TEXT: Uno, 67, resigned last summer after only two months as prime minister to take responsibility for the Liberal Democratic Party's stunning election loss of its majority in the upper house of Parliament. Uno was stung by a scandal in which a former geisha accused him of paying for her services. Analysts say the 10-term lawmaker is in danger of losing his seat in western Shiga Prefecture.
DOC.HEAD: Takao Fujinami
DOC.TEXT: Currently on trial for bribery in the Recruit scandal, Fujinami, 57, is running as an independent for his ninth term from Mie Prefecture in western Japan. A former chief Cabinet secretary under Nakasone, Fujinami resigned from the Liberal Democratic Party after being indicted last May. Charged with accepting $138,000 from Recruit, Fujinami maintains it was not a bribe and that he did no special favors for the information conglomerate.
DOC.HEAD: Kunio Takaishi
DOC.TEXT: Takaishi, 59, former vice education minister, is also on trial for bribery in the Recruit scandal and is seeking his first term in the Diet from the southwestern prefecture of Fukuoka as an independent.

DOC.HEAD: Actress-Wife of Cornel Wilde Dead at 66
DOC.TEXT: Jean Wallace, the film actress of the 1940s and 1950s whose off-screen escapades fueled Hollywood gossip, died at home after an internal hemorrhage, officials said. She was 66. Miss Wallace, the wife of actor Cornel Wilde from 1951 to 1980, died Wednesday at her home here, family members said Friday. The cause of death was ruled to be an upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, said Los Angeles County coroner's spokesman Bob Dambacher. Born Jean Walasek in Chicago on Oct. 12, 1923, she came west in 1940 and worked as a showgirl at Earl Carroll's legendary Hollywood nightclub. As a Paramount contract player, she appeared in the 1941 musical ``Louisiana Purchase.'' Her other 1940s films included ``You Can't Ration Love,'' ``It Shouldn't Happen to a Dog,'' ``Blaze of Noon,'' ``When My Baby Smiles at Me,'' and ``Jigsaw.'' She married actor Franchot Tone in 1941 and the couple had two sons before a 1948 divorce. She married James Lloyd Randall, but the marriage was annulled after a few months. She married Wilde in 1951 and they had a son before divorcing in 1980. Wilde died of leukemia on Oct. 16, 1989. The blonde leading lady's highly-publicized personal life included a sleeping pill overdose in 1946, hospitalization in 1949 for a self-inflicted knife wound and bitter child-custody squabbles with Tone in 1951. Her later films were produced primarily for Theodora Productions, a company she and Wilde created. Her credits from that period include ``Storm Fear,'' ``The Devil's Hairpin,'' ``Lancelot and Guinevere,'' and her last film, ``No Blade of Grass,'' a 1970 picture praised for its anti-pollution theme. Beside her children, survivors include a brother, a sister and three grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Cameras Roll for Reagan Again in Day Two of Iran-Contra Testimony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Reagan, Poindexter returning to begin second day of deposition. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The former...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Reagan was in front of the camera again, with lawyers hanging on his every word as the former president produced a videotaped version of his recollection of the Iran-Contra affair. Reagan testified behind closed doors for about six hours Friday and returned for a second session today, answering questions about his role in the Iran-Contra affair, the failed arms-for-hostages deal during Reagan's second term. Reagan was compelled to testify in the case by U.S. District Judge Harold Greene, who is presiding over the trial of former White House National Security Adviser John M. Poindexter in Washington, D.C. The former president's blue luxury car pulled up in a pounding rainstorm at about 9:30 a.m. today. Poindexter arrived by taxi about 15 minutes earlier, bounding through the rain and past a throng of reporters on his way into the courthouse. As they did Friday, both men ignored reporters' questions outside the courthouse. The former president was to face 154 questions, which were drawn from 183 submitted to the court by defense attorney Richard Beckler. The attorney was allowed follow-up questions if necessary but the judge prohibited him from raising additional questions on new subjects. On Friday, Greene had estimated that the president would wind up the taping by lunchtime today. Security was especially rigorous for the extraordinary session, which began Friday morning at the federal courthouse in downtown Los Angeles. Reporters were kept more than 100 yards away. In deference to the former president, Greene allowed Reagan, 79, to give videotaped testimony near his Bel-Air area home rather than require him to appear in person at Poindexter's trial in Washington. On Friday, Reagan entered the courtroom a few minutes after Poindexter, and the two exited separately about 6{ hours later. The former security adviser goes on trial March 5 on charges of concealing from Congress assistance by his former aide, Oliver North, to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels and lying about a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran.
