Poindexter sought the former chief executive's testimony to bolster his contention that his secret activities had been authorized by Reagan. ``I think he was very fair in his testimony,'' Beckler said of the president as he left court. Greene threw out 29 of Beckler's questions because they lacked relevance or touched too closely to national secrets. Cross-examination was to be conducted by Dan K. Webb, the chief prosecutor for Iran-Contra independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh. Although the judge has not made the specific questions public, he said they fell into several broad categories, such as the extent of Reagan's knowledge of the shipment of missiles to Iran and Reagan's understanding of legislation that barred, temporarily, U.S. aide to the Contras. Reagan said early in 1987 that he hadn't known about ``secret bank accounts and diverted funds,'' two products of the Iran-Contra affair that he said he found ``personally distasteful.'' He told the Tower Commission he didn't know the National Security Council staff was assisting the Contras. Poindexter subsequently told Congress he believed Reagan understood that ``North was instrumental in keeping the Contras supported without maybe understanding the details of exactly what he was doing.'' Greene earlier rejected a request by news organizations to attend the deposition. However, he said he would order the videotape released within a few days, after editing to remove material deemed to touch on classified matters.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Anger Engulfs Soviet Central Asia
DOC.TEXT: From the deserts of Turkmenia to the glacier-laced peaks of Tadzhikistan, Soviet Central Asians are venting their anger over nationalist issues as they awaken from decades of complacency. Dangerous ingredients that have been brewing for decades _ suppression of Islam, joblessness, pollution and a burgeoning population _ have come to a boil, and they pose dangerous new challenges for the Kremlin. In some cases, the emotions have exploded into violence. Since 1986, more than 120 people have been killed in ethnic clashes in the region. Stretching over an area half the size of the United States and home to 49 million people, Soviet Central Asia is becoming the nation's heartland, but also one of its biggest headaches. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is well aware of the dangers as he tries to reverse decades of neglect of the environment, culture and religion. ``This is a kind of chain reaction accompanied by an orgy of violence,'' Gorbachev told the Supreme Soviet legislature last week during the most recent outbreak of ethnic violence in Tadzhikistan. ``The country's destiny and the safety of our citizens is at stake, comrades. We must do everything to put out the fire,'' Gorbachev said. Soviet Central Asia has been in flames before. It was a crossroads for invading Mongols, Turks, Persians and Slavs until it was absorbed in Czarist Russia's drive south in the 19th century. In modern times, the Central Asians have fought each other. In 1986, the bloodiest Soviet ethnic riots in decades broke out in Alma Ata, the capital of Kazakhstan, following the replacement of the republic's party leader, a Kazakh, by an ethnic Russian. Two people were killed. That same year _ in a prelude to the riots that began last week _ 3,000 people rioted in Dushanbe, the capital of Tadzhikistan. Reports spoke of an unspecified number of injuries. Last May, bands of young people frustrated with high prices and consumer shortages rioted in two cities of the Turkmenia republic bordering Iran. Then in June, a large-scale rampage of arson and murder involving ethnic Uzbeks and Meskhetian Turks _ forcibly deported to Central Asia by Stalin in 1944 _ tore through Uzbekistan's Fergana Valley. About 100 people were killed. Later that month, four people died in the Kazakhstan city of Novy Uzen when rioters attacked immigrants from the Caucasus, accusing them of setting up private business and getting special housing and other privileges. Similar factors fueled riots that exploded Feb. 10 in Dushanbe, where 20 people have been reported killed. As many as 200,000 of the republic's 5.1 million people are reported to be unemployed and housing is in short supply in Dushanbe for the large families that are traditional among Central Asians. Young villagers living in tents since an earthquake destroyed their homes in January 1989 have been identified as rioters in Dushanbe. They reportedly were enraged by rumors that Armenian refugees fleeing ethnic violence in the Caucasus were being given apartments. The protesters' demands have included banning the sale of pork, which Moslems do not eat, and introducing measures to combat unemployment. They also want the Tadzhik language to use the Arabic script instead of Cyrillic. Other problems include animosity between the indigenous population and immigrants, many of whom have better skills and therefore receive better jobs and better housing. Demographics are an important factor in the unrest. A population boom in the five Central Asian republics _ Tadzhikistan, Turkmenia, Kazakhstan, Kirgizia and Uzbekistan _ means that in many areas, there are more people than jobs. A Soviet legislator has estimated that 6 million young people are not working or studying in Central Asia. The population boom has political ramifications. It threatens to shift the power balance, which now favors European Slavs in the north, to the Moslems in the south. The Central Asian republics now account for 17 percent of the total Soviet population, compared with 15 percent in 1979 and 11 percent in 1959. Western demographers say Central Asia could hold the majority of the Soviet population within a century if current birthrates continue. Tadzhikistan has the highest birthrate of all 15 Soviet republics, with its population increasing 34.5 percent in the last decade. Most of the residents of the broad area separating the country's Slavic heartland from Iran, Afghanistan and China are of Moslem heritage, and have taken advantage of the freedoms Gorbachev has offered to assert their religious interests. The number of students in Islamic academies is increasing along with the publication of the Koran and other religious books. The Kremlin is removing a Stalin-era ban on group religious education and plans to allow believers to organize charities. Last year, the spiritual leader of Central Asia's Moslems was ousted after radicals accused him of corruption and ignorance of Islam. In Central Asia, as elsewhere, the deteriorating environment has become a rallying point. National policy demanding increased cotton production has led to overuse of fertilizers, increasing infant mortality in some places to as high as 70 per 1,000 live births, seven times the U.S. rate. Pushing marginal land into production has ruined hundreds of thousands of acres. Rivers tapped to irrigate the cotton crop on arid land have dried up nearly half the Aral Sea between Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, making its revival one of the Soviet Union's most pressing environmental concerns.

DOC.HEAD: Arms Treaties Indicate Shift in Soviet Thinking
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: By BRYAN BRUMLEY=

Superpower leaders are expected to sign two big and three small treaties in 1990, the year of arms control, and the proposed pacts mark a big change in the way Moscow views its security interests. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, who for the past five years has amazed the West with sweeping arms proposals, made dazzling concessions over the past two weeks, clearing the way for a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START) and a multilateral pact to cut conventional armies in Central Europe. The treaties, which are qualitatively different than previous arms control pacts, reflect the change in Soviet thinking on security issues, say U.S. and Soviet arms control officials and experts. The changes in Kremlin thinking, sparked in large measure by an economic crisis within the Soviet Union, have prompted the Gorbachev generation to scrap the doctrine that guided Kremlin leaders during the four decades of the Cold War: that they needed an East European military alliance as a buffer against possible aggression from the West. And both superpowers have decided that the world would be safer with fewer nuclear weapons, reversing a four-decade build-up. ``Someplace, there is a museum of old `vital interests' that nations could no longer afford to defend,'' said Albert Carnesdale, an arms control expert at Harvard University. Several of the agreements are likely to be signed at a summit this June in Washington, U.S. and Soviet officials say. President Bush and Gorbachev are likely to sign a START framework agreement in June, instructing negotiators to hammer out the remaining details of the 1,500-page document for signing by year's end, said one Soviet official, speaking on condition he not be further identified. In June, the two leaders also are expected to sign protocols designed to ease Senate ratification of two minor treaties from the 1970s limiting underground nuclear tests. And agreement is near on a bilateral pact under which the superpowers would destroy most of their chemical weapons. Multilateral negotiations continue for a global ban. In the most notable recent Soviet concession, Gorbachev dropped opposition to Bush's proposal that the United States retain 30,000 troops in Britain and southern Europe under a treaty reducing conventional armies in Central Europe. Bush's plan would allow the superpowers to keep 195,000 troops apiece in Central Europe, mostly in Germany. Gorbachev also waived his opposition to the reunification of East and West Germany. Those concessions, and others designed to speed work on START _ which would reduce superpower strategic nuclear arms by 30 percent _ prompted some Western commentators to describe the Soviet Union as a failing power. U.S. and Soviet arms negotiators, however, reject that argument, saying Gorbachev's flexibility reflects a changing perception of national security, and the wish of Kremlin leaders to concentrate on domestic affairs. ``No one is holding a gun to our head. We are negotiating agreements on the basis of our security interests _ what is good for us,'' said one Soviet official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Gorbachev was willing to allow the 30,000 U.S. troops to stay on the European periphery because far more Soviet forces will remain within the Soviet Union, far closer to the potential battlefield than American reserves. A U.S. arms control official agreed, saying the Soviets ``are preoccupied with their internal problems, and they want to minimize the time their top leaders will spend on internal questions.'' The Soviets have accelerated work on arms control treaties ``by coming to the U.S. position in a couple of cases, but the U.S. positions were not cutthroat,'' said the American official, also speaking on condition he not be further identified. ``They are not rolling over completely,'' he said, but want to close deals this year, and are ``willing to push some hard questions down the road.'' Among the issues that have been moved to later negotiations are Soviet efforts to draw the United States into talks on naval arms control, limitations on sea-launched cruise missiles and a superpower disagreement on how to count fighter aircraft in Europe. The nuclear, conventional and chemical treaties differ from arms control pacts of the 1970s by requiring the superpowers to scrap large numbers of arms, including new weapons systems. The treaties of the 1970s limited the numbers of weapons, but did not require destruction of significant quantities. ``By and large, in the past, arms control agreements codified defense plans,'' said Carnesdale. ``What has changed is that our defense plans have built into them an expectation of arms control.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Bryan Brumley covers foreign affairs for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Smoking Laws Emerging Even in Tobacco States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `When you...', to CORRECT group's name to Action on Smoking and, sted or, Health.
DOC.TEXT: Powerful tobacco interests that have ruled Virginia since Colonial times may be losing clout as legislators prepare to join their counterparts in 44 other states in passing a law to restrict smoking in public. How influential the tobacco lobby remains will be shown by whether the General Assembly approves the stronger or weaker of two bills that have survived initial votes in the House of Delegates and the Senate. The success of both bills so far shows the increasing clout of health groups that have battled well-financed tobacco interests over public smoking for years, lawmakers and lobbyists say. ``When you see bills introduced in Virginia, what more can you say?'' said Athena Mueller, general counsel for Action on Smoking and Health, an anti-smoking lobby based in Washington. Anti-smoking activists attribute their success to recent medical reports on the harm caused by second-hand smoke and the waning political influence of rural counties where tobacco is the No. 1 cash crop. Virginia, the nation's fifth biggest producer of tobacco, is among six states with no statewide limits on smoking in public. The others are North Carolina, Tennessee, Missouri, Alabama and Wyoming. States such as Illinois and Kentucky merely limit smoking in schools, Ms. Mueller said, but 30 to 35 states have relatively strong anti-smoking laws that cover a variety of public places. Tobacco lobbyists concede they have been forced to accept smoking regulations because of the growing strength of smoking opponents. ``The anti-smoking zealots are much louder than smokers,'' said Tom Lauria, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute in Washington. ``They're able to get their point across to both the media and to the lawmakers. I don't think the smokers are doing that.'' But Lauria said the tobacco industry continues to influence legislators. The weaker Virginia bill ``has been drafted at least in part by tobacco interests,'' he said. The bill's sponsor, Delegate C. Richard Cranwell, and the Tobacco Institute's chief Virginia lobbyist, Anthony F. Troy, have vehemently denied the tobbaco lobby is behind the weaker bill as a way of forestalling the other one. ``There are provisions in that bill that we object to,'' Troy said. The House-passed bill sponsored by Cranwell, a Democrat from Roanoke County, would ban smoking in elevators, school buses, school common areas and hospital emergency rooms and require no-smoking areas in government buildings. But it would also limit cities and counties from passing tough new local smoking ordinances and require employers to have the support of two-thirds of their workers before banning smoking in the workplace. Troy said the tobacco industry thinks the bill's guidelines for local ordinances are too stringent. A Senate-passed bill would ban or limit smoking in a wide range of public places, allow localities to make ordinances as strict as they want and let employers forbid smoking in the workplace. Anti-smoking ordinances already in effect in nearly two dozen Virginia localities, including some of the state's most populous counties and cities, would remain intact under either bill. The differences between the two measures probably will be resolved by a committee of legislators from both chambers, said Sen. Thomas J. Michie Jr., a Democrat from Albemarle, sponsor of the Senate bill. The two chambers must act before their adjournment March 10. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, who took office last month, has not endorsed either bill, saying he preferred to let the legislators work the issue out among themselves first. Michie, who saw his legislation narrowly defeated last year, attributed the turnaround to medical warnings about passive smoke and constituent pressure. ``I don't think interest groups have a great deal of influence when the citizenry feels strongly about something,'' he said. Health groups are divided about the smoking legislation. David L. Bailey Jr., a lobbyist for heart, lung and cancer associations, said the weaker bill would satisfy them. ``It's a good half a loaf,'' he said. But other health activists see the tobacco lobby behind the bill. Anne Morrow Donley, executive director of the Virginia Group to Alleviate Smoking in Public, said she would rather see no statewide law than the Cranwell bill. ``When the tobacco industry sees that it is inevitable that some law is going to go through, then they do what Cranwell has done,'' she said. ``They get a weak bill, as weak as they can get it and they tie the localities' hands.''

DOC.HEAD: Husak, Strougal, Other Leaders Expelled From Czechoslovak Party
DOC.TEXT: Former President Gustav Husak and other ex-leaders, including some forced from power in the pro-democracy revolution, were expelled Saturday from the Communist Party, official media reported. The expulsions were announced during a session of the party's Central Committee, the CTK news agency said. Husak became party chief in 1969 after the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in August 1968, which crushed the Prague Spring reform movement. He was replaced as party chief in December 1987 by Milos Jakes but continued as president until resigning Dec. 10 during the peaceful revolution that led to one-time dissident Vaclav Havel assuming the office. Also ousted from the party Saturday was former Premier Lubomir Strougal, who resigned from his government position on Oct. 11, 1988 after criticism from inside the Communist Party. He was replaced by Ladislav Adamec, who is now leader of the declining Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Mayoral Rival Won't Call for Barry's Resignation
DOC.TEXT: David Clarke is running for mayor of the nation's capital and already is just a step away from getting the job, eight months before the election. Clarke, the only white candidate for mayor in this predominantly black city, would automatically become acting mayor if incumbent Marion Barry stepped down because of his indictment last week by a federal grand jury. The 46-year-old City Council chairman says, however, that he doesn't want the job that way. ``I am not a candidate for acting mayor,'' Clarke said. ``I'm not calling for (Barry's) resignation.'' He says that if he succeeded Barry before the Nov. 6 election it could upset many blacks, who make up 70 percent of the population of the District of Columbia. ``Our community is going through a difficult time,'' Clarke said. ``It's going through mourning.'' He says he knows that a number of blacks are concerned over whether Barry has been treated fairly. In any case, he says, Washingtonians need to ``restore their dignity'' by voting for the next mayor and not have one foisted on them. Barry was indicted Thursday on three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury and five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession. He was arrested Jan. 18 in a sting operation in a downtown hotel. Barry, in a statement released by his aides, said he would be exonerated at his trial and added that he was not considering a resignation. Under city law, he can serve as mayor unless he is jailed after being convicted. Clarke, asked in a recent interview about his chances of being elected, said, ``I'm staking my career on it.'' He stressed his ties in Washington, where he was born and schooled. He was director of the local branch of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in the 1960s and part of the campaign that led Congress to grant home rule to the city in 1973. He said he doubts that race will be a major factor in the voting. ``I am not hearing it, and I do not think it is a feeling of the majority of the voters in this city,'' Clarke said. ``If I thought it was a dominant feeling, why would I take this gamble?'' Clarke pointed out that before winning the chairmanship in a citywide election eight years ago, he represented a racially diverse ward. The next mayor should come from within local politics, he says. He brands the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who moved here last year, as an outsider. Jackson remains noncommittal about a run for mayor. A Washington Post poll the day after Barry was arrested showed Jackson as a strong favorite, with Clarke and other announced candidates well behind. There have been hints that the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia, Jay B. Stephens, might accept Barry's resignation as part of a plea bargain. The mayor dropped plans to announce for a fourth term on Jan. 21 _ three days after his arrest _ but has given no sign that he will not run. He currently is in a drug and alcohol rehabilitation clinic in Florida while city administrator Carol Thompson heads a caretaker government. Barry says he is being treated for alcoholism. If Barry were to resign, Clarke would become acting mayor for up to 120 days, the deadline for holding a special election. If Barry were to resign within 60 days of the election, however, Clarke would be mayor until then. Clarke refused to discuss what he would do if Barry resigned and he automatically became mayor. But he spoke eagerly of the kind of mayor he would be if the voters choose him in November. ``I'd be much more low key,'' he said, contrasting his style to Barry's. ``You won't see any great claims of the Dave Clarke administration,'' he said. Instead, Clarke says, he would concentrate on ``getting things done.'' The 6-foot-5, 250-pound Clarke at times appears disheveled with shirttail out and necktie askew as he lumbers about the District Building. Often, he can be seen pedaling a bicycle around town. Clarke and his wife, Carole, have been married for 16 years and friends say their social life is anything but flamboyant. His style is in sharp contrast to that of Barry, an impeccably groomed, self-described ``night owl'' who travels by chauffeured limousine and relishes his entourage and other trappings of power. Clarke characterizes his relationship with Barry as one of ``respect, constructive tension,'' but is noticeably irritated with the way Barry has reacted to policies Clarke helped establish on the council. ``After 16 years in making policies, we haven't seen enough realized because of the administration,'' the chairman said. The other candidates for mayor are Sharon Pratt Dixon, a utility company executive and Democratic National Committee member; and council members John Ray and Charlene Drew Jarvis.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Southeast Has Gotten Cooler and Wetter Over Past 30 Years
DOC.TEXT: Despite fears that the planet is heating up, temperatures in the southeastern United States have actually fallen 1 degree Fahrenheit over the past 30 years, according to a federal study released Saturday. The finding contradicts the widely held notion that pollution in the atmosphere has already made temperatures start to rise. ``It's cooling and getting wetter,'' said George A. Maul. ``This is quite different from what the computer models suggest should be going on with global warming.'' Often-repeated theories of global warming hold that rising levels of carbon dioxide, methane and other gases are trapping heat in the atmosphere, causing the so-called greenhouse effect. These gases result from burning fuels and other sources. Computers programmed to run complex mathematical formulas predict that if the gases continue to build up, temperatures around the world will jump between roughly 3 and 8 degrees Fahrenheit over the next century. Maul, an oceanographer with the U.S. Commerce Department's Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory in Miami, presented his findings at a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. He said his work does not definitely prove that global warming isn't happening. The fall in temperatues ``may be a factor of the difficulty of calculating global warming on a regional scale. But it should increase the debate about global warming.'' Last year, Maul and colleagues produced a report showing that overall temperatures across the United States have been virtually unchanged during the past century. Two other studies, done by other groups of researchers, suggest that around the world, temperatures have risen 1 degree in the past 100 years. However, some critics have suggested that this rise might be partially due to increasing urbanization where the temperatures are recorded. City temperatures are higher than the surrounding countryside because of the concentration of people. Maul's latest data show that from the turn of the century to the mid-1940s, average temperatures in the Southeast rose a half-degree. But since then, they have fallen a full degree. So over nearly a full century, temperatures have dropped half a degree. At the same time, annual rainfall in the Southeast has increased 65 millimeters, or roughly 2{ inches, since the turn of the century. Maul said he believes that if the heat-trapping gases continue to increase _ and nothing else changes _ then global temperatures almost certainly will increase. However, he said, too little is known about other forces that affect weather, such as ocean currents and the sun's output, to say with certainty that the planet will heat up. Computerized predictions, known as computer models, produce widely divergent scenarios of what might happen, especially over relatively small portions of the Earth. The weather is affected by mountains, lakes and other features on the Earth's surfaces. However, adding all of these features to the computerized calculations makes the job dauntingly complex. Michael E. Schlesinger of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, who makes computer models, said that accurate predictions about global warming will require calculations that use 10 times finer detail. And producing a model with this much detail would require running the world's fastest supercomputer non-stop, day and night, for 40 years, he said. Despite the uncertainties, many climate experts have used the existing models to speculate about what might happen over the next century. Among the predictions offered at Saturday's meeting: _Diana Liverman of Pennsylvania State University said higher temperatures and lower rainfall could damage Mexican farming. Corn output, for instance, in non-irrigated fields could fall by 40 percent. _Orman E. Granger of the University of California at Berkeley said that rising sea levels in the Caribbean would destroy the beaches, which are crucial to the islands' tourist industry.

DOC.HEAD: Former Politburo Member Dead at 71
DOC.TEXT: Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, a conservative former Politburo member and chief of the Ukrainian Communist Party for 17 years, has died at the age of 71, the Tass news agency said Saturday. Tass said Shcherbitsky died after a long illness on Friday, a day short of his 72nd birthday. The conservative party chief, who ran the Ukraine and its 50 million people with an iron fist, was retired from the ruling Politburo Sept. 20 in a shake-up orchestrated by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He was relieved of his Ukraine post a week later. Shcherbitsky was one of the last Politburo members from the days of former President Leonid I. Brezhnev. Before his removal from party positions, activists in the Ukraine blamed him and his followers for slowing down economic and political reform in the nation's breadbasket and industrial heartland. Some Ukrainians blamed him for covering up the radiation damage from the Chernobyl nuclear power plant accident, for restraining the local press and for the arrests and harassment of dissidents. Thirty-one people died and hundreds were hospitalized in the Chernobyl accident on April 26, 1986. Shcherbitsky was born in the city of Verkhnedneprovsk in the Ukraine. Following service in the Soviet army from 1941 to 1946, Shcherbitsky began his climb in the Communist Party hierarchy by being elected second secretary of the Dneprodzerzhinsk City Committee in 1948. In 1961, he was appointed chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Ukraine and became a member of the Communist Party Central Committee. Shcherbitsky was appointed a member of the Politburo under Brezhnev in 1971. The Tass obituary was signed by Gorbachev and other members of the Politburo, including Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, Vitaly Vorotnikov, Yegor Ligachev, Vadim Medvedev and Alexander N. Yakovlev.

DOC.HEAD: Embattled Dodd Stakes Out Moderate Stance on Salvador Aid
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Christopher Dodd can't seem to shake the criticism on his left from opponents of military aid to El Salvador, an odd predicament for a longtime foe of administration policies in Central America. Dodd's Wethersfield, Conn., office has been occupied. His name has been pasted on effigies of death squad victims. In the latest campaign, college students in the Northeast are receiving phony draft notices urging them to call Dodd and change his position on Salvadoran aid. During the Reagan administration, Dodd supported a measure barring economic aid to El Salvador unless the U.S. certified progress in human rights. He also opposed President Reagan's certification of the country. Dodd, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs, has been a spokesman against aid to the Contras in Nicaragua. On those and other issues affecting the region, he has been no darling of the right. But his proposal last week to cut military aid and then either increase it or decrease it depending on the progress of peace negotiations won no converts among left-leaning groups. Dodd says the plan was a logical progression of his long-held view that Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani, a personal friend, wants peace and is willing to negotiate with rebel forces. The change in Dodd's position is in the amount he is willing to support. If the Salvadoran government broke off negotiations or failed on the human rights front, the aid would be cut entirely. On the other hand, if the rebel forces were responsible for breaking negotiations, full military aid would be restored. ``The time has come to frame our assistance in a way that evidences our firm support for what President Cristiani is trying to achieve,'' Dodd said. Among other things, he said, ``this legislation makes it clear that if Cristiani is overthrown or unconstitutionally removed from power, all assistance will be terminated.'' Coming two days after Sens. John Kerry and Edward Kennedy proposed a complete cut-off of aid, Dodd's proposal pleased conservative observers. ``Dodd is looking at it in a realistic manner,'' said Michael Wilson, a policy analyst at the conservative Heritage Foundation. ``He understands the issue a little bit better than some of these other senators as well.'' Typifying the reaction from the left was Larry Birns of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs. ``The basic thing about Dodd is he's a straddler,'' Birns said. ``He has lost a lot of credibility in terms of being the serious student of the region that he has long been believed to be. Within the community of those who closely monitor U.S.-Latin American relations, Dodd is looked on as unreliable and inconsistent.'' Dodd and his liberal critics disagree on a fundamental point: the impact of military aid. Birns and others argue that military aid simply provides the tools for right wing death squads to carry out their terror campaign against peasants, land reformers and anyone else deemed potentially ``subversive.'' Dodd argues that military aid prevents violence by convincing rebels that they cannot take over the country by force and must negotiate for a political role. ``There are those who say `If we cut off aid we cut off the war.' That is just not a fact,'' said Dodd's top Senate aide, Jason Isaacson. The group whose local chapter was responsible for the ``draft cards'' being sent to Yale, Rutgers and other schools is pleased that Dodd has at least abandoned his support for full military aid to El Salvador. ``That he's calling for a cut-off of half the aid indicates that the policy is in trouble and it indicates that the pressure that has been put on in his district and around the country has had some impact,'' said Hugh Byrne, political director of the Committee in Solidarity With the People of El Salvador. Byrne points to the co-sponsors of his proposal _ moderate Sens. Jim Sasser, D-Tenn., Joe Biden, D-Del., Terry Sanford, D-N.C., and Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., _ as an indication that he has staked out a centrist position. Isaacson rejected any notion that Dodd formulated his policy with his critics in mind. ``This proposal has to do with what's going on in El Salvador today and with what's gone on in El Salvador for the last 10 years,'' Isaacson said. ``It has nothing to do with what goes on in this country.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Will Stay Out of Reagan-Poindexter Court Fight
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Bush plans no more public appearances Saturday; this story may stand
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, out for a chilly ``power walk'' near his snow-swept vacation home, said he plans to stay out of former President Reagan's court battle with John Poindexter. Asked if he had talked recently to Reagan, who gave closed videotape testimony Friday and Saturday in the trial of his former national security adviser, Bush said ``No, have not talked to him.'' Bush said he planned to ``stay out of it.'' As to whether he thought it was good that the former president had testified, Bush said ``That's a matter between him and the process. ... The process worked.'' The Bush administration, however, joined Reagan's defense last week in supporting his assertion of executive privilege to avoid turning over diary excerpts sought by Poindexter. Poindexter goes on trial March 5 on charges of concealing from Congress assistance that national security aide Oliver North gave to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels and lying about a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Bush, who was Reagan's vice president, consistently has denied any knowledge of the Iran-Contra dealings. Bush arrived in Maine on Friday to spend the holiday weekend with his wife, Barbara, at their seaside home. Skies dawned sunny on Saturday, but a bitter wind blew across the snow scape. Dressed in wool plaid pants and a leather flight jacket against the icy air, Bush headed off on a vigorous march of about 5 miles to inspect repairs on his speedboat. Although he invited reporters to join him for part of the slushy walk, Bush was not in a mood to discuss issues. ``No questions,'' he called curtly as he and Mrs. Bush set out from the family compound on Walker's Point. Instead he bantered about the ``great day,'' and pointed out his secret for icy-weather walks _ a cane he called ``one of these sticks for the non-slide walker.'' He said he had heard no news of reports that Cuba was to reform its party structure. However, he said he had spoken to Boston Cardinal Bernard Law, who was going to meet with church leaders in Cuba. Asked about the four-nation drug summit he attended Thursday in Colombia, he said reaction has been ``so far pretty good.'' He jovially shook hands with a few bystanders along the residential route, but seemed more intent on racing past them to keep up his breakneck pace. ``Careful of this down slope, you guys,'' Bush told the press pack before dashing off ahead. ``I have to speed up. I hate to go so slow,'' he said as aides and bodyguards panted along. ``Power walk,'' he shouted to reporters, apparently missing their rejoinders that this form of exercise was the habit of his former Democratic presidential rival, Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis. Bush walked to nearby Cape Porpoise where his speedboat Fidelity is in dry dock for an overhaul. Bush proclaimed the job ``beautiful.'' ``New screws, new engines, everything. It's perfect.'' Mrs. Bush rode back in one of the security vehicles that accompanied them on the walk, while Bush was joined by his daughter Dorothy LeBlond, a Maine resident, for the return hike. Bush went the opposite direction for his walk than he did a year ago when a walk into the town of Kennebunkport resulted in a chaotic traffic jam of reporters, cameras, townspeople and security vehicles. The Bushes were planning later Saturday to go over remodelling plans with the interior decorator who will redo some rooms in the 87-year-old stone house on Walker's Point. They plan to return to Washington on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon: Winter Winds, Waves Remove Much of Oil Spill
With AM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Winter winds and waves have broken down or removed much of the oil left over from last year's cleanup, Exxon says, but state officials are not so sure. ``There's a considerable amount of oil that's not been removed,'' said Art Weiner, an Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation official who heads scientific programs for the state's oil spill team. Exxon officials said Friday that some beaches that were black with oil in September from the March 24 spill from the Exxon Valdez tanker are now clean, especially those that have taken the most intense beatings from winter storms. The beaches are in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska. Even areas that are more protected from the elements are being cleansed by the harsh weather, they said. ``There has been significant removal through time,'' said Andy Teal, a biologist coordinating Exxon's shoreline monitoring. ``More than half of what was found in September has disappeared by now,'' he said. Exxon said its data reflected surveys conducted from September through December. On Friday, Exxon turned over four months of data from its monitoring program to the state conservation department and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The company said the data reflected its best estimate of how much oil from the nation's worst oil spill remains on the beaches and under the surface of Prince William Sound and the nearby gulf. The Exxon Valdez went aground on Bligh Reef as it was leaving the oil port of Valdez. It spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude into the sound and the gulf. Company officials said they hoped the sharing of data with the federal and state governments would help defuse a ``contentious'' atmosphere that has existed in recent months concerning the effects of the spill and cleanup. ``We don't want to come across as if there's no problem,'' said Hans Jahns, Exxon's scientific coordinator who is analyzing the information that 19 scientists have gathered since September. The studies were conducted at 64 sites throughout the oil spill area, Jahns said. Some beaches remain blackened to varying degrees, he said. Jahns disputed recent state figures that as much as 6 million to 7 million gallons of oil remained along the affected area, more than 1,000 miles of shoreline of Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska. Exxon officials refused to estimate how much cleanup might be needed this summer, saying they will release their general 1990 cleanup proposal in March. State crews surveying the shorelines in the sound and the gulf would have more information on current oil conditions within 10 days, Weiner said.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Promises to Work to Free Lebanon Hostages
By MICHAEL GOLDSMITH
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat promised the sister of American hostage Terry Anderson on Saturday that he will do his ``very best'' to help free Anderson and the other 17 Westerners held in Lebanon. The Palestine Liberation Organization leader met for an hour with Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, in the dining room of his well-guarded mansion overlooking the Mediterranean in the Tunisian capital, where the PLO has its headquarters. They ate lunch while a score of friends and associates looked on and later discussed what Arafat called the ``tragedy of the hostages held in Lebanon.'' ``I am doing my very best to get the hostages released,'' he told Mrs. Say. ``I shall continue to do this because I consider it my duty. With the fanatical groups holding them, it is not an easy task. But I promise you that I will do my utmost.'' Mrs. Say arrived in Tunis on Friday to appeal to Arafat to use his influence to obtain freedom for Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press who was kidnapped March 16, 1985 in Beirut. On her European trip, Mrs. Say has been accompanied by Larry Heinzerling, a deputy director of the AP. In Tunis, Mrs. Say also pleaded the cause of the other Western hostages, who include seven Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. Most of the hostages are believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups. Arafat told Mrs. Say that he had no contact with those holding the hostages and that the only person who could be expected to help was President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran. ``Even he is blocked for the present because of the power struggle inside the Iranian leadership,'' Arafat said. ``If Rafsanjani alone were in power, it would be very easy.'' Rafsanjani is believed to want to improve Iran's ties to the West, and this has put him at odds with more hard-line Iranian politicians. Arafat agreed ``with pleasure'' to accept letters to the hostages carried by Mrs. Say and assured her he would try to relay them. ``You have my sincere gratitude for your efforts,'' Mrs. Say told the Palestinian leader. Mrs. Say's ``humanitarian pilgrimage'' has also taken her to meet with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar in New York, Pope John Paul II in Rome, leaders of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France and top officials of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva. She is scheduled to continue her trip Monday to Paris to meet with UNESCO Director-General Federico Mayor, then to Damascus to confer with Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk Al-Sharaa and later Canterbury, England to meet with Anglican Archbishop Robert Runcie. A group calling itself Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, is believed to hold Anderson and Runcie's special envoy to the Middle East, Terry Waite, who disappeared while trying to negotiate the release of the hostages on Jan. 20, 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Man With Altar in Basement Charged With Possessing Stolen Religious Articles
DOC.TEXT: A man with an immaculately kept basement room furnished with an altar and labeled ``chapel'' has been charged with possessing thousands of dollars worth of stolen religious articles. Priests from around the area were showing up at the police station Friday and Saturday following the arrest to reclaim vestments, chalices, statues and other items. William R. Silva, 22, was arrested Friday, the day after police acting on a tip confiscated hundreds of articles following a search of the house where he lives with his parents. The ``chapel'' was furnished with an altar, church kneelers, votive candles, flowers, church linens, chalices for Communion wine and a tabernacle for the storage of Communion wafers, police said. A photo album taken by police was filled with pictures of the altar decorated for Christmas, Pentecost and other religious holidays. There were pictures of Silva dressed in vestments and standing at the altar posing as a priest offering Mass. There also were color photos of people laid out in coffins, and newspaper obituary clippings. Silva reportedly had worked at several funeral parlors. Police said there was no evidence any of the photos had been taken in Silva's basement ``chapel.'' Dozens of vestments were confiscated, ranging from brown monks' robes and plain black cassocks to ornate brocade garments, police said. There also was a crimson skullcap belonging to Bishop Kenneth Angell, auxiliary bishop of the Diocese of Providence, police said. Silva may have bought some of the items, or received them as gifts, police said, but most were believed to have been stolen from Roman Catholic churches throughout Rhode Island. Their estimated value was more than $15,000. The thefts could date back as far as a decade, said Detective Capt. Alan B. Leach. Silva was released on $25,000 personal recognizance after arraignment in District Court, Warwick, on Friday. A steady stream of priests showed up at the station Friday to reclaim articles, Leach said. A dispatcher said Saturday that priests were continuing to show up to identify property. A priest from St. Augustine's Church in Providence recovered a carved wooden statue of St. Joseph worth about $3,000, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Parliamentary Election At-A-Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs Outgoing Lineup section to CORRECT Socialist seats to 83, sted 85
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Japan-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief rundown of facts and figures for Japan's national election Sunday. VOTING TIMES: Polling stations are open for 11 hours, closing at 4 a.m. EST Sunday. Most votes will be counted about six hours after polls close. VOTERS: About 90 million people are eligible to vote. AT STAKE: Voters cast one vote each in 130 multi-seat constituencies for 512 seats in Parliament's House of Representative, or lower house. The ruling Liberal Democratic Party must win at least 257 seats to retain the right to name the prime minister. CANDIDATES: 953 people, 66 of them women, are running. The Liberal Democrats are fielding 338; the Socialists 149; the Komeito (Clean Government Party) 58; the Communists 131; the Social Democrats 44; the United Social Democratic Party 6; the Progressive Party 7 and minor parties 64; independents 156. OUTGOING LINEUP: The Liberal Democrats, who held 295 seats in the outgoing lower house, have governed Japan since the party was formed in 1955. The Socialists, who had 83 seats in the lower house, are the largest opposition party, followed by the Komeito, with 54 seats; the Japan Communist Party, with 26 seats, the Democratic Socialist Party, with 25 seats; the United Social Democratic Party, with four seats, and eight independents. The remaining 17 seats were vacant. OUTLOOK: Polls predicted the Liberal Democrats would keep their lower house majority, though with fewer seats. The election was seen as a test of their popularity against criticism of a sales tax and of senior politicians' links to the Recruit influence-buying scandal. If the Liberal Democrats lost their majority, opposition parties were expected to try to form a coalition government, but major ideological differences between the various opposition groups could result in a period of political instability.

DOC.HEAD: National Attention on Spill to Prompt Call For Reforms in Oil Industry
With AM-Hazelwood Trial, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The sticky black goo slopping onto Southern California beaches from an oil spill is more than an environmental disaster. It's a conspicuous, election-year issue for politicians and environmentalists. ``This kind of thing motivates to action even people who are not politically or environmentally active,'' said Bob Hattoy, regional director of the Sierra Club. ``You've got angry Republican housewives from Orange County sopping up oil with tea towels. This will have an effect.'' The cause of the 400,000-gallon spill Feb. 7 still is under investigation, but officials speculated the 811-foot American Trader was struck by one of its anchors while maneuvering into a mooring area two miles offshore. The spill coincided with campaigns for the June primary, when candidates for governor will be chosen along with many other state and local offices. So many politicians went to the beaches that Mayor Tom Mays finally asked them for advance notice so they would not interfere with the cleanup. ``They were bringing their podiums on the beach and it was a whole show,'' Mays said. The interest among lawmakers, however, also is expected to revitalize efforts aimed at improving oil industry safety, including proposals for double hulls and double bottoms on tankers, better traffic control system to guide tankers along the coast, more tanker safety equipment, and a halt to new offshore oil drilling. The double hull issue probably will be the first settled because it is currently before a House-Senate committee working on compromise legislation. William Rusnack, vice president of corporate planning for Arco, said the oil industry was bracing for the worst. ``We always have a concern there could be an overreaction,'' he said. In the first days after the spill, strong Santa Ana winds kept the oil slick offshore, but a sudden shift in wind direction and high tides last weekend pushed the oil ashore on Huntington Beach and Newport Beach. Chocolate-brown waves crashed onto beaches caked in black muck that looked like asphalt and smelled like road tar. From the air, it looked like a highway had been paved where the water touched the sand. As of Saturday morning, 10 days after the spill, the oil had killed about 175 birds and coated 370 others in oil. About 1,000 grunion, a small fish, were killed when they came ashore to lay their eggs, which also were doomed. Halibut fisheries were devastated, fishermen said. Ship traffic was barred at three harbors, hurting fishing boat charter services, Catalina Island excursion operators and whale-watching boat operators. Even local fish stores that sold fish caught far away from the spill lost business from the publicly. State officials said things could have been much worse. The spill will not make the record books in terms of wildlife killed or dollars lost, and it pales in comparison to Alaska's Valdez spill. The cleanup was aided by cooperative weather in the early days, the geography of the beach, the accessibility of equipment and a lot of dumb luck. Sandbags and booms so far have protected environmentally sensitive wetlands, and almost no oil drifted south to the tide pools and the rocky shoreline, which would have been much more difficult to clean than the sandy beaches of Newport and Huntington. Some businesses even benefited from the spill. Restaurants and shops catered to curious visitors who wouldn't normally be on the beach in the slow winter season. One shop was selling $12.95 T-shirts that read, ``Crude is Rude, Dude.''

DOC.HEAD: Body of Foreign Minister Recovered
DOC.TEXT: Police flew the body of the country's foreign minister to the capital Saturday but refused to comment on whether he was murdered after dropping from sight last week. ``Only the Police Commissioner (Philip Kilonzo) or his deputy can comment, and they are not in,'' said an officer at the police headquarters. President Daniel arap Moi announced Friday that the body of 58-year-old Robert Ouko was found four miles from his family home at Koru. It had been partly burned. The president said the body was found ``in circumstances which indicated foul play'' and vowed ``anyone who may be associated with this horrible event will most certainly be apprehended.'' Ouko, considered one of the most articulate and able members of Moi's Cabinet, disappeared Tuesday, apparently without informing colleagues or family members of his plans. His disappearance went unreported until Thursday evening, when the offical Kenya News Agency broadcast an appeal from family members urging him to contact them or government officials. Nairobi newspapers Saturday carried lurid reports of the sighting of the body and its location on a slope, in a bush about a mile from the nearest road. The Daily Nation said Ouko's remains were in ashes. Nearby were a pair of gum boots, a walking stick, and a sheathed knife. Reporters at the scene said police kept them and local residents about 300 yards away as they loaded Ouko's remains into an air force helicopter for the journey to Nairobi. Ouko's last public appearance was on Feb. 10, when he addressed a service club in Kisumu, 220 miles northwest of Nairobi and not far from his home. The Kenya Times has reported that a white car arrived at Ouko's home at about 3 a.m. Tuesday and left with the minister. The newspaper attributed its report to sentry and a servant. Ouko, a father of four girls and three boys, first served as permanent secretary in the ministry of foregn affairs from 1963 to 1964 and held the same position in the ministry of works up to 1969. He later held other high-ranking government jobs before being tapped by Moi to head the foreign ministry in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Antony Michael, Popular Welsh-Born Actor, Dead at 38
DOC.TEXT: Antony Michael, a Welsh-born actor and theater director who had lived and worked in Denmark for 17 years, died of a heart attack at his home in Copenhagen, television reported Saturday. He was 38. The actor left his hometown of Swansea, Wales, in 1973 and traveled to Denmark, where he started his career by playing mimics. As he learned to speak Danish, Michael became popular as a revue theater actor. In 1989, he was awarded Denmark's top revue theater prize. He was also well known for a series of children's television programs. His death was announced by the TV2 channel during a show that once featured a comic routine in which Michael portrayed a Turkish immigrant trying to understand the manners and mores of Denmark. Michael married three times and was the father of three children.

DOC.HEAD: Militia Strikes Back At Helicopter Base
With AM-Lebanon-Scene, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with photographer killed, new cease-fire called, details. Pick up 13th graf pvs, `Geaga's gunners...'
DOC.TEXT: Christian militiamen struck back Saturday after a major defeat in Beirut, launching a massive tank-led assault against a helicopter base held by Gen. Michel Aoun's army north of the capital. Rescuers evacuated 32 bodies _ some mutilated beyond recognition _ from burned-out cars, tanks, apartments and narrow alleys of east Beirut's Ein Rummaneh district, taken by Aoun's troops Friday. The 18-day-old showdown for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has left 615 people dead and 1,829 wounded, by police count. Among the latest fatalities was Khalil Dehaineh, 26, a part-time photographer for the British news agency Reuters. Police said Dehaineh was killed by machine-gun fire in the Shiite Moslem district of Shiyah as he was taking pictures in the Ein Rummaneh neighborhood. A Shiite militiamen standing next to Dehaineh also was killed. Aoun's gunners and Lebanese Forces militiamen dueled with mortars in the streets of east Beirut Saturday, starting a dozen fires in the districts of Ashrafiyeh and Nabaa, the last two pockets controlled by the Christian militia in the capital. ``We are taking a short rest before we start uprooting them from Ashrafiyeh,'' one of Aoun's soldiers told reporters in Ein Rummaneh on Beirut's southeastern edge. Police said at least 1,000 heavily armed fighters from Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia were engaged in a three-pronged attack on the helicopter base at Adma, on the hilltop above the famous Casino du Liban in Kesrouan province. The Lebanese Forces said they had taken control of the base, but Aoun's command said the garrison shook off the repeated tank assaults. Aoun called a cease-fire throughout the Christian enclave as of 8:30 p.m. in response to repeated pleas by Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of the dominant Maronite Catholic sect. Geagea's forces accepted the truce and said its fighters had been ordered to stop shooting on deadline. Eleven previous cease-fires have failed to hold. The police spokesman, who cannot be named according to regulations, said Geagea's militiamen launched the attack on the base at first light. About 500 army commandos have been holding out against repeated assaults by the militia since the fighting started Jan. 30. He said Geagea's gunners used truck-mounted, multi-barreled rocket launchers that spit out 40 projectiles a minute to hit the base, as well as T-54 tanks to try to advance from the north, east and south. The commandos also held the Mediterranean beach that lies below the base to the west. Aoun's gunners outside the area were firing U.S.-made 155mm howitzers, ``trying to ease the pressure on the helicopter base,'' the police spokesman said. ``He won't be able to keep protecting it by shellfire.'' Geagea's gunners were also shelling the Aoun-controlled mountains on Kesrouan's eastern edge in an apparent effort to prevent the general from concentrating forces for a ground offensive to rescue the base, which has 12 of Lebanon's 18 French-made helicopter gunships. The remaining six are controlled by the 22,000-strong mainly Moslem troops loyal to President Elias Hrawi, whom Aoun refuses to recognize as Lebanon's leader. Geagea has recognized Hrawi, who was elected to implement a peace plan that Aoun opposed on grounds it did not provide for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon. The helicopter base is the only military facility that remains loyal to Aoun in Kesrouan province, the power base for Geagea's militia. Lebanon's four-plane air force, which had been loyal to Aoun, took off from its Halat air base in Kesrouan late Friday and defected to Hrawi's Syrian-backed governmment. They landed at a base in Syrian-policed north Lebanon, far from Aoun's artillery range. In the Ein Rummaneh neighborhood, scene of Friday's fighting, glass shards and debris carpeted the narrow alleys. Smoke billowed from hundreds of gutted apartment buildings. Power cables dangled from twisted poles and the wreckage of burned cars lined both sides of the streets. Pieces of furniture, pushed out of blown-up apartments, were scattered in the streets as water from blasted roof-top tanks drained underground shelters. ``Is this where we used to live?'' asked Mary Hajj, emerging from an underground shelter. Tears on her face, Mrs. Hajj, in her late 60s, kept repeating the same question. She seemed so stunned that she could not say anything else.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Demonstrator in White House Protest
DOC.TEXT: A Connecticut man protesting U.S. policies in Nicaragua was arrested Saturday for allegedly throwing a blood-like liquid onto a White House gate, police said. The arrest took place as an estimated 20 members of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War chanted `Give Peace a Chance' during a demonstration in support of the Nicaraguan government and its elections next Sunday. The group also demanded that the U.S.-backed Contra rebels be disbanded. Louis Debenedette, 46, was arrested outside the northeast gate of the White House after he threw what was believed to be blood onto the gate during the protest, U.S. Park Police officials said. He was charged with vandalism and released on his own recognizance, U.S. Park Police Lt. Philip Kramer said. The charge carries a $50 fine. Park police and Secret Service officials halted a White House tour, sealing some tourists inside the gate while the protest took place. None of the protesters got on the White House grounds, Kramer said. President Bush was at his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine, at the time. ``We are here protesting today in support of the Nicaragua elections (and) in support of President (Daniel) Ortega,'' Debenedette, a Vietnam-era veteran, said. ``We believe that the U.S. is trying to interfere in these elections. Nicaragua and El Salvador all represent to me the ugliness of this war machine in this country.'' A written statement issued by the group said the Contras ``continue to kill, destroy and terrorize.'' Debenedette currently lives in either Washington or Baltimore, but is originally from Montville, Conn., officials said.

DOC.HEAD: DoD Investigating Aircraft Engine Part
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department is investigating allegations that a Connecticut company manufactured a defective engine part used on some F-16 aircraft, according to documents obtained by a watchdog agency. A Navy memo from Dec. 13, 1989, noted that the Defense Criminal Investigative Service has ``initiated an investigation into allegations that gearbox housing assemblies ... are defective, creating a potentially serious hazard.'' The investigation centers around allegations about the units made by the Purdy Corp. of Manchester, Conn., for use in the F-16's F-100 engine, said the documents released by the Project on Government Procurement. The allegations are that the F-100 gearbox housing assemblies are being made in such a way that they could vibrate loose when attached to another part, the documents said. But the documents said, ``No problems of this nature have been reported ... regarding these parts as of this time.'' Navy spokesman Lt. Frank Thorp said the service does not fly F-16s with F-100 engines. The memos on Navy stationery were written as a precautionary measure after the Defense Department's inspector general was notified of the problem. The Air Force flies the F-16s with F-100 engines manufactured by Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Division, officials said. Lt. Don Black, an Air Force spokesman, said he did not know how many F-100 engines were involved. Purdy has been shipping the gear housing assemblies to Kelly Air Force Base in Texas since December 1988, the documents said. Carol Howell, who answered the telephone at Purdy, said no one at the company was available to talk about the case.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Deny Report of Riots in Ancient City of Samarkand
With AM-Soviet-Central Asia, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: A regional Communist Party leader on Saturday denied reports of rioting in Uzbekistan and another top official said the rumors were aimed at inflaming ethnic tensions in the neighboring republic of Tadzhikistan. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda warned that ethnic strife threatens the reforms of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and thousands of people in Leningrad demonstrated against civil violence, particularly anti-Semitism. Radio Moscow on Friday night reported clashes between members of the Moslem majority and ethnic Armenians in the ancient Uzbekistan city of Samarkand. It said army troops had been sent to the city and a curfew had been imposed. It attributed its information to the Interfax news service, a joint venture affiliated with Radio Moscow. But Nasyr Yakubov, the first party secretary of Samarkand, told The Associated Press by telephone that his city was quiet, there were no riots and no curfew was imposed. He said the city's 12,000 Armenian residents live in peace with members of other ethnic groups. Interfax later quoted an unidentified high-ranking Interior Ministry official in Moscow as saying the report amounted to ``provocative information aimed at aggravating the situation in the region and provoking new national disorders.'' Radio Moscow said further checks by its correspondents showed that Samarkand was ``calm and quiet.'' The city is about 1,700 miles southeast of Moscow and has a population of 390,000, mostly Moslems. The Armenian refugees are mainly Christians and had fled ethnic violence in the mostly Moslem republic of Azerbaijan. In the Tadzhik capital of Dushanbe, the army general in charge of enforcing a state of emergency said that thousands of troops have helped to stabilize the city after a week of unrest. ``I cannot say we have full control over the situation now, but there are no more outrages like those that took place Feb. 13 and 14,'' Lt. Gen. Georgy Kondratyev said in an interview with the newspaper Sovietskaya Rossia. The violence in Dushanbe, a city of 596,000 people 1,600 miles southeast of Moscow, was touched off Feb. 10 by rumors that Armenian refugees were arriving by the thousands and receiving scarce apartments. The official Tass news agency said the death toll in Tadzhikistan had risen to 22. In a front-page editorial, Pravda said increasing civil violence and confrontations in the far-flung Soviet republics are endangering Gorbachev's reforms. The newspaper said the Soviet Union was at a turning point. Democracy, it said, must be defended from political extremists on the right and left. ``Democracy should not be left defenseless before the danger of civil confrontation, chaos and unstability,'' Pravda said. ``Unfortunately, the danger is becoming more and more real.'' ``The key question of the day is on what ground stabilization will be achieved,'' it said. ``On the grounds of democracy, with the help of emerging democratic institutions, on the ground of national and inter-ethnic accord _ or in accordance with the forced methods of `tightening the screws' happily used in the past?'' Perestroika is forging fundamental changes in the Soviet Union, Pravda said. ``We must defend our perestroika as a revolution which is worthwhile only if it can defend itself,'' Pravda said. ``And we shall defend it from violence and political platitude, from ignorance and Philistinism, from unreason and destruction.''

DOC.HEAD: The Brotherhood of Violence in and out of Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Strangulation, decapitation, cocaine dealing, greed and a teen-ager's ghoulish rap song are elements in a bizarre murder trial that has pitted brother against brother. Ruben Deases, just turned 18, is charged with first-degree murder in the killing of Jennifer Ann Gardner. A brother, Edward Deases, 21, awaits trial on the same charge. A third brother, Johnny, 16, is the state's key witness. Four youth workers have testified that Ruben bragged about the May 28 killing after his arrest and even made up rap songs about it. One such song included the lines, ``She thought she was cool, and I was a fool. And now she's dead and I'm ahead,'' said Jack Leinen, a former youth services worker at the Des Moines detention center where Ruben was held. Ms. Gardner, 20, was the girlfriend of a fourth Deases brother, Eustaquio, 23, a cocaine dealer who according to defense lawyers sold $10,000 worth of the drug a week. They shared a one-bedroom apartment in Ames, a college town north of Des Moines in central Iowa. Called by prosecutors to testify on Friday, Eustaquio lunged across the defense lawyers' table at Ruben, throwing punches and snarling curses. Officers had to pull the brothers apart. At the time of the death, Edward and Ruben Deases also were living in the apartment. Johnny, then 15, was visiting for the weekend from Boys Town, the Nebraska home for troubled youth where Eustaquio met Ms. Gardner years earlier. On the night of May 28, while Eustaquio was out of town, Edward got into an argument with Ms. Gardner, Johnny testified. She was strangled, then decapitated. The next day her head was found by a jogger in a roadside ditch south of Ames. Ruben and Edward were arrested June 1, hours before her torso was found in a lake north of Ames. Johnny Deases testified that Edward was jealous of Ms. Gardner's influence over Eustaquio and that Edward viewed the woman as an obstacle to his advancement in Eustaquio's cocaine dealing business. After quarreling with Edward, Johnny said, she threatened all three brothers with a 9mm automatic and went into the bedroom. Johnny, Ruben and Edward sat in the living room and plotted her death. Johnny said he was recruited to kill her because of his legal status as a juvenile, but lost his nerve. Ms. Gardner had returned to the living room with a beer and was sitting on the couch watching MTV, Johnny said, when Ruben moved behind her and grabbed her throat in a choke hold, lifting her feet from the floor. ``She was struggling,'' the youth said. ``Her legs were moving and he brought her to the ground in about 45 seconds.'' ``She was panicking as if she was drowning. Her arms were moving every which way. ... Her legs were moving every which way ... She was gasping for air,'' he said. Johnny Deases said Ruben choked the woman until she was unconscious, and Edward then strangled her with a belt while Ruben held the body down with his foot. Johnny also said he saw Ruben have sex with the corpse. Defense lawyer Stephen Terrill contends Ms. Gardner was killed by Edward, and that Ruben pleaded with his brother to call an ambulance. He also got Johnny Deases to admit he earlier had withheld evidence and lied about what happened on the night of the killing. Chris Cox, a former Iowa State University football player who shared the rent on a West Des Moines apartment with Eustaquio Deases, said Edward, Ruben and Johnny Deases showed up at his apartment in the wee hours of May 29. Cox said that while Johnny Deases went to another room, he freebased cocaine with Edward and Ruben, who wanted to know what to do with a dead body and whether they could borrow knives, rope and tape. ``It seemed weird,'' Cox said, when Edward and Ruben told him they had killed Ms. Gardner and left the body in the bathroom of the apartment. The brothers were arrested only after they told another friend about killing Ms. Gardner and he alerted authorities after hearing news accounts about the slaying. Ruben is scheduled to testify in his own defense. If convicted of first-degree murder, the brothers face mandatory life prison sentences, without parole. Since the killing, Eustaquio has been arrested and sentenced to prison on a federal cocaine trafficking conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Prosection Close to Wrapup in Exxon Valdez Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES extraneous matter at end; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: When the Exxon Valdez sailed into icy Alaskan waters, its crew included a timid helmsman, a second mate with alleged mental problems and a captain with a history of drinking, according to testimony at Joseph Hazelwood's criminal trial. As the prosecution ended its second week of evidence and prepared to wrap up its case, a picture emerged of a cohesive navigational team strengthened by highly educated and experienced officers but weakened by the troubled few. As the case against Hazelwood unwound, questions were raised about the skipper's drinking, his knowledge of the crew and his judgment in leaving the ship's bridge in the hands of others at the time of a tricky maneuver. Did he know that the man holding the ship's wheel, Robert Kagan, had well-known problems with steering? Did he rely too much on the veteran third mate, Gregory Cousins? And, once the ship was grounded, did Hazelwood try a dangerous maneuver to rock it off a jagged reef? The jury must decide whether any of Hazelwood's actions constituted the reckless behavior with which he is charged. The 43-year-old Hazelwood, the only person criminally prosecuted in the nation's worst oil spill, is charged with second-degree criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanors _ reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. If convicted on all charges, Hazelwood faces a maximum penalty of 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. The March 23, 1989, grounding of the 987-foot Exxon Valdez spilled 10.92 million gallons of oil into the clear waters of Prince William Sound, killing countless birds, fish and wildlife and coating hundreds of miles of rocky coast with black goo. As crew members formed a virtual parade to the witness stand, their struggle to maintain loyalty to the captain while testifying against him was evident. Cousins, who was in charge of the ship when it ran aground, blamed the helmsman, Kagan, for failing to follow orders and steer hard to the right. ``I think Mr. Kagan didn't really understand the command,'' said Cousins. The third mate credited Hazelwood with being calm and clearly in command after the disaster. Kagan himself conceded under oath that he had become ``timid'' about steering after he was once accused of ``chasing the compass,'' or oversteering a ship. James Kunkel, the chief mate, graduate of prestigious Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy and a 20-year veteran of the seas, suggested the skipper knew _ or should have known _ that helmsman Kagan was the weak link in the ship's chain of operations. ``I mentioned I'd sailed with him before and I thought he needed extra supervision and extra practice in steering,'' Kunkel said, recalling a conversation he had with Hazelwood. He said Kagan could not do even the simplest tasks without being watched. Once, he said he assigned Kagan to paint a bulkhead, but knew he would have to keep an eye on him to make sure he used the right paint and brush. Yet Kunkel credited Hazelwood with keeping everyone calm aboard ship and said he made prudent decisions in the wake of the grounding. The second mate, Lloyd LeCain, said he had assessed Kagan's capabilities as ``slightly below normal.'' ``I talked to Capt. Hazelwood about it,'' he testified. ``He knew he had a problem. He told me to keep an eye on him when he was steering.'' But Hazelwood's defense team immediately attacked LeCain's crediblity, telling the judge that LeCain was on leave from Exxon for mental problems. They asked that the jury be told that LeCain had boasted of being a submarine commander in the Falklands, a Green Beret in Vietnam and a figure in the Iran-Contra affair. Defense lawyer Dick Madson said that when Hazelwood left his ship after the accident, LeCain approached him and said he had two cyanide pills in case he needed to commit suicide, saying he was ``Ninja trained.'' Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone ruled that jurors should not hear these allegations because they were confusing and constitued ``character evidence'' not permitted under Alaska law. And then there was crew member Maureen Jones, who was the lookout. When the Exxon Valdez grounded she said she saw ``an aura'' around the bow of the ship which she could not explain. She described it as ``a greenish glow.'' For Hazelwood, who has a history of drunken driving convictions and is accused of intoxication on the fateful night, one fact mentioned by every crew member was important. They said the captain seemed sober and in command after the accident and denied smelling alcohol on his breath. Blood and urine tests taken about 10 hours after the accident showed alcohol in his system and an investigator smelled liquor on him. ``What was the captain's demeanor?'' Kunkel was asked about the hours after the grounding. ``Very sullen but all business,'' he replied. ``Cool, calm, in charge.''

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Declare Success in Putting AIDS in Remission
DOC.TEXT: Drugs are now available that can put AIDS patients into remission, and recent advances have made clear that a vaccine to protect against AIDS infection is possible, a panel of AIDS experts said Saturday. At the same time, however, the AIDS epidemic is being followed by a suddenly resurgent epidemic of tuberculosis, the scientists said. ``We have now made demonstrable first steps in inducing remission,'' said William Haseltine of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. ``I think there is evidence that a substantial number of people who would have died are now alive,'' Haseltine said at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. He cautioned against a premature conclusion that the AIDS epidemic may be coming to an end. A number of treatments for AIDS and AIDS-related infections are available, he said, but many of them are not available to the poor or to developing countries. ``It looks like most of these will be expensive, hard to deliver and require monitoring,'' Haseltine said. ``Unless we develop a vaccine, the future of this epidemic worldwide will be extremely grim,'' he said. A year ago, the prospects for an AIDS vaccine looked doubtful, said James Mullins of Stanford University. But that has changed. ``There has been a transition in the effort to find a vaccine,'' Mullins said. Vaccines to protect animals against AIDS-related viruses have shown some success, he said, encouraging researchers to believe that similar vaccines can be found for humans. ``There's new hope and interest that a vaccine is possible,'' said John McGowan of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Md. Sten Vermund, also of the Allergy Institute, noted that an epidemic of tuberculosis is emerging in AIDS patients in the inner cities. In New York City, for example, tuberculosis declined between 1960 and 1977, but is now increasing and has reached the 1960 level again. ``We anticipate in our major cities losing two decades of progress in our tuberculosis control efforts,'' said Vermund. And unlike the AIDS virus, which cannot be transmitted through casual contact, tuberculosis is easily transmitted through the air. ``I think we should worry about tuberculosis and the risk to the general population,'' Vermund said. Many of the cases of tuberculosis are occurring when individuals who were exposed to tuberculosis early in life contract AIDS. They lose the ability to continue suppressing the tuberculosis bacteria, which normally would have remained dormant, and tuberculosis appears. ``It's likely to be yet another health problem imposed on the inner cities, where the health problems are already legion,'' Vermund said. There is no strong evidence yet that tuberculosis is spreading to a significant number of poeple who do not have AIDS, but that is likely, Vermund said. He said the rise in tuberculosis began before the AIDS epidemic, probably because of the rise in the homeless population during the 1970s. Homeless people are at elevated risk of tuberculosis, Vermund said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Demand Talks With U.S. Diplomats on American Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT ages of Donnelly and Kent, SUB 8th graf; pickup 9th graf, `The third...'
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas said they would free two American hostages if U.S. diplomats negotiate conditions for their release, a newspaper reported Saturday. The fate of a third American hostage was unknown. The three men were captured last week when President Bush met in Colombia with three South American leaders to discuss ways to stop drug trafficking. The Bogota newspaper El Tiempo said relatives of two of the Americans _ James Donnelly of Detroit and David Kent of Indianapolis _ had been contacted in Medellin, where they traveled to gain news about the captives. The report said the relatives were assured that Donnelly and Kent, who were captured either Monday or Tuesday in the drug center of Medellin, were ``in good health and their lives will be respected.'' The paper said the kidnappers demanded that a committee be formed to discuss the unspecified conditions under which the two hostages would be freed. The report quoted the kidnappers as saying the panel should include representatives of Antioquia state, of which Medellin is the capital; the U.S. Embassy in Bogota; the Colombian Human Rights Comittee; the Red Cross; Colombia's attorney general; and relatives of Donnelly and Kent. The U.S. Embassy in Bogota did not comment immediately on the report. Donnelly, 65, a mechanical engineer, and Kent, 40, a school teacher, were kidnapped in Medellin in separate attacks by armed men. The third American, the Rev. Francisco Amico Ferrari of Rochester, N.Y., was kidnapped in Cali on Thursday while the summit was held in the resort city of Cartagena, 450 miles to the north. Although police blamed the leftist guerrillas for the abduction, no claim of responsibility has been received, and authorities and Amico's colleagues said no word has been received about his fate. The guerrillas, of the pro-Castro National Liberation Front, issued a statement Friday night claiming responsibility for the abduction of Donnelly and Kent, which the police had already blamed on the front. The communique, obtained by The Associated Press, said the rebels kidnapped Donnelly and Kent ``to condemn the U.S. intervention in Latin America.'' It said the Bush meeting with the leaders of Bolivia, Peru and Colombia was part of a plan to impose military control over Colombian territory. The four nations agreed on a joint plan to fight drug trafficking. Since last year, Washington has played a key role in Colombia's crackdown on the Medellin and Cali drug cartels by extraditing several top drug traffickers to the United States to face federal charges.
