Referring to the U.S. invasion of Panama on Dec. 20 that ousted dictator Manuel Noriega, the guerrilla statement said: ``As it just happened in Panama, the objective (of the plan) is to impose its (U.S.) own interests.'' The statement also criticized to a U.S. proposal to place American ships off Colombia's shores to interdict drug shipments. The proposal was put on hold after it was criticized by Colombian officials. The guerrilla communique also criticized the Colombian government's free-market economic policies and a recently passed Medellin law taxing citizens to raise funds for the construction of a subway. The leftist insurgency, aimed at establishing a Marxist-Leninist state in Colombia, began 25 years ago. Authorities say the National Libertion Front and the Cali and Medellin drug cartels have not worked together in the past.

DOC.HEAD: Fauntroy Urges Tax Boycott Until District Achieves Statehood
DOC.TEXT: Walter E. Fauntroy, the capital's non-voting delegate to Congress and a prospective candidate to succeed embattled Mayor Marion Barry, has again asked his fellow residents to withhold payment of their federal income taxes until the city is granted statehood. Fauntroy, whose statehood bill lies virtually dormant in Congress, has promoted the tax disobedience strategy for weeks without much notice. But the proposal landed him on the front page of The Washington Post on Saturday, and was sure to raise more than a few eyebrows at a time when Congress and the administration are not in the friendliest of moods toward city officials. Fauntroy, who said he is ``agonizing'' about running for mayor in the wake of the perjury and cocaine-possession charges lodged against Barry, noted at a news conference Friday that people who fail to file tax returns or withhold their payments could face fines or imprisonment. But ``Those of us who have decided to take this action are prepared to accept those consequences,'' he said. Fauntroy and other statehood advocates have tried several gambits recently to revive interest in the statehood issue, even as the city's image is bogged in municipal scandal, a monumental drug problem and the highest murder rate in the nation. One idea has been to post signs at the city's borders which read: ``Welcome to the Nation's Last Colony. All residents must leave their rights at the border. D.C. Statehood Now.'' Another, in Barry's last proposed city budget, calls for the election of two ``shadow'' senators and a ``shadow'' congressman to lobby for statehood, though Fauntroy already effectively has that job in the House. Congress in 1978 did pass a constitutional amendment which, if ratified, would have granted statehood to the city. But only 16 states approved the amendment before the 7-year ratification period expired. Approval from 38 states is required. Fauntroy likened his tax protest to the civil disobedience of the civil rights movement. He said he would soon establish an ``escrow corporation'' to receive tax payments of fellow protesters, and hold them until statehood is attained. That organization, he said, will be called the ``Taxation Without Representation'' committee. Henry B. Holmes, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, said that while formation of the escrow corporation would appear to be legal, taxpayers who diverted their payments could still face serious penalties. Holmes noted that the U.S. courts have consistently ruled that similar tax protests, such as those against the Vietnam War, did not obviate criminal or civil liability for non-payment. With 650,000 residents, the District of Columbia is more populous than Alaska, Wyoming, Delaware, Vermont and North Dakota, while its 68 square miles is less than one-tenth the size of Rhode Island. President Bush has long opposed statehood for the district, though he favors it for Puerto Rico _ which likely would send Republicans to Congress. The Democratic Party's national platform in 1988, meanwhile, singled out the heavily Democratic city for statehood, a plank won by supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Despite that, the Democratic Congress has been less than eager to press the issue again. Jackson, himself a possible contender in the mayor's race, has acknowledged he might someday like to serve in the Senate, but denies any personal motivation for his support of D.C. statehood. Under limited home rule granted by Congress in 1974, Washington residents elect their own city government, which levies one of the highest local income taxes in the nation. But while they participate in presidential balloting, their only representation in Congress is the sole non-voting post held by Fauntroy. The federal government annually contributes about $500 million to the city's $3 billion budget. That payment, in theory, is in lieu of property taxes on federal lands and buildings in the city. Sen. John Warner, R-Va., recently called the federal subsidy a ``very hefty price'' and said that was why he had no use for the ``taxation without representation'' complaint. ``I brush aside this quotation, which was revered in 1776, but believe me, it doesn't apply to the District of Columbia today,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Miners Mostly Positive On UMW-Pittston Contract
DOC.TEXT: Miners, who vote Monday on the contract offer that would end their 10{-month-old strike against Pittston Coal Group Inc., are giving the proposals mixed reviews _ but say it probably will be accepted. ``It's kind of like a marriage. There are some good things and some bad things, but you've got to take them both,'' John Kirk, a striking UMW member from Coeburn, Va., said Friday. ``It's a good contract. I think it'll fly.'' The strike has idled 1,700 United Mine Workers members in three states. Kirk and the rest of the striking miners got their first look Friday at Pittston's 49-page proposed contract. The four-year pact would give Pittston's 1,700 union miners in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky concessions on health care and pension benefits and the company more flexible work rules. If the miners ratify the contract Monday, they could be back at work before the end of the week, more than two years after the old contract between the union and Pittston expired, UMW President Richard Trumka said. Trumka drew a round of applause when he displayed the contract offer while he met Friday with miners at the Russell County Fairgrounds in southwestern Virginia. ``I'm proud,'' Trumka said, choking back tears. ``I'm proud you did this,'' he said referring to the long strike. Pittston's offer is a winner, said Charlie Keen, a veteran miner from Whitewood, Va., who attended the rally at the fairgrounds. ``It's better than I expected,'' Keen said. ``I believe we'll be back to work next week. There's no doubt in my mind it will be ratified.'' ``I think a lot of people are relieved to hear it's a good contract,'' said Steve Powers, a striking miner from Clintwood, Va. ``Some people are struggling financially.'' Similar briefings were held for striking miners in West Virginia and Kentucky. UMW Vice President Cecil Roberts had to coax more than 200 members of Local 5737 out of the rain and into an eastern Kentucky elementary school to hear the contract provisions. The miners were angered with the pact's lack of provision for taking back 13 strikers accused of picket-related violence. ``I've glanced at it enough to know what my vote is, and my vote is no,'' said Jerry Hurley of Lick Creek, Ky. Roberts said the 13 miners were suspended, not fired, and their work status will be decided by an arbitrator. The UMW's strike began April 5. The contract settlement offer was reached New Year's Eve, but not made public until Friday, while the UAW tried to get $64 million in fines for illegal strike activities dismissed. Pittston President Michael Odom said the company was delighted the proposal is going to a vote. ``It's a good contract for our employees, good for the company and good for the communities,'' Odom said in a statement Friday. ``We look forward to going back to work.'' The UMW is eager ``to get back to doing what we do best, and that's mine coal,'' Trumka said. Wages were not a major issue in the strike, but miners would receive a cumulative $1.20-an-hour raise at the end of three years. Top-scale hourly pay in selected positions would be $17.52. Pittston won the ability to hire contract truck drivers and maintenance workers, so long as union miners are not laid off in the process. And the company would be able to run its mines 24 hours a day, seven days a week, except for Christmas and the Sunday day shift. The UMW won its demand to maintain the 100 percent medical coverage for employees, pensioners and their families, the same coverage provided by the 1988 national agreement. Pittston agreed to continue participation in the union pension plan.

DOC.HEAD: Crowd Welcomes Boxing Champion Home
LaserPhoto CO2
DOC.TEXT: A sometimes unruly crowd weathered freezing weather Saturday to hail heavyweight boxing champion James ``Buster'' Douglas as its hometown hero. Police on horseback had to drive back the crowd which surged toward Douglas' car in a parade downtown. Police estimated that 25,000 people jammed the parade route, including about 15,000 for a ceremony at City Hall. Douglas' motorcade passed through his old neighborhood earlier. One woman was injured when a mounted officer's horse stepped on her foot during the downtown parade, police said. The parade route was cut short and Douglas and his manager, John Johnson, arrived at the City Hall podium from a side street. The woman, whose identity was not available, was treated at St. Ann's Hospital and released, nursing supervisor Rick Ward said. No other injuries were reported. At City Hall, onlookers crowded the streets and watched from several levels of a high-rise parking garage across the street. The crowd crossed barriers erected earlier and pressed toward the reviewing stand. Some people carried posters lauding Douglas and ridiculing Mike Tyson's promoter, Don King. Douglas knocked out Tyson in the 10th round of their title bout last weekend in Tokyo. ``I'd like to thank everybody for coming out today, showing us support and appreciation,'' Douglas told the crowd. ``And, Columbus _ make the best of it, baby! ``As Mayor (Dana) Rinehart said, I couldn't have done it without the support of Columbus, my family, the Coach Boxing Team _ I love you,'' Douglas said. ``It really makes me feel good to see all you out here today.'' ``We're just everyday, hard-working, honest, God-loving'' people, Johnson said to scattered ``Amens'' from the crowd. ``The reason we beat Mike Tyson is because we believe in Jesus Christ. Mike Tyson is just another man. He was just another man.'' Rinehart and state Rep. Ray Miller presented proclamations designating Saturday James ``Buster'' Douglas Day in Ohio and the city. Nine-year-old Clent Dalton said he braved snow flurries and wind chills of 14 degrees because he watched the fight and wanted to see Douglas in person. ``Tyson had it, and he lost it,'' Clent said. ``I wanted Douglas to win, because he thought he was so bad at first. I guess there's always a bigger man, and he was one of them.'' Earlier Saturday, a 20-car motorcade wound through the low-income north-side neighborhood where Douglas grew up and stopped for a ceremony in his honor near the elementary school where his 11-year-old son, Lamar, is a student. ``I sure hope this does a lot to help. This neighborhood is infested with crack cocaine, and people don't know how to live right. Maybe this will help,'' said neighborhood resident Calvin Wilson. Douglas was recognized as the heavyweight champion by all three of boxing's governing bodies after a short-lived dispute over Tyson's knockdown of Douglas in the eighth round. King claimed referee Octavio Meyran gave Douglas a long count, allowing him extra time to get up.

DOC.HEAD: Two Charged With Extorting Money from Family of Missing Girl
DOC.TEXT: The grandfather of a 5-year-old girl missing since early December reacted with outrage to an alleged attempt by two men to extract $75,000 in exchange for her promised return. ``People who would prey on a tragedy are about as low as the people who would do it in the first place,'' Larry Pigue said after the arrest Thursday of two men on federal charges of extortion. Pigue is the maternal grandfather of Melissa Brannen, who has been missing since she attended a Christmas party Dec. 3 at the apartment complex where she lived in Lorton, Va., a suburb of Washington. Pigue told The Washington Post he and the girl's mother, Tammy, had doubts that the people who telephoned them Wednesday with the demand for money were really kidnapers because 10 weeks had elapsed since Melissa's disappearance. ``Your head tells you that it probably isn't true, but your heart tells you that you hope it is,'' Pigue said. The family had contacted the FBI by the time a second call came Thursday that led to the arrest of Anthony G. McCray, 24, and Emmett M. Grier III, 20, both of Washington, after arrangements were made to deliver the ``payoff.'' On Friday, U.S. Magistrate Jean F. Dwyer ordered McCray held for 10 days pending notification of authorities in Illinois, where officials said he was on probation. Dwyer placed Grier's bail at $100,000. U.S. Attorney Henry E. Hudson said the two men did not have custody of the child ``and there was no indication that they had in the past.'' Grier's father, Emmett Grier Jr., said his son had been on the honor roll at Royal Oak Shrine high school in Detroit, and had won two scholarships to Howard University. ``He said he wanted to take a semester off,'' Grier said. ``I was very upset but I didn't want to push. My son is basically a follower. I can't see him conjuring something like this up.'' McCray has never been a student at Howard, said university spokesman Alan Hermesch.

DOC.HEAD: Zulu Movement Questions Mandela's Commitment to Black Unity
LaserPhoto CPN1
DOC.TEXT: Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi and his organization Saturday lashed out at the African National Congress and questioned ANC leader Nelson Mandela's commitment to black unity. Buthelezi and the leadership of his Inkatha movement accused the ANC of trying to aggravate black political divisions. Their statements suggested that a bloody feud between the ANC and the more conservative Inkatha may persist despite the release of Mandela, who has been widely viewed a possible peacemaker. Also Saturday, blacks staged protest marches and rallies in several cities and towns across the country. The central committee of Inkatha adopted a resolution urging Mandela ``not to be used by factions in the ANC (which) are even now being destructively divisive when history is calling on all blacks to unite.'' Buthelezi, in a separate statement, said he was the target of a ``sordid and sick'' smear campaign by ANC-aligned activists, aimed at depicting him as the main cause of the 3-year-old conflict in Natal Province that has claimed more than 2,500 lives. Inkatha, which claims 1.5 million members, opposes the ANC's use of guerrilla violence and its advocacy of militant anti-apartheid tactics such as economic sanctions and consumer boycotts. The ANC favors a partly socialist economy, while Inkatha backs capitalism. On Friday, Buthelezi became the first black leader to criticize Mandela publicly since the ANC patriarch was freed Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison. Mandela made ``serious errors of judgment'' in suggesting that police sided with Inkatha in clashes between the group and the ANC, Buthelezi said. ``He did not even pick up the phone to check my side of the story.'' On Saturday, however, Buthelezi directed his criticism at the ANC, not at Mandela personally. Buthelezi said Mandela contacted him after the statement was issued Friday and added: ``I am entirely at ease and satisfied that there is still love and respect between us.'' Buthelezi, chief minister of the tribal homeland of KwaZulu, said he hoped to meet Mandela when the ANC leader visited Natal. This trip could take place as soon as next weekend. In black protests Saturday, police in the tribal homeland of Ciskei reportedly fired tear gas over a large area after blocking protesters from a stadium. A rally was planned at the stadium to protest the fatal shootings of several blacks by police last week during celebrations marking Mandela's release. In Johannesburg, about 1,000 black postal workers jogged through downtown, chanting in support of the ANC. They demanded higher wages and protested government moves to privatize major state-owned enterprises. About 1,000 youths staged a peaceful march in the Cape Province town of Wellington to demand improved educational and recreational facilities. In Thokoza, near Johannesburg, several thousand blacks attended a rally protesting high rents and demanding the mayor's resignation. In another development, a group opposed to mandatory military service said conscription should be suspended pending an inquiry into charges that a secret army unit masterminded assassinations of anti-apartheid activists. The statement by the End Conscription Campaign follows disclosures by police investigators and in news reports about four former members of a Johannesburg police squad who allegedly joined a covert army unit assigned to attack anti-government groups. One of the four is in custody, and arrest warrant have been issued for the others.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Break With Organized Labor
DOC.TEXT: Several hundred employees of a national bank ended a two-day sit-in Saturday to protest plans to close branches and cut jobs, but workers threatened a strike involving all five national banks. The employees at the National Mortgage Bank began their sit-in strike Friday and left Saturday afternoon. The secretary-general of the Bankworkers Association, Juan Zanola, said union members would strike all five national banks Monday. Organized labor, one of Argentina's most powerful institutions, appeared to be nearing an open break with the Peronist Party government it helped elect 10 months ago. Teachers demanding pay hikes threatened to boycott the start of classes March 5, and striking clerks who shut down federal courts one day last week pledged to do so again next week. The National Mortgage Bank workers were protesting plans to close 14 branches and cut 1,200 jobs. On Friday, President Carlos Menem said of the striking bank employees that ``It will go bad for them.'' He insisted he will go ahead with plans to restructure Argentina's failing, state-dominated economy. ``They may fatten the lines of the unemployed,'' he said of the strikers. Leaders of the 3 million-member General Labor Confederation sided with the strikers. ``We workers support ... Menem, but we reject restructuring plans that include layoffs of bankworkers,'' said Guillermo Andreoni, a secretary-general. Menem was elected last May and took office in July. His current confrontation with labor poses dire consequences for his plans to sell public companies, balance the budget by reducing state spending, and hold wage increases below price hikes as a way to curtail inflation. The confederation opposes any plan that may reduce jobs and benefits, and defends workers' demands for more pay. When the previous government tried similar measures, the group responded with 13 general strikes. The confederation so far has refrained from calling a general strike even though wages shrank by 50 percent last year, and Menem seems to have put the needs of business ahead of the demands of labor. Labor is disenchanted with Menem, who pledged during the campaign to raise wages, increase employment and turn around the state sector by increasing efficiency rather than selling companies that were created or nationalized four decades ago by President Juan Domingo Peron. Menem has said he has no choice but to impose austerity measures. Argentina no longer may borrow abroad because it stopped repaying its loans. Argentines refuse to lend money to the government that on Jan. 1 seized bank deposits. Printing money has led to hyperinflation. The showdown with organized labor comes at a time when Menem's public approval rating has slid to 48 percent, compared to 80 percent four months ago, according to a poll published several days ago by the respected Socmer agency. The national currency lost 28 percent of its value this week against the dollar, bringing the austral's devaluation to 51 percent since the start of the year, and 99 percent since January 1989. Devaluation has fueled inflation that in January soared by 79 percent, and by 4,924 percent in 1989. The cost of living from February 1989 through last month skyrocketed by 8,164 percent. Wages have not kept pace, a dilemma the government sought to alleviate by setting up soup kitchens, then by handing out food coupons. Neither solved the problem, and fears of social unrest, such as the food riots of last May, are widespread.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Upholds Legality of Nation's First Needle Exchange
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `If the...said,' to CORRECT name to Barker sted Baker.
DOC.TEXT: The legality of the nation's first hypodermic needle exchange program has been upheld by a state judge. Superior Court Judge Robert Peterson said Friday there is only preliminary proof the program is slowing the spread of AIDS but added, ``to wait until you get that concrete, specific evidence is too late.'' ``We waited a long time,'' said David Purchase, founder of the 1{-year-old program. ``Now we have a clear legal sanction, and we can go about the business of saving lives.'' Each week, health workers distribute about 2,000 clean needles to drug users in return for used ones, to prevent intravenous drug users who carry the AIDS virus from spreading it to others by sharing syringes. ``We'll obviously keep on going with what we think is a successful program to combat AIDS,'' said Dr. Al Allen, director of the Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. It is spread most often through sexual contact, shared needles or syringes, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring. Allen filed the lawsuit against the city of Tacoma and Pierce County last fall to test the legality of the program. The health department was the first public agency in the nation to sponsor a needle-exchange project. Robert Rohan, the department's lawyer, said the case also was the first in the nation to test the legality of a needle-exchange program. Although the ruling directly affects Tacoma only, Allen said the decision could serve as a precedent for similar programs nationwide. City Attorney Bill Barker said his staff would meet with the city manager and City Council next week to decide whether to appeal the ruling, and whether to pay the city's 50 percent share of the $45,000-a-year program. If the ruling stands, the city could participate ``without being under the threat of being charged or accused of making an expenditure on an unlawful or illegal program,'' Barker said. The city withheld its share in November after state Attorney General Ken Eikenberry issued an advisory, non-binding opinion saying needle exchange programs were illegal under state law. The law exempts state, county and municipal officers who distribute paraphernalia in their lawful duties, and the judge ruled that health officials are covered by that exemption.

DOC.HEAD: Ukraine Legislators Call for Chernobyl Nuclear Plant to be Closed
DOC.TEXT: Ukrainian lawmakers said Saturday the Chernobyl nuclear power plant must be closed and demanded to know why the issue was not on the agenda of the nation's Supreme Soviet legislature, the Tass news agency reported. Tass said a majority of lawmakers attending the current session of the republic's Supreme Soviet favored shutting down Chernobyl because of harmful environmental effects following a fire and explosion at the plant on April 16, 1986. Thirty-one people died and hundreds were hospitalized in the world's worst atomic accident. Ecologists have increasingly said the plant is a danger to the ecology of the Ukraine, the breadkbasket of the Soviet Union, and should be closed. Tass said deputies opposed to Chernobyl sent a telex to the national Supreme Soviet, currently in session in Moscow. ``In it, they ask why the question of the Chernobyl was not included in the agenda as one of the most vital questions,'' the news agency said. The national Ministry of Atomic Energy controls the nuclear power plant and the national legislature would decide whether it should be closed.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Sees One Of His Plays For First Time
With AM-Czech-Havel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, on his way to the United States and Canada, stopped over to meet Iceland's president Saturday and attend a play he wrote but had never seen performed. The new non-Communist president told a news conference he decided to visit Reykjavik, Iceland's capital, because the name is a symbol of peace _ a reference to the U.S.-Soviet summit in 1986. Havel talked with reporters before attending a production in Icelandic of his play ``Slum Clearance.'' Czechoslovakia's former hard-line Communist government banned Havel's plays for 20 years. Havel, his wife, Olga Havlova, and an entourage of about 80 people were scheduled to depart for the United States Sunday for a three-day visit. It will be the official trip to the United States by a Czechoslovak president, the nation's news agency CTK reported. Havel said he and Iceland's president, Vigdis Finnbogadottir, had common interests, since she is a former director of Reykjavik's municipal theater. Speaking in Czech, which was translated by a member of his entourage, Havel said he invited her to visit his country. The Czechoslovak president, who took office Dec. 29 after Communist leaders resigned, said he did not know whether he would run for the presidency in June elections. ``It does not depend on me,'' he said. ``It depends upon the various political forces, parties and organizations. All I can do is either accept or refuse.'' Also traveling with Havel is Premier Marian Calfa, Finance Minister Valcav Klaus and Minister of Foreign Trade Andrej Barcak. Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier and Deputy Premier Vladimir Dlouhy will join the delegation in Canada, CTK said.

DOC.HEAD: Filmmaker Michel Drach Dead at 59
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf `Drach made...' with 1 graf to ADD dropped letter in Dimanche. Pickup 5th graf `Working at...'
DOC.TEXT: Michel Drach, a director who along with Jean-Luc Godard and Francois Truffaut created a new style of filmmaking known as New Wave, died last week and was buried Saturday. He was 59. About 200 people attended the burial at the famed Pere Lachaise cemetery for Drach, who died of lung cancer Thursday at the American Hospital in Paris. The mourners included Drach's wife, actress Marie-Jose Nat, and his son, David, as well as Greek director Costa-Gavras and writer Gilles Perrault, whose novel ``Le Pullover Rouge'' Drach adapted into a film in 1979. Drach made his film debut in 1959 with the well-received ``On N'Enterre Pas le Dimanche.'' Working at the same time as Godard, Truffaut and Claude Chabrol, Drach experimented with the new, freewheeling cinematic styles that eventually became known as New Wave. In 1974, Drach made ``Les Violons du Bal,'' a dark tale based on the anti-Semitism he experienced as a child during the Nazi occupation. The 1979 hit ``Le Pullover Rouge'' turned his camera to crime in Marseille, where he made a strong case against the death penalty for the killers of a young girl. Drach's last film, ``Il Est Genial, Papy,'' in 1987, featured his friend Guy Bedos, who also attended Saturday's ceremony. He is survived by his wife and son.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Arrested During Soccer Protest
DOC.TEXT: Iran's official news agency reported Saturday that 30 people were arrested in Tehran after they hurled stones at cars and buildings to protest the postponement of a soccer game. The Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the angry fans had come great distances and waited in line for hours to see the match Friday. Some of the detainees were released after interrogation, IRNA said. Meanwhile, Iran's main opposition group said in a statement telexed to The Associated Press that there also were ``bloody'' anti-government protests in the Iranian capital Friday. The Mujahedeen Khalq, or People's Holy Warriors, said tens of thousands of Iranians demonstrated and clashed with security forces. The Baghdad-based group said the demonstrations began shortly after the soccer protest. The head of the Tehran soccer board, Hassan Aminbakhsh, said the matches were postponed because the field had been flooded by heavy rains and snow the night before. Aminbakhsh told IRNA he was present at the stadium Friday and unsuccessfully tried to switch the games to another stadium. He criticized the government-run radio for not carrying IRNA's anouncement about the postponement hours before the scheduled game time.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin Opposes NATO Link For Reunified Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that Genscher is foreign minister sted defense minister, SUB 2nd graf pvs; pickup 3rd graf pvs, `The Bonn...
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union will block the reunification of Germany if the West insists on NATO membership for the combined states, a top adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Saturday. Also Saturday, two West German publications said Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher made concessions to Moscow to win Kremlin support for reunification last week. The Bonn government denied the reports, which said the West German leaders agreed to seek immediate legal recognition of Poland's Western border by a united Germany; and promised that East Germany would continue to supply the Soviets with much-needed food and farm equipment. In an attempt to calm Soviet fears about security, Genscher Saturday ruled out basing NATO troops on what is now East German soil. ``The West is agreed that with a unification of Germany, there will not be any eastward extension of NATO,'' Genscher told the Westdeutsche Rundfunk radio station. His comments conflicted to some extent with those of West German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg, who said Friday that NATO's military protections should extend ``without weakening'' to all of Germany in the event of unification. West German officials have said they have no intention of turning their backs on the Western alliance. The Kremlin made its stance clear Saturday. ``If the Western alliance sticks with its demand for a NATO membership of all of Germany, then there won't be any German unification,'' Valentin Falin said in an interview with Saarland state radio. Falin, in addition to serving as a Gorbachev adviser, is the head of the international section of the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee. He also is a former Soviet ambassador to West Germany. The Soviet Union has been hardening its stance against NATO membership for a united Germany, creating an impasse that could slow the breakneck pace toward reuniting the states split after World War II. Poland's insistence on a role in guiding the process has created another potential stumbling block. It is concerned about conservative West German politicans' claims to pre-war German territories that were awarded to Poland by the Allies after World War II. The Welt am Sonntag newspaper reported that Kohl and Genscher, when they met with Gorbachev last week, promised to seek full and immediate legal recognition of Poland's Western border by a unified Germany. A Bonn government spokeswoman denied Saturday that such a promise was made but added that ``it is possible this issue was discussed.'' Welt am Sonntag and the influential Der Spiegel magazine of Hamburg said Kohl and Genscher also guaranteed to the Moscow leadership that East Germany's contractual obligations to deliver various products to the Soviet Union would be upheld after reunification. Welt am Sonntag said the products were mainly food and farm equipment. The Soviet Union is heavily dependent on East Germany for such agricultural products. The spokeswoman denied that such an agreement was reached in Moscow but added: ``These issues can only be settled after the joining of the two German states.'' Der Spiegel appears on the newsstands on Monday and Welt am Sonntag is a Sunday newspaper. Both provided their reports to other news media in advance of publication. West Germany has sought to quicken the pace of unification, prompting East German protests that Bonn has been heavy-handed in its dealings with its troubled neighbor. For weeks, there have been assertions that the troubled East German economy could soon collapse. East Germany has been hurt by the exodus of about 2,000 emigrants a day this year, joining the more than 340,000 who left last year. Many of them are young, skilled workers. In the financial capital of Frankfurt, West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann criticized East German Premier Hans Modrow's rejection of quick introduction of the West German mark in East Germany. ``Heading back home with the West German mark in your luggage is one of the greatest gifts there is,'' Haussmann said, referring to Modrow's trip to Bonn earlier in the week. ``A free market-oriented country like Hungary would know how to appreciate such an offer,'' Haussmann added. East Germans have said they realize that unification is inevitable, and they have been making plans to join the two countries and the city of Berlin. That includes East German plans to tear down a 1.2-mile stretch of the Berlin Wall between the Reichstag, the former Parliament building, and the famous Checkpoint Charlie crossing. The West Berlin city government said the East Germans will put up a 5-foot fence along most of the stretch, but leave open a 200-yard section near the Brandenburg Gate. The work is to start on Monday. East Germany's Communist leaders began opening the wall last Nov. 9 in response to the exodus of East Germans and the growing street rallies demanding democratic reforms. A group of about 1,000 West Germans held their own street rally in Frankfurt Saturday and clashed with police in a demonstation against an extreme rightist party. Several police officers and 27 demonstrators were injured in the clashes. Police said the demonstrators threw rocks, bottles and fireworks. The protesters demanded that the ultra-rightist National Democratic Party be outlawed.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Boots Ex-Leaders In Pre-Election Housecleaning
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party on Saturday expelled former President Gustav Husak, former Premier Lubomir Strougal and other members it said had given communism a bad name. The action came four months before the party, which in December gave up its monopoly on power, is to compete in free elections. In addition to Husak and Strougal, 18 other former officials were expelled, including five who were on the party's ruling Politburo until recently. ``With their activity, they contributed to a situation where the ideas of socialism are quite discredited in a considerable part of the population,'' said a party announcement quoted by the government news agency CTK. The expulsions were proposed by a commission looking into the political responsibility of former senior party officials ``for the crisis development'' in the past. They were announced following a party Central Committee meeting chaired by current party chief Ladislav Adamec. Adamec told the session that ``20 to 30 percent'' of the party's 1.7 million members had left its ranks since Nov. 17, 1989, the start of the peaceful revolution that removed the Communists from power. The Communist Party lost its control of the goverment and its majority in Parliament following the revolution. It also has lost credibility and prestige among the people and is expected to face a tough campaign in free elections tentatively scheduled for June 8. Husak became party chief in 1969 following the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in August 1968. He was replaced as head of the party by Milos Jakes in December 1987 but continued as president of Czechoslovakia, a post he lost during the revolution to playwright Vaclav Havel, once the nation's leading dissident. Strougal resigned as premier on Oct. 11, 1988, following party criticism of his work. The party suspended the memberships of Husak, Strougal and 30 other former party officials in December.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Found Alive After Avalanche Buries Her for Two Hours
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ester is cq in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old girl who was caught in an avalanche Saturday was found alive after being buried under three feet of snow for nearly two hours, authorities said. Carrie Hamilton, a drill team member from Mater Dei High School in Santa Ana, was treated for minor frostbite to her toes, said sheriff's Deputy Ronald Card. ``She's a lucky girl,'' he said. Miss Hamilton was among 98 people on an excursion to the Ester Christian Conference Center in the Angeles National Forest, 45 miles northeast of Los Angeles, said Mike Corrigan, leader of the outing. The avalanche apparently was touched off by 10 students who hiked without permission up a hill covered in 1{ feet of snow, said Corrigan. Miss Hamilton, who was at the bottom of the hill, was buried, but managed to clear a small breathing space in the snow. The other hikers were tossed around by the snow, but were unhurt, said Card. She was rescued by members of the National Ski Patrol and a sheriff's search team.

DOC.HEAD: First Test Launch for Sea Lance Anti-Sub Missile
DOC.TEXT: A Sea Lance anti-submarine missile was successfully launched for the first time in a test Saturday at the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico, Boeing Aerospace & Electronics announced. Boeing is testing the missile although the Navy has cancelled its $380 million contract the Sea Lance. The 20-foot-long missile was launched from a ground pad and made a long-range flight to its target, the company said in a news release. Boeing spokesman Milt Furness said Boeing was required to build and test the two missiles under its contract with the Naval Sea Systems Command, which expires in September. Before money for the missile was eliminated from the 1991 defense budget, Boeing was to develop and build 50 missiles for testing. Sea Lance is designed to be launched from either submarines or ships. After flying to the vicinity of an enemy submarine, the missile would release a torpedo which would float by parachute to the ocean's surface and then hunt down the sub.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Raid Village, Arrest 100
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD that 20 Palestinians were arrested for not paying taxes, SUB 10th graf pvs; pickup 11th graf pvs, `It quoted...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers backed by helicopters raided a West Bank village and tracked down Palestinian fugitives in nearby caves, arresting more than 100 suspected uprising activists, the army and state radio said Saturday. In the occupied Gaza Strip, a 22-year-old Palestinian woman was stabbed and beaten to death Saturday morning by fellow Palestinians who accused her of helping Israeli authorities, Arab reports said. The woman, Ishanhaz Timraz, was murdered on the main street in the Gaza town of Rafah when she went to a U.N. relief office to get food supplies, Palestinian journalists and hospital officials said. The military command confirmed the death and said it was under investigation. The killing brought to 186 the number of Arabs slain by fellow Palestinians as suspected pro-Israeli collaborators in the 26-month uprising against Israeli rule in Gaza and the West Bank. At least 656 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli troops or civilians, and 43 Israelis have died. Also in Gaza, Israeli troops shot and wounded at least six Palestinians in a number of stone-throwing clashes, Arab hospital officials said. The army said it knew of three Palestinians who suffered light injuries. The military command said soldiers raided the village of Yamun in the northern part of the occupied West Bank over the weekend. It did not say when exactly the raid took place. The soldiers, backed by air force helicopters, arrested some 90 Palestinians suspected of guerrilla activities and participation in violent protests, the army said. It said instigative material and weapons such as axes, knives and sticks were found in the village. Israel radio said some Palestinians were captured in caves near the village, where they had fled. The radio said another 20 Palestinians were arrested for not paying taxes, a major uprising protest tactic. It quoted an unidentified army commander of the area as saying no shots were fired during the operation. In another development, Israeli authorities expelled from the country a Yugoslav woman suspected of spying for the PLO, the radio reported. Patricia Kansevitz, 26, was sent to Zagreb, Yugoslavia on Friday. Kansevitz was arrested by Israeli security officials on Jan. 7 along with another Yugoslav woman, Victoria David, 34. David, a convert to Judaism who immigrated to Israel in 1987, was charged on Jan. 28 with contact with a foreign agent, membership in an illegal organization and passing information to the enemy. The charge sheet alleged that she took photographs of military installations and strategic sites. According to the charge sheet, David went by the code name of ``Halila'' and was recruited in Yugoslavia into Fatah, the Palestine Liberation Organization's mainstream branch headed by Yasser Arafat. Kansevitz reportedly acted as a courier who transferred the information to the PLO. The case was under a court-imposed news blackout lifted on Jan. 23 when the Hebrew daily Haaretz published the story on its front page.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The metal rings that bulls wear in their noses have taken on new appeal for humans. Collectors and decorators now covet the rings, said Sandi Mauldin, owner of the Antique Corner in this central Illinois town. ``It's one of the things we sell anytime we can get one,'' she said. The nose rings are brass, bronze or stainless steel, giving them lasting value. Usually 2 to 3 inches in diamater, they are inserted in the flesh between the nostrils when the bull is about 1 year old. Cattle owners have long used the rings in the sensitive noses to control ornery bulls. ``About the only one who ever removes a ring from a bull is the butcher, my farmer friend says,'' said Mauldin in a recent interview. She has bought the rings at auctions for $2 or so. The rings sell at her shop for as much as $5. ``I've found them in a box of tools at auctions, and I've had people bring them in, wondering if I had a use for the rings,'' she said. ``I want those that are used. I wouldn't have any use for a new one.'' People who decorate with country items use the bull rings as wall decorations, according to Mauldin. ``The pure country enthusiast would not polish the ring. They don't want it to shine or look new,'' she said. Nostalgia also is a selling point, especially for customers who grew up on farms. ``They exclaim, `I know what this is!','' Mauldin said.

Elvis Presley impersonator Don Wright is in the spotlight of a lawsuit. The 43-year-old Wright of Akron appeared in Cuyahoga County court, dressed in black, his shirt opened nearly to his waist, and his black hair swept back in the best Elvis style. Speaking in an Elvis sound-alike voice, Wright testified at a hearing Friday. At issue: whether Wright copied his program, in which he invites bar patrons to take the stage and sing to professionally recorded music, from a former employer. Judge Richard J. McMonagle refused to issue a temporary restraining order to stop Wright from conducting the shows. He scheduled a hearing on the case in about two weeks. ``We're not telling him he can't be Elvis,'' said lawyer Thomas S. Hudson, representing Center Stage Entertainment of Parma Heights, which brought the action against Wright. ``The only person who has a claim against that would be Elvis, and I don't know if he's in the building,'' McMonagle said. Hudson said Wright was hired by Center Stage as the host of audience participation programs. The plaintiff said Wright engaged in unfair competition by continuing to stage the programs under the name ``Stars of the Bars.'' Company owners said he used similar advertising and the identical musical library, which the company says he copied. Wright's lawyer, Teddy Sliwinski, said his client helped create the bar concept.

DOC.HEAD: Government Appoints Defense Minister Backed By Officers
DOC.TEXT: The interim government on Saturday named a defense minister backed by reformist officers, who demanded the resignation of the previous chief for failing to purge commanders from the Ceausescu regime. Lt. Gen. Victor Anastase Stanculescu, who was the interim government's economic minister, was the choice of hundreds of army and air force officers who had demonstrated since Monday in front of government headquarters. Former Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru handed in his letter of resignation Friday morning, said government spokesman Dan Radulescu. He did not disclose the contents of the letter, but said ``Militaru clearly realized he had to step aside, when faced with such massive opposition.'' Saturday afternoon, the army's general staff discussed the events of the past week and the internal reorganization demanded by the officers. The officers criticized Militaru for not replacing many top officers after December's revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Stanculescu, who had been a first deputy defense minister under Ceausescu, told reporters he agreed with the purge. ``The Securitate as a body no longer exists,'' he said, referring to the disbanded secret police. ``But there needs to be an investigation and punishment of those who were compromised (in the army).'' At Stanculescu's installation ceremony, interim President Ion Iliescu said Stanculescu was ``professionally and intellectually qualified'' to ``lead the process of ... improving the army on all levels.'' Iliescu told about 200 military officers assembled in the hall of the Grand National Assembly that Militaru ``did not succeed in establishing a real communication with the army's command, aggravating the situation in the army to a point at which it became a source of tension for all of society.'' Stanculescu promised to ``collaborate with all the army's commanders.'' ``We will present our conclusions in consensus,'' he said. The officers present responded with loud applause. On Thursday night, state-run television broadcast a frank but edited tape of talks between Deputy Prime Minister Gelu Voican Voiculescu and 58 officers from 38 units who presented a list of 13 demands including Militaru's resignation. The 21-member Executive Bureau of the ruling Council of National Unity Friday approved the creation of a commission to investigate all the officers' demands and expressed hope that the measures taken by the government would calm the situation in the country. But Saturday afternoon, about 200 civilians demonstrated outside government headquarters against Iliescu. Demonstrators claimed that he ``controls three-quarters of the Council of National Unity,'' which is ruling the nation until elections scheduled for May 20. Iliescu's National Salvation Front led the country for six weeks after the revolution and is now one of 37 parties that will compete in the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Blankets Much of Nation; Rain Remains in South
DOC.TEXT: Snow blanketed much of the nation from New England to the Pacific Northwest on Saturday, and rain continued to pose a threat in the West and South where torrents had caused flooding. Snow was scattered in northern New England, New York state, northern and western Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Michigan, Montana, western Wyoming, northern and western Utah, eastern Nevada, and the mountains of northern California, Oregon and Washington. Rain fell in the lower elevations of western California, and from southeast Louisiana across northern Florida and the Texas Gulf Coast. A winter storm warning remained in effect for interior parts of western Washington state, where up to 12 inches of snow fell between Whidbey Island and Olympia. Strong winds brought the wind chills to near zero in many locations. Rain continued in Los Angeles and Orange counties. Wind advisories were posted in southern Nevada and the deserts of Southern California, while a winter storm watch was posted for Saturday night for parts of Utah. Advisories for blowing and drifting snow were posted in much of Minnesota, eastern North Dakota, and across South Dakota except the state's extreme eastern and western parts. Winds gusting to 40 and 45 mph moved snow around north-central Nebraska and caused hazardous driving conditions. Yellowstone Park in Wyoming had as much as 3 inches of snow overnight, and there were greater amounts of snow in the higher mountains nearby. Gusts reached about 50 mph near Casper Mountain. In Colorado, winds gusted to more than 50 mph at Elbert, and to near 80 mph at Telluride ski resort. Ski lifts at Telluride and Snowmass ski resorts were closed by the winds. Duluth, Minn., broke its low temperature record for the date, plummeting 27 degrees below zero. The previous record: 21 degrees below zero, set in 1958. The normal low temperature for the date in Duluth is 3 degrees. The nation's low Saturday morning was 28 degrees below zero at Hibbing, Minn. The nation's temperatures at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 7 degrees below zero at Cutbank, Mont., to 84 degrees in Bartow, Fort Myers and Orlando, all in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: 40th Chief Executive Spends President's Day Weekend In Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 7th graf pvs, `Testimony is...Beckler,' to UPDATE with comment from Reagan spokesman. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Reagan was allowed...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: LOS ANGELES _ (AP) _ Former President Reagan spent a second day in court Saturday, testifying about the Iran-Contra affair that mired the final two years of his presidency. Reagan, flanked by Secret Service agents, emerged from a federal courtroom at 2:10 p.m. and headed down a back stairwell after completing approximately eight hours of videotaped testimony over two days. Reagan, who had entered the downtown federal courthouse smiling and waving earlier in the day, smiled broadly as his limousine pulled out of the courthouse parking garage. As he has before, Reagan ignored reporters' questions. Reagan testified before U.S. District Judge Harold Greene in connection with the trial of his former national security adviser, John Poindexter. Poindexter is accused of concealing his former aide Oliver North's assistance to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels and lying about a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Poindexter declined comment as he climbed into a taxi after the session, but answered ``no'' when asked if he would be returning to the courthouse for more testimony. ``Testimony is finished. That's all I can tell you,'' said his lawyer, Richard Beckler. Later, Reagan's spokesman, Mark Weinberg, issued a news release saying the former president had cooperated and hadn't asserted executive privilege. ``Since he first learned of the Iran-Contra matter and immediately told the American people about it, President Reagan has cooperated fully with all of the attendant investigative and judicial proceedings,'' the statement read. ``President Reagan testified fully and completely in response to questions posed by counsel for Adm. Poindexter and the Iran-Contra independent counsel. President Reagan agreed to the videotaped deposition and did not assert executive privilege,'' the statement concluded. Reagan was allowed to give his videotaped depositions at a courtroom near his Bel-Air area home, rather than in Washington, where the proceedings against Poindexter are to begin March 5. Security was especially rigorous for the extraordinary two-day session. Federal marshals and Secret Service agents kept the media some 40 feet away from Reagan as he entered and left the courtroom Friday. Reporters were allowed only a bit closer Saturday. Although the deposition-taking was closed to the public, Greene said the videotapes would be released within a few days after editing of issues deemed to involve national security. Over the two days, the former president answered 154 questions about his role in the Iran-Contra affair, the failed arms-for-hostages deal during Reagan's second term. The questions were drawn from 183 submitted to the court by Beckler, who was allowed follow-up questions if necessary. However, the judge prohibited Poindexter's attorney from raising additional questions on new subjects. ``I think he was very fair in his testimony,'' Beckler said. Poindexter sought the testimony to bolster his contention that his secret activities had been authorized by Reagan. Although the judge hasn't made the specific questions public, he said they fell into several broad categories, such as the extent of Reagan's knowledge of the shipment of missiles to Iran and Reagan's understanding of legislation that temporarily barred U.S. aid to the Contras. Reagan said early in 1987 that he hadn't known about ``secret bank accounts and diverted funds,'' two products of the Iran-Contra affair that he said he found ``personally distasteful.'' He told the Tower Commission, which was appointed to investigate the affair, he didn't know National Security Council staffers were assisting the Contras. Poindexter later told Congress he believed Reagan understood that ``Col. North was instrumental in keeping the Contras supported without maybe understanding the details of exactly what he was doing.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Group Asks U.S. Government to Protect Crane Habitat
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet environmental group has asked the U.S. government to protect the habitat for sandhill cranes when it considers relicensing the Kingsley Dam on Nebraska's Platte River. Alexander Mischenko, deputy chairman of the Soviet Association for Ecology and Peace, said in a letter to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission that the Platte River habitat is a primary staging area for the cranes. About 10 percent of them nest in Siberia following their spring migration from the United States. The Soviet made their appeal at the urging of the U.S. chapter of Friends of the Earth. Brent Blackwelder, vice president for policy for Friends of the Earth, called the Soviet move unprecedented and a sign of the growing recognition that environmental issues often transcend political boundaries. U.S. environmental groups have urged Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to place conditions on the long-term licenses sought by Central Nebraska Public Power and Irrigation District and the Nebraska Public Power District to operate the dam, two other power plants and a steam plant. Applications for those licenses will be submitted May 5. The environmentalists say the dam has held back too much water from the Platte River, threatening the habitat of 300 species of migratory birds, including six endangered species, and the sandhill cranes. The long-term licenses for the districts expired in 1987 and they have operated on annual licenses since then. On Wednesday, the federal commission placed conditions on Nebraska Public Power District's interim license concerning habitat development and flows in the Platte River. ``At first I thought when I heard it (Soviet intervention in the relicensing) that it was a joke,'' said Frank Dragoun, manager of the power and irrigation district. He said that although sandhill cranes aren't hunted in Nebraska, they are hunted legally in eight or nine other states, with 14,000 to 16,000 killed annually. Power district spokesman Wayne Jacobsen said the Soviets's intervention in the relicensing issue ``looks like it might make an interesting legal problem for somebody to straighten out.'' Ken Strom, manager of the National Audubon Society's sanctuary along the Platte River between Kearney and Gibbon, said the international interest in the river shouldn't come as a surprise. ``We and anyone involved in habitat on the river realize it's not just a Nebraska resource, but a national and international resource,'' he said. Sandhill and whooping cranes that rest and feed along the river each spring often begin their migratory flights in South America and Mexico, Strom said, and continue north to Canada and Siberia. More than 500,000 cranes stop along the shallow river in Nebraska each spring to feed and gain strength for the flight north. The cranes roost along the river's sandbars to keep safe from predators.

DOC.HEAD: Fire At Tire Dump Near Lake Erie Burns For Sixth Day
DOC.TEXT: A blaze at a huge tire dump near Lake Erie defied firefighters for a sixth day Saturday, spewing smoke that forced 600 nearby residents from their homes. The fire at Tyre King Recycling, which contains between 12 million and 14 million tires, broke out Monday and investigators have blamed arson. Ontario officials said there was no health hazard outside the 2{-mile evacuation area surrounding the blaze, 12 miles north of Lake Erie and 60 miles north of Erie, Ohio, which lies across the lake. About 40 firefighters were working to bring the blaze under control. Some environmental experts say it could burn for months because of the number of tires. Environment Minister Jim Bradley said Friday that Ontario taxpayers may end up paying an estimated $1 million to clean up after the fire if the owner is unable to pay. The Environment Ministry declared Tyre King, Ontario's largest tire dump, an illegal waste site in December 1985. Since then the owner, Edward Straza, has not applied for a certificate of approval to operate the dump, according to a news report. Four thousand people, including many of Hagersville's 2,500 residents, were urged to leave their homes but records showed only about 600 had left. Preliminary air samples showed levels of cancer-causing benzenes but not at levels much higher than in major urban areas, chemist Akos Szakolcai of the Environment Ministry said Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Train Derailment, Explosion Forces Evacuation In Small Texas Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, `The train...possibility,' to UPDATE with decision to let fire burn itself out, drug tests for train crew. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Curtis Rash...
DOC.TEXT: A freight train derailed near this small town Saturday morning, sparking a huge fireball and forcing the evacuation of several families living nearby, authorities said. Nobody was reported injured in the accident shortly before 8:30 a.m., said Mike Cox, spokesman for the state Department of Public Safety. He said the derailment of 24 cars caused ``quite an explosion.'' The cause wasn't immediately known. The train was reported carrying liquid propane and other hazardous materials, Cox said. He said there was a possibility some of the material would leak into a creek, but other authorities discounted the possibility. Fearing further explosions, firefighters decided ot allow the fire to burn itself out. Doug Fogg, Corsicana Police Department's assistant fire chief, said it was common practice to allow derailment fires to extinguish themselves. The three crewmembers, who weren't identified, were given drug tests, a standard procedure following train accidents. Curtis Rash, mayor of this town of 200 about 45 miles south of Dallas, said he was about two miles away when the blast occurred. ``It looked like napalm going off,'' he said. ``It was a ball of fire about 100 feet in diameter. It rose up in the air about 100 feet or so.'' The wreckage continued burning past noon, and huge black plumes of smoke could be seen for 15 miles. Reporters and other non-residents were being kept out of the area. The 44-car train, bound for Houston from Tulsa, Okla., lost its last 24 cars on a curve, said John Grundmann, superintendent of operations for Fort Worth-based Burlington Northern, which owns the train. A commercial clean-up team from nearby Corsicana arrived shortly before noon to begin removing the wreckage. The Texas Railroad Commission and state Water Commission dispatched investigators to the derailment. Fear of more explosions kept five public safety department teams from approaching the site and forced evacuations of fewer than a dozen families in a rural section of Emhouse. The evacuation area was scaled back later in the day and all but three or four families were allowed to return. Cox said the authorities at the site believed some of the hazardous liquids were leaking into Chambers Creek, which feeds feeds Lake Corsicana and the Richland Creek Reservoir, which supplies water to many Navarro County residents. But Rash said the creek is about 400 yards from the accident scene, and said he doesn't believe the leaking materials would be able to reach the water. And Charles Gazda, chief of the emergency branch of the Environmental Protection Agency in Dallas, said as far as he knew nothing spilled in the creek that would cause any significant problem. The mayor said that despite the mammoth fireball, the explosion wasn't extraordinarily loud. ``When we went around to evacuate those who lived nearest there, thy were still sleeping,'' he said. ``They didn't even wake up.'' The nearest residents were about a quarter-mile from the derailment scene.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Says He Tried To Negotiate With Noriega To Step Down
DOC.TEXT: Former President Carter revealed Saturday that he tried to persuade Panamanian ruler Manuel Noriega to step down after that country's May presidential election, which was widely considered fraudulent. Carter, who served as an unofficial election observer, tried to negotiate with Noriega on May 8, a day after the election, said Robert Pastor, who was Carter's national security adviser on Latin America from 1977 to 1981. ``I negotiated with Noriega through an intermediary all through that day, and I tried to convince him (Noriega) could be a hero, that all of his problems would be over,'' Carter told the Peace Prize Forum at Augsburg College. ``I had the authority _ this is the first time I've ever said this publicly _ to tell Noriega, `You can stay on as commander in chief until September (1989), when the new president takes over. You will not be extradited to the United States. You can stay in Panama if you wish, after you step down as commander in chief.''' Carter recalled. ``I think he considered this very carefully. About 2 o'clock Monday afternoon (May 8), it became apparent to me that Noriega decided to steal the election. He refused to communicate with me any more,'' Carter said. Carter left Saturday's conference, which was attended by an estimated 3,400 college students and others, without saying who had given him the authority to negotiate with Noriega. Noriega, who held ultimate power in Panama as military commander, is accused of trying to steal the election for his hand-picked candidate. International observers said the opposition really won by a 3-1 margin, but Noriega annulled the results. Noriega surrendered to the United States after this country's invasion of Panama last year and is in custody in Miami awaiting trial on drug-trafficking charges. Pastor, reached Saturday night at his home in Georgia, declined to say who gave Carter permission to negotiate with Noriega. ``I think I would like to leave it as saying he consulted with senior levels of the U.S. government,'' said Pastor, an Emory University professor and director of the Latin American program at the Carter Center at Emory. Through tabulations made by the Roman Catholic Church, Pastor said he and Carter determined early the day after the election that the opposition had beaten Noriega's candidate. He and Carter tried to contact several senior military officials and subsequently Noriega to arrange a meeting, Pastor said. In the meantime, Carter met with the opposition leadership, current Panamanian President Guillermo Endara and vice presidents Ricardo Arias and Guillermo Ford. ``They encouraged Carter to get directly in touch with Noriega to try to arrange a peaceful transition,'' Pastor said. ``We later learned that Noriega had gotten the message and was just too afraid to meet with Carter.'' After Noriega failed to respond, Carter's staff informed him they would give him an hour to do so before Carter would hold a 7 p.m. news conference to denounce the election as a fraud, Pastor said.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Experiment Will Deny Job Training for Poor, Paper Reports
DOC.TEXT: A federal welfare experiment would deny some job training opportunities to about 10,000 poor people in 10 states to see how well they do without them, a newspaper reported Saturday. Texas welfare officials have questioned the ethics of the experiment and refused to participate, according to The Dallas Morning News. The experiment is intended to evaluate the Job Opportunities and Basic Skill training program, which requires some people on welfare to apply either for education or training programs or lose benefits. The experiment would reject some people who normally would have received training _ forming a control group _ and compare their experience over several years with those who participate in the program. Government officials say this kind of experiment is the only way to determine if the training programs will work _ even if it means some people are denied job training opportunities. Federal officials hope to have 10 states participate in the experiment. Arkansas, California and Oklahoma have expressed an interest. But some state officials, including those in Texas, are uncomfortable with the ethical dilemma of randomly forcing some people out of potentially helpful programs in the name of science, the paper said. ``We told them we would not take part,'' said Claudia Langguth, deputy commissioner for the client self-support services division of the Texas Department of Human Services. ``My staff told me it would require a very large control group of several thousand people.'' Federal officials have focused new attention to the ethics of welfare experiments. On Feb. 12, U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan killed a federal study that would have denied about 800 Texans access to extended medical coverage and child care. Officials also told Ohio that a similar study of new Medicaid benefits in that state would likely be canceled, the paper said. Martin Gerry, assistant secretary for planning and evaluation for HHS, said the although the value of Medicaid and child care programs are generally accepted, the benefits of JOBS programs are still being weighed. Therefore the need for a precise experiment is greater, he said. ``I don't see here, yet, any real disadvantage to the person who is not picked'' to go into JOBS, Gerry said. JOBS was created by the Family Support Act of 1988. It requires states to have specific educational and job training programs for people who are, or are likely to become, long-term welfare recipients. The law set aside $500,000 a year to pay for control-based experiments to evaluate the program. In states included in the experiment, a small percentage of those who meet the guidelines for inclusion into JOBS will be randomly rejected and placed in a control group. Their ability to find work will be compared to those in the JOBS program. The experiment's results will be used to adjust the program, federal officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Six Alabama Counties Approved for Federal Disaster Aid
DOC.TEXT: President Bush approved federal disaster aid Saturday for six central Alabama counties hit in recent days by severe weather that has led to extensive flooding. The declaration opens the way for low-cost loans, temporary housing, help for cities to repair bridges and other public structures and a variety of other help for individuals and businesses. Counties eligible for federal relief are Bibb, Greene, Russell, Shelby, Talladega and Tuscaloosa. The federal relief operations are coordinated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, or FEMA.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Calls Party Congress Meeting For Next Year; Hints at Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with background on Cuban-Soviet ties; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Cuba's hard-line Communist Party called for a party congress next year, the official Cuban news agency said Saturday in a dispatch that hinted the party will consider economic and political reforms. Cuba's Fidel Castro has remained one of the Communist world's staunchest Stalinist holdouts and has criticized the democratic reforms that have swept out Old Guard Communist leaders in Eastern Europe over the past year. While Saturday's Prensa Latina dispatch was the first indication that Cuba is willing to consider change, the report said the Communists also reaffirmed ``revolutionary principles'' and cited a need to strengthen Cuba's defense. The dispatch came less than a month after Castro declared on Jan. 28 that Cuba would stick to orthodox Communism even if its longtime ally, the Soviet Union, cut off $5 billion a year in aid. He also said he would brook no political liberalizations and rejected a petition for recognition by an opposition party based in Miami. The U.S. State Department in Washington had no independent knowledge of Saturday's report and could not comment, said an official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Communist Party Central Committee said Friday that on March 15 it would announce the date of next year's party congress, Prensa Latina reported in the dispatch, monitored in Mexico City. ``The members of the high body studied an analysis made by the political bureau about fundamental problems that should be tackled by the fourth party congress, that need to be debated and adopted,'' Prensa Latina said, quoting Cuba's official Communist Party daily Granma. ``At Friday's meeting, the committee promised to improve results in the process of correcting the sphere of economic and social development, such as in the political conscience of the country,'' it said. The news agency said the Central Committee also reaffirmed its support for Castro, who came to power in 1959. ``There is agreement that conditions have matured enough to tackle in practical and concrete terms as to perfect the political system in the country,'' Prensa Latina said. Despite indicating a willingness to consider reforms, the dispatch said the Cuban government remains committed to its fundamental policies. ``Analyzing these realities in light of the situation of socialism on the world level, the meeting concluded that if Cuba has been able to maintain itself despite certain errors, it was due to our sticking to a revolutionary policy,'' Prensa Latina said. ``It should remain clear that this critical analysis will not question Cuba's principles and will discuss how to make more perfect a united Leninist party based on democratic centralism,'' it said. Prensa Latina apparently referred to the U.S. invasion of Panama in December as a reason to maintain its defenses. ``Facing the crisis of socialism and the aggressive euphoria of American imperialism, we need to continue strengthening our defenses and preparing the people to resist and conquer any aggression. ``It is necessary to analyze the immediate and long-term goals of the revolution. We will follow the light of our principles without ever responding to external pressures,'' the dispatch said. Cuba is heavily dependent on Soviet economic aid and there have been signs the assistance is being pared. U.S. sources last year said there had been substantial reductions in Soviet aid to Cuba as evidenced in the marked decline in the purchase of sugar, which the Soviet Union buys from Cuba at prices substantially higher than world market levels as a form of subsidy. During a visit to Havana in April, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made no move to ease Cuba's debt burden, which last year was estimated at between $8 billion and $12 billion. Cuba's debt to Western nations was believed to be about $6 billion. Castro in the past has expressed disapproval of Gorbachev's domestic reforms as leaning too much toward capitalism. ``The (Cuban) revolution will not back down one millimeter, not even if it is totally blockaded by the United States or if the Soviet Union totally cuts off its supplies,'' he said last month.

DOC.HEAD: Former Leader of Irish Labor Party
DOC.TEXT: Brendan Corish, former leader of the Irish Labor Party and deputy prime minister from 1973 to 1977, died Saturday in a nursing home in Wexford, his family said. He was 71. The cause of death was not disclosed. Corish was an old-fashioned Irish socialist and professional politician who in 1945 inherited the Wexford seat in the Dail, Ireland's parliament, from his father, Richard. He succeeded William Norton as Labor Party leader in 1960. In the 1973 general election, Labor sided with the right-wing Fine Gael party to form a coalition that narrowly defeated Fianna Fail, which had held power without a break since 1957. Liam Cosgrave, the Fine Gael leader, became prime minister and Corish was minister of health and social welfare. The coalition lasted four years and ended on a low note in 1977 when it was decisively defeated at the polls by Fianna Fail led by Jack Lynch, who became prime minister. Cosgrave and Corish both resigned their party leaderships. Fine Gael and Labor formed a coalition to govern again in 1981 after an inconclusive general election in which no party secured a majority. Corish subsequently resigned from politics. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis, and two children.

DOC.HEAD: Compensation For Relatives Of Civilians Killed During Anti-Rebel Attack
DOC.TEXT: The government on Saturday said it will compensate the families of four children and an adult who were killed last week by an army rocket during an attack on suspected rebel positions. ``The cause of death of the civilians was the explosion of a rocket launched by a helicopter,'' the Armed Forces Press Committee said in a statement. Air force planes and helicopters last Sunday bombed suspected leftist rebel positions in Chaltenango province, in northeastern El Salvador. Fifteen people were injured. The attack occurred in Corral de Piedra, about 50 miles northeast of San Salvador, the capital. It was the second time the government announced indemnities for civilian losses in the country's decade-old civil war. In a similar attack in 1985, the government paid civilians for their losses from an army bombing. The number of casualties in that incident was not reported.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Members Owe $1.59 Billion in Overdue Payments
DOC.TEXT: More than half the members of the United Nations owe $1.59 billion in back dues at a time when the world body faces mounting fiscal problems due to its growing peacemaking role, officials say. Of the total amount due by 81 countries, roughly $1.09 billion is for the regular budget and about $500 million for U.N. peacekeeping missions, according to a U.N. report released Friday. The United States owes the largest share, $772 million, the report said. The Soviet Union owes $229 million. The regular budget for the 159-member world body is for the U.N. headquarters in New York, Vienna and Geneva, and for smaller offices in more than 70 countries. A two-year budget of $1.98 billion has been approved for 1990-91, with about $935 million of that for this year. Member contributions for 1990 became overdue on Feb. 1. ``In light of all that the organization is being asked to do at the moment, I think it is high time that the U.N. be able to leave its financial worries behind,'' said U.N. spokesman Matthew Nerzig. In recent years the United Nations has heightened its involvement in mediating regional conflicts, clearing the way for an end to the Iran-Iraq war and overseeing the transition to independence in Namibia. The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council _ the United States, Soviet Union, France, Britain and China _ have recommended a major role in Cambodia peace efforts.

DOC.HEAD: 10 People, Four Companies Named in Obscenity Probe
DOC.TEXT: Obscenity charges were issued against a satellite adult-movie channel and three other companies, including GTE Corp., over broadcasts of what officials described as hard-core sex movies. Four companies and 10 people were indicted by a county grand jury over the movies, which authorities said were picked up on home satellite dishes and in some cases recorded and shared by teen-agers. Among those named in the 18-count indictment unsealed Friday were GTE Corp. of Stamford, Conn.; a subsidiary, GTE Spacenet Inc. of McLean, Va.; U.S. Satellite Inc. of Murray, Utah, and Home Dish Satellite Networks Inc. of New York City, also known as the Exxxtasy Channel. The names of the individuals charged were withheld because they hadn't been served with court papers, said Montgomery County District Attorney Jimmy Evans. The charges involve allegedly obscene videos with titles such as ``Hardcore Girlfriends'' and ``Fantasy Chamber'' that were beamed into Alabama on the American Exxxtasy Channel. Colette Connor, vice president of advertising and promotion for Home Dish Satellite Network, denied wrongdoing. ``The movies that we broadcast, as far as we know, have never been judged obscene,'' she said. Barbara Foelbar, manager of corporate communications for GTE Spacenet, said ``as a communications common carrier, regulated by the (Federal Communications Commission), we have no authority to censor what customers use our satellite to transmit.'' An attorney for U.S. Satellite Inc. said he hadn't seen the indictments and couldn't comment on them. An investigation of the transmissions began about a year ago after Evans' office received complaints from parents whose children were buying copies of adult movies at school. ``The movies had been taped by other students off satellite dish transmissions,'' he said. Gov. Guy Hunt and the governors of Utah, Virginia and New York will be asked to arrange extradition of those defendants to Alabama, the prosecutor said. Evans said that for $150, anyone with a satellite dish, code number and descrambler could subscribe to American Exxxstasy for six months. He said his investigators began taping the material and found it contained graphic sex scenes which he called ``hard-core obscenity'' and ``clearly a violation of the Anti-Obscenity Act.'' That law, approved by the Legislature in May, expanded the definition of obscene materials to include telephone and electronic communications. Evans said he sought federal cooperation in the prosecution on grounds the defendants may have violated federal obscenity statutes. The mother of a porn star who committed suicide in 1984 after two years of making movies came to Montgomery to testify before the grand jury. Karen Applegate of Burnsville, Minn., said some of the movies made by her daughter, Colleen, are still shown on the Exxxtasy Channel. ``The only reason I'm here is to get rid of (my daughter's) films and stop the men who use her,'' she said. ``Those men made money off her before her death, they don't have to after.'' The charges carry a maximum penalty of 36 years in prison and a $540,000 fine against each defendant. The state also could seize property and profits, which Evans said could amount to millions of dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Soccer Fans, Police Clash; Two Bombs Explode In Belfast
