DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf `It was...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with two bomb explosions in Belfast, two soldiers injured. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `Security forces...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival Protestant and Roman Catholic soccer fans rioted at a match Saturday, and police said they fired plastic bullets into the stands to stop the disturbance. Forty-eight police officers and 15 civilians were injured and one officer and one civilian hospitalized, police said. The violence spread from the stadium to surrounding streets, and fans hijacked buses and set them on fire, a statement from the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. In other incidents later, police said a bomb exploded near an army vehicle in southwest Belfast, slightly injuring two soldiers on patrol. A second bomb exploded 10 minutes later in a parking area at the Greenan Lodge Hotel in the west of the city after an anonymous warning that allowed police to evacuate the building in time. No injures were reported at the hotel. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for either blast. The violence at the stadium was the worst in years at a soccer game in Northern Ireland. Sports events are usually free of the fighting between Protestants and the Roman Catholic minority that has torn other areas of life in the British province. Security forces had feared trouble at the game, a first-round match in the Bass Irish Cup competition, so it was delayed 25 minutes until the spectators were seated. The police _ who said many fans ``were under the influence of drink'' _ had formed a barrier between supporters of the Linfield team, which has a tradition of having only Protestant players, and Donegal Celtic, a team based in a Catholic neighborhood of West Belfast. Police said one Linfield supporter got onto the field and attacked a Celtic player and ``serious public disorder'' continued in Donegal Celtic's area. Officers were pelted with bottles and stones and had to use riot shields to protect themselves, police said. The officers eventually charged fans in the Donegal Celtic area to keep from being overrun by the crowd and had to fire plastic bullets ``to repel the sustained attack,'' the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. Trouble flared again at half time and continued sporadically during the remainder of the match, which Linfield won, 2-1. After the game, ``as the Donegal Celtic supporters made their way home through west Belfast, they hijacked four buses and set them on fire,'' the police statement said. Officers fired more plastic bullets to disperse those crowds, it said. The statement also said a bomb had been discovered in an empty house ``convenient to where police would have been taking up duty to see these supporters through the area.'' It was being defused, and no one had claimed responsibility, police said. The soccer match had been drawn to be played at the Donegal Celtic ground in the heart of Catholic West Belfast. But the Irish Football Association, fearing trouble, switched it to Windsor Park, Northern Ireland's international soccer ground, which is also home to Linfield. Celtic failed in a High Court bid to have the match switched to a neutral spot.

DOC.HEAD: Reuters Plans to End News Pictures Agreement With UPI
DOC.TEXT: Reuters, which announced it will end its news picture agreement with United Press International, continued to supply photos on Saturday to UPI amid a public flap between the two news services. Under a 10-year agreement begun in January 1985, UPI has been supplying Reuters with news pictures from the United States while Reuters supplied UPI with news pictures from abroad. On Friday, Reuters abruptly stopped sending photos to UPI, saying it was dissatisfied with the quality of photographs supplied by UPI and intended to start its own U.S. photo coverage. It resumed sending photographs to UPI after UPI threatened a lawsuit. ``We told them they were way out of line through our attorneys,'' UPI Vice Chairman Joe Taussig said Friday. He added that Reuters offered to turn the service back on if UPI would agree not to sue for breach of contract. UPI made no agreement and is still considering legal action, Taussig said. Taussig said the original agreement calls for either service to give 10 days notice of intent to terminate. But on Saturday, Milt Capps, the senior vice president for corporate affairs at UPI, said: ``Earlier comments about the 10-day period may have been in error.'' He said UPI lawyers are reviewing the contract to determine if Reuters had violated it. UPI is considering restarting its own international photo coverage and also studying a photo exchange agreement with other foreign news service agencies, Capps said. Reuters said it restarted the service Friday night after a senior UPI official called and asked that the service be resumed temporarily. Capps said no senior UPI official had made such a request. Andrew M. Nibley, editor of Reuters America, said in a statement released early Saturday: ``At their request this evening, we agreed to temporarily continue providing them with non-U.S. pictures. However, we will no longer be using UPI pictures. ``We will be covering the United States with our own resources to ensure a quality service to our subscribers in the United States and abroad.'' The dispute between the two news services started Friday when Reuters issued a news release announcing it was ending its agreement with UPI and starting up its own news photo network in the United States. In addition, Reuters filed a lawsuit to recoup money it says it lost on the agreement. The company didn't say what those claims might total. ``It has not been an easy decision. It's essentially a quality issue. We do not want their pictures,'' said Robert A. Crooke, a spokesman for Reuters America. As to why Reuters was providing photographs to UPI, he said: ``This is simply giving them some continued international coverage for a limited amount of time.'' In a statement released Friday before the service was restored, UPI said the abrupt cancellation of the photo exchange ``was unjustified and without regard for the interest of both companies' subscribing newspapers.'' UPI Chairman Earl W. Brian said the news service ``is outraged at the sneak termination of the Reuters international picture service, for which there was no basis whatever.'' UPI is owned by Infotechnology Inc., a holding company with interests in scientific and information ventures, which completed acquisition of the company that controls the news service in March 1989 from Mexican publisher Mario Vazquez Rana. UPI lost $16 million in 1988 and $25 million in 1987. Reuters presently supplies news photographs directly to 20 United States newspapers and 500 newspapers around the world, Crooke said.

DOC.HEAD: AFL-CIO Leaders Attempt to Regain Lost Clout
DOC.TEXT: AFL-CIO leaders are using their annual winter trek to Florida as a strategy summit designed to help unions regain bargaining clout lost in the 1980s and to bolster the chances of labor-supported candidates and legislation heading into 1990 elections. Union chiefs gathering in Bal Harbour will try to capitalize on the unity and renewed fighting spirit many said has been felt following successful strikes in 1989 by Appalachia coal miners and telephone workers in the Northeast, where unions won on key bargaining points. ``It was one of the most traumatic decades for organized labor _ it was ushered in with union busting but ushered out by union building,'' said Jan Pierce, vice president of the Communications Workers of America in charge of the New York region. The Pittston coal strike served as a rallying point for organized labor. At one point before a tentative settlement was reached New Year's Eve, some 46,000 coal workers in 10 states walked off their jobs in sympathy strikes. ``There's a new spirit of solidarity. Unions are again living up to the credo that an injury to one is an injury to all,'' Pierce said. Also on this week's agenda for the AFL-CIO's Executive Council is the second meeting between the 33-member board and Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole; meetings with several prominent officials of the Democratic Party, one of labor's traditional allies; and domestic and international issues. Abortion is expected to dominate much of the behind-the-scenes maneuvering, though AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland has already said a vote on pro-choice resolutions will be skipped and instead a committee will study whether the 14.1 million member federation should take a stand. Recent Labor Department statistics show that union membership has remained fairly constant since 1985 at about 17 million, but the percentage of the workforce that is unionized has dropped to about 16 percent _ meaning that labor is not bringing in new members to match the rapid growth of the workforce. In 1985, for instance, 18 percent of the workforce belonged to unions. AFL-CIO spokesman Rex Hardesty said union officials realize that future organizing drives will have to center around issues such as health care that employers are reluctant to provide. ``We bottomed out in the 1980s, and it was just brutal. But we've gotten up off the floor,'' Hardesty said. Still, others noted that unions suffered their share of setbacks last year, such as the machinists' walkout at Eastern Airlines. The strike, which continues, was dealt a major blow last November when pilots and flight attendants ended sympathy strikes. Their defection followed President Bush's veto of legislation establishing a special congressional panel to propose a solution to the strike. ``A whole bunch of workers got kicked around a lot. We're not out of the woods yet ... in the face of all the monkey wrenches that can be thrown at us, we still have a rotten situation,'' said Paul Booth, organizing director for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. Booth and others contend the Bush administration is following former President Reagan's anti-union lead by allowing employers to intimidate workers who try to organize. Many labor leaders felt Reagan, who fired striking air traffic controllers in 1981 and effectively killed their union, was the worst president of the century for organized labor. Union officials will continue efforts for a warmer relationship with the Bush administration as Mrs. Dole visits with council members Tuesday. Also on labor leaders' mind this week will be the upcoming 1990 elections as a steady stream of political heavyweights make appearances. Democratic National Committee Chairman Ronald Brown, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt of Missouri, the chairmen of the House and Senate Democratic election committees and two senators who face tough re-election bids _ Paul Simon of Illinois and Tom Harkin of Iowa _ are among those who will meet with union officials. Gephardt will discuss major bills before Congress this year that labor is interested in, such as legislation involving health care and child care and the proposed Social Security payroll tax cut. Brown and DNC staff will be discussing the party's campaign for statehouse seats around the nation, since control of state legislatures will dictate which party controls congressional redistricting. Labor is providing much of the funding for the party's redistricting effort and also is involved in identifying potential candidates for targeted state races.

DOC.HEAD: Report: IRS Investigating if Foreign Companies Underpaying Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Federal tax officials are using new auditing powers to investigate the American subsidiaries of Japanese companies they suspect have underpaid corporate income taxes by billions of dollars, according to a published report. The New York Times reported in its Sunday editions that while foreign-owned assets in the United States more than tripled in 10 years to $1.8 billion and gross income of foreign firms here more than doubled, the amount of taxes paid didn't change much. Data compiled by the Internal Revenue Service indicates that of 36,000 foreign-owned companies, more than half didn't report any reported taxable income. Tax officials say subsidiaries underestimate their earnings to reduce their tax liability by manipulating transactions with parent companies, the Times said. But the government, often thwarted in its efforts to review the records of such companies, is now armed with a new law that gives the IRS broad authority to assess taxes on foreign-owned firms that fail to promptly comply for requests for records or testimony. ``We don't target a particular country for enforcement,'' Charles S. Triplett, deputy associate chief counsel of the tax agency told the Times. ``Nonetheless, it's pretty clear that the Japanese do a lot of business here and have many U.S. subsidiaries acting as distributors of manufactured goods.'' The Japan Tax Association said the IRS was partly to blame because it had failed to establish ``concrete guidelines'' for determining the right price of transactions between branches of a multi-national company. Tadashi Iwashita, a financial counselor at the Japanese Embassy in Washington, D.C., said Japanese firms try to comply with U.S. tax laws. One unidentified IRS official told the Times the agency suspects that underpayments amount to at least $12 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents Line Up Against Daley's Airport Proposal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4, `The plan...Calumet Airport,' to CLARIFY that homes and businesses to be demolished are spread through several neighborhoods. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `We have all...
DOC.TEXT: Residents lined up against Mayor Richard M. Daley's plan to build a third airport in Chicago, voicing concern that their neighborhoods would be eliminated by his proposal. ``Isn't there some other place he could put this thing, some other place than this town?'' resident Mary Ann Kolojay asked. The plan would virtually obliterate her Hegewisch neighborhood on Chicago's far southeast side. Hegewisch _ an old steel mill neighborhood separated from the city by stretches of landfills, factories and vacant lots _ is one of two neighborhoods and two suburbs where 6,700 homes and 47 businesses would be demolished to make way for the proposed Lake Calumet Airport. ``We have all this land everywhere and they still have to flatten this town,'' Kolojay said, while working a cash register at a local food store. ``Why not Bridgeport?'' said resident Mike Hennessy, referring to Daley's neighborhood. Daley said the $4.9 billion project would rejuvenate an area impoverished over the last decade by the decline of the mills and other industry. He said the airport would generate 200,000 jobs and $13.7 billion in annual revenue. The airport, scheduled to open in 2010, would be 20 percent larger than O'Hare International Airport on the city's far northwest side and 15 times the size of Midway Airport, southwest of Chicago. O'Hare has been criticized by federal officials as being overcrowded and the cause of national travel delays. The question of a third airport has been under debate for months and four other sites have been proposed. Federal Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner and Illinois Gov. James R. Thompson said that Daley's proposal, unveiled Thursday, will be considered with the others. ``We are a long way from having a third airport,'' said Gregory Baise, chairman of a three-state committee conducting a $6 million, study to pick a rural south suburban site. ``I would view (Daley's) plan very skeptically.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS first item to UPDATE with Trump criticizing media coverage of marital troubles.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK _ Billionaire Donald Trump says the news media in New York has treated him unfairly and inaccurately reported his separation from his wife, Ivana, according to a published report. The Daily News in New York reported in its Sunday editions that Trump is unhappy with extensive coverage of his marital problems in New York's tabloid papers and local television stations. ``I think the news media should be ashamed of itself,'' Trump told the News in a telephone interview. ``I'm sure that it sells, and people don't care for the truth. ``They have me with women I never even met before. They have me with women I shook hands with. On Saturday, the Daily News quoted an anonymous source as saying Trump was upset by coverage of the split and was considering ``dropping the whole thing.'' Trump lawyers Jay Goldberg and Stanford Lotwin couldn't be reached Saturday, but they told the Daily News they knew nothing about any possible reconciliation. No legal action has yet been taken by either Trump. Mrs. Trump was in seclusion Friday at the couple's Greenwich, Conn., home with the couple's three children, New York Newsday reported Saturday. On Saturday, according to the Daily News, they were in Florida. Mrs. Trump met with Cardinal John O'Connor Friday in his office. ``It was a private meeting,'' said archdiocesan spokesman Joe Zwilling, who declined to say what was discussed. Mrs. Trump's father, Milos Zelnicek, flew from Czechoslovakia to be by his daughter's side, the New York Post said. Mrs. Trump reportedly burst into tears Friday when she saw the Post's front page story quoting alleged ``other woman'' Marla Maples as saying Trump was the ``best sex I've ever had,'' the Post reported. Miss Maples' manager, Chuck Jones, was quoted in Saturday's Post as saying his client called the quote a ``blatant lie'' made up by a jealous actress-friend.

The Virginia budget is shrinking, but Gov. L. Douglas Wilder's limousine has grown a few inches and nearly doubled in cost over the one used by his predecessor. Wilder's black Lincoln Town Car is a wee bit longer than the stretch Cadillac used by ex-Gov. Gerald L. Baliles. But Wilder's limo is costing the state $37,923 plus trade-in of the Cadillac, which cost $19,949 plus trade-in four years ago. Wilder's car will be delivered in about six weeks, Curtis Wells, general manager of the dealership, said Saturday. It will have a keyless entry system, a 5-liter V-8 engine and six-way adjustable power seats. Since taking office, Wilder has pleaded for fiscal austerity among state agencies. On Friday, the House Finance Committee sent a $267 million package of revenue enhancement bills to the floor to help Virginia balance its proposed $25.8 billion budget. Car prices have gone up in four years, said Laura F. Dillard, the governor's press secretary. Plus, she said, former Gov. Charles S. Robb's car commanded a higher trade-in price to bring the cost of the Baliles car down. New governors traditionally trade in the vehicle of their predecessors.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Rankin Smith Jr., the target of a paternity lawsuit, is taking a leave from his post as president of the Falcons. No cause was given for the announced leave of absence from the National Football League team. Smith is the son of team owner Rankin Smith Sr. The Atlanta Journal and Constitution on Friday quoted an unidentified source with the club as saying Smith planned to take a leave until he could ``get his personal matters in order.'' Mona Simmons Smith, has filed a lawsuit alleging the younger Smith is the father of her 3-year-old son and 10-month-old daughter. The lawsuit seeks child support, permanent custody of the two children, legal fees and reimbursement for medical expenses. Smith's attorney, J. Stephen Clifford, said Smith does not deny that the children are his and has been providing child support. It wasn't clear whether Mona Smith had taken Rankin Smith's name. Gwinnett County property records show Rankin Smith gave Mona Smith a house valued at $213,000 three years ago.

Barbara Bush said her secret to staying happily married to the same man for 45 years is hugging. ``As you get older, I think you need to put your arms around each other more,'' Mrs. Bush said in the March issue of Ladies' Home Journal. Despite the pressures and demands on the president and the first lady, Mrs. Bush said they have never been closer. ``He calls me much more on the phone than he used to. He'll say, `Look out the window; there's a friend of yours,' and we'll wave hankies back and forth.'' During her daily swims in the White House pool, Mrs. Bush said she makes sure to pass by the far side of the Oval Office so her husband won't see her. ``George is so bad about saying, `Come in and say hello.' He caught me the other day in my preswimming clothes, and there was a new ambassador from a foreign country. There we were, eyeball to eyeball.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Vote In Parliamentary Election That Tests Governing Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 13th graf pvs to UPDATE with comment from Kaifu and Doi; pickup 14th graf pvs, `He accused...'; SUBS 20th graf `He quit...' to CONFORM. Pickup 21st graf pvs, `Ms. Doi...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TOK5,10,11,15
DOC.TEXT: Japan held parliamentary elections Sunday that put the scandal-plagued governing Liberal Democratic Party to its toughest test in decades. A controversial sales tax and sex- and influence-peddling scandals have dogged Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's party for nearly two years, forcing the resignation of two prime ministers. On Saturday, hundreds of candidates wearing white gloves to symbolize clean politics held final campaign rallies, and the issue was on the minds of some voters. ``The consumption tax and cleaning up politics are the most important issues in this election,'' said a middle-aged woman coming out of a voting booth who declined to give her name. But Masaru Oshima, 48, said although opposition parties are gaining support, ``their policies are unclear and their leadership untested.'' He said he voted for the Liberal Democrats. Polls indicated that the large number of uncommitted voters could hurt the Liberal Democratic Party, which has ruled Japan since 1955. The conservative party needed to win at least 257 seats in the 512-seat lower house of Parliament to retain its majority and win the right to name the prime minister. The Liberal Democrats hold 295 seats in the outgoing house, to 83 for the main opposition, the Socialist Party. A victory for the Socialists could lead to Japan having its first female prime minister _ 61-year-old Socialist Chairwoman Takako Doi. Polls opened at 7:00 a.m. (5 p.m. EST Saturday) and were to close 11 hours later. Partial election results were expected later Sunday, but final results were not expected until Monday afternoon. Mild winter weather across the country was expected to contribute to an unusually high voter turnout; polls predicted 80 percent of Japan's 90 million eligible voters would cast ballots. A poll released Saturday by the nationwide Asahi Shimbun newspaper reaffirmed earlier surveys showing the Liberal Democrats leading the Socialists by about 20 percentage points. But 32.2 percent of the 103,200 people surveyed said they had not decided which party they supported. The newspaper did not provide a margin of error for the survey, conducted Feb. 8-9 and 11-12. Ms. Doi said Sunday she was ``confident that people will move the mountain a second time,'' referring July elections for the less powerful upper house of Parliament in which the governing party lost its majority for the first time in 34 years. That chamber is now controlled by a Socialist-led coalition. Outside his Tokyo residence, Kaifu told reporters, ``It's up to the judgment of the people, but I'm certain that the Liberal Democratic Party's policies are generally accepted by the people.'' Both leaders voted earlier by absentee ballots. At a rally Saturday, Kaifu urged several thousand people at Tokyo's Shinjuku Station not to be swayed by the opposition. He accused the Socialists of being unclear on their position on defense and said a comment by Ms. Doi that such issues could be worked out ``overnight'' after the election was ``irresponsible.'' ``We can't allow someone who does things overnight to take over this precious country,'' he said. In an effort to win support from conservatives, the Socialists watered down their longstanding opposition to the U.S.-Japan security treaty, under which the United States bases 50,000 troops in Japan. But opposition to the treaty remains party policy, giving the conservatives an opening to accuse Socialists of weakening Japan's security. The Liberal Democrats had a disastrous year in 1989, caused by scandal and the passage of the unpopular 3 percent sales tax in April. Also in April, Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita resigned to accept responsibility for an influence-peddling scandal in which politicians profited from sales of cut-rate stock shares supplied by the Recruit Co. conglomerate. Takeshita's replacement, Sousuke Uno, lasted only two months and was plagued by allegations of extramarital affairs. He quit after the sex scandal and sales tax cost the Liberal Democrats their majority in the upper house in the July election. The party also lost farmers' support for partly opening agricultural markets to imports. Ms. Doi urged several thousand people at a rally in the western Tokyo suburb of Hachioji to ``show you believe the consumption tax and money politics are unforgivable.'' Kaifu, 59, urged voters not to base their decisions solely on the sales tax and promised the Liberal Democrats would not allow another Recruit scandal. ``The LDP will repeat right policies, but we will never repeat wrongdoings,'' he said. The Uno scandal and the sales tax, which was particularly disliked by housewives who do most of the family shopping, gave women in this male-dominated society a new voice in politics. The women's vote was said to have played a large part in the Liberal Democrats' election loss in July. The Liberal Democrats fielded 338 candidates; Socialists 149; Komeito (Clean Government Party) 58; Japan Communist Party 131; Democratic Socialist Party 44; United Social Democratic Party 6; and the Progressive Party 7. There were 64 candidates from minor parties and 156 running as independents.

DOC.HEAD: Jet Made Famous by D.B. Cooper Is Being Dismantled
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing 727 airliner made famous by D.B. Cooper is being dismantled for money _ not the skyjacker's ransom but for spare parts. The jet arrived Friday at the Greenwood-Leflore Airport where it will be disassembled for parts by The Memphis Group, a Tennessee-based company. The company purchased the airplane from American Transair, which bought the airplane from Northwest Airlines several years ago for charter flights. The jetliner was the one hijacked on Nov. 24, 1971, by a ``D.B. Cooper.'' A man using that name hijacked the plane during a flight from Portland, Ore., to Seattle. He demanded $200,000 in $20 bills and four parachutes. After the aircraft landed in Seattle, he released the 36 passengers and some of the crew in exchange for the ransom. Cooper ordered the crew to fly to Reno, Nev. Somewhere over southwest Washington, Cooper opened an exit door and jumped. He has never been located and his body was never found.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Raids Alleged Bootleg Video Ring
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators said Friday they smashed a pirate video movie ring that produced 1,500 illegal videocassettes a week for distribution to rental stores in the Northeast. The investigation, described by film industry officials as the most damaging operation ever against video bootlegers, led to the arrests of seven people in New Jersey and New York in raids Thursday night, said Gary Penrith, acting special agent in charge of the FBI's Newark office. During those raids, he said, agents discovered a video duplicating lab in a home in the New York borough of Queens packed with 78 state-of-the-art video recorders and about 2,000 copies of video movies popular in the rental market. Agents also found what they believe to be a distribution center in a private home that manufactured phony labels and boxes for the videos and shipped them to stores in the Northeast, officials said. ``For us this series of seizures in New York and New Jersey represents the toughest crackdown ever on video piracy,'' said Mark Harrad, an attorney and investigator who worked with federal agents on the case for the Motion Picture Association of America. ``We've had bigger seizures, but the discovery of the labs and distribution centers are really the most significant thing,'' he said. Neither the FBI nor the motion picture association could provide an estimate of how much money the bootleg ring cost the industry. Authorities believe the Queens lab was producing at least 1,500 illegal videocassettes a week, said Jack Valenti, president of the movie association. Arrested in New York were Julio Larraquente, owner of Video Latino and Sarita Feldman, owner of Latin Video, both in the New York borough of Brooklyn. In New Jersey, agents arrested Walter Martinez, 45, owner of Paradise Video & Record in Paterson; Santiago Branopolsky, 48, of North Bergen; Eddie Torres, 22, of Marlboro, Mass.; and Felix Humberto Blas-Aguilar, 20, of Union City.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Customs Cracks Crack Vial Ring
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Customs Service agents have confiscated 30 million empty crack vials worth $3 million and other drug paraphernalia in a series of arrests here and Los Angeles, federal officials announced Friday. During the last three days, special agents in New York arrested 11 people involved in the smuggling and distribution of drug paraphernalia, the service said in a statement. In addition to the vials, agents seized 40 million plastic bags valued at $639,000, three 1989 luxury automobiles and $14,500. The investigation started Dec. 13 last year when 270 cartons of plastic vials were found during a routine investigation by a Los Angeles inspector. The vials had been smuggled into the country as part of a shipment of cast iron from Taiwan. Customs agents then tracked the cartons, which contained about 10 million vials, to a warehouse in Elizabeth, N.J., and on to a warehouse in the New York City borough of Queens, where nine people were arrested Wednesday as they unloaded the cartons. The next day, agents executed search warrants at nine locations in Queens and confiscated 20 million additional vials and the 40 million plastic bags. At the same time, customs agents executed a search warrant at the offices of Success Systems Services in San Gabriel, Calif. The seizures and arrests are part of the customs services effort known as ``Operation Pipe'' designed to confiscate drug paraphernalia.

DOC.HEAD: Connery Caught for Speeding
DOC.TEXT: Actor Sean Connery pulled a James Bond stunt and drove at high speeds along a scenic highway, but police nabbed him. He admitted guilt and paid a fine, authorities said. ``007 did it. But unlike Zsa Zsa, he didn't fight with police,'' said Bob Calvert, Santa Barbara County chief trial deputy, referring to Miss Gabor's conviction for slapping a Beverly Hills policeman who stopped her Rolls-Royce. Connery, through his attorney, on Thursday paid a $190 speeding ticket for going 82 mph in a 55 mph zone. He was driving a rented 1989 Thunderbird when he was caught along the two-lane Highway 154 near the Southern California town of Solvang last Dec. 23. A California Highway patrolman ticketed him for speeding and for driving without a license. The latter charge was dismissed after Connery's attorney showed the star had a British driver's license. ``Too bad he wasn't in an Austin Healy and got away with an oil slick or smoke screen,'' Calvert said. ``All the secretaries in the office were going crazy. They wanted me to make sure that he appeared in court. I would've lost a whole day's work if he did.'' Connery, the first of four actors to play Bond, starred in ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' one of the top grossing movies of 1989 with $196 million. His newest film, ``The Hunt for Red October'' opens next month.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Im Bank Resuming Deals to Panama
DOC.TEXT: The Export-Import Bank said Friday night it was again accepting applications for financing to support sales to Panama. Financing and related insurance services were cut off in December 1987 as part of the U.S. campaign against the regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the dictator deposed by the U.S. invasion last Dec. 20. Economic sanctions have been lifted since the establishment of a new government and Congress has voted extra aid to Panama. The bank said short-term insurance was available for both public and private buyers in Panama; loans, guarantees and medium-term insurance for up tom five years is available for private sector buyers.

DOC.HEAD: NBC's ``ALF'' Moves to New Night
DOC.TEXT: NBC, shuffling its prime time schedule slightly, said the popular ``ALF'' series will move from Monday to Saturday at 8 p.m. EST as of March 3, and ``My Two Dads'' will fill its Monday slot starting March 5. The latter comedy series, which previously aired on the network, has been on a production hiatus. NBC said Friday that ``227,'' a Saturday comedy series whose time slot is being taken by ``ALF,'' will return later this season.

DOC.HEAD: Man Nabbed at High-Tech Conference by Low-Tech Intercom
DOC.TEXT: A man who stiffed a cabbie for the fare to a security exposition eluded detection in the hall filled with new anti-crime gadgetry _ but a message over a low-tech intercom got him. The man, who was not identified, vanished into the exhibit area of the International Security Conference and Exposition on Thursday after failing to pay the cab driver. Then he fell for an old trick. He responded to an intercom page asking him to come to the expo office at the Orange County Convention and Civic Center. ``I wish we could say it was something high-tech, but all we used was an intercom,'' said Gary Shaw of the Cahners Exposition Group. ``And boy, he came right away. He thought he was going to win something.'' He won a police escort back to the cabbie, who had called the man's hotel to get his name. Authorities said the man was released after paying his fare.

DOC.HEAD: Investigator Says Hazelwood Didn't Seem Drunk
DOC.TEXT: A Coast Guard investigator said Joseph Hazelwood smelled of alcohol but otherwise did not appear drunk the night his Exxon Valdez went aground, causing the nation's worst oil spill. Mark Delozier, one of the first officers to board the Exxon Valdez after it rammed a reef last March 24, testified Friday that he called for someone to administer blood and urine tests to the crew after first encountering Hazelwood and smelling liquor on his breath. But Delozier said his message to Coast Guard headquarters was misinterpreted and a state police officer was dispatched with a different mission. ``He was under the impression he was supposed to come out to the ship to take ahold of an unruly drunk,'' Delozier said, noting the officer brought no testing equipment. ``I was disgusted at the fact that we had already waited a few hours and now he was going to be of no use to us,'' he said, noting that the passage of time meant alcohol could dissipate from blood and urine. But Delozier acknowledged that Hazelwood seemed coordinated and showed no sign of being intoxicated other than the smell of his breath. Delozier said Hazelwood had ``a very intense and very obvious'' smell of liquor about him and was trying to hide it by covering his mouth and drinking coffee. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with one felony count of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. If convicted, the former tanker skipper could draw up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. Nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil spilled from the Exxon Valdez into Prince William Sound on March 24, killing countless birds, fish and wildlife and blackening hundreds of miles of rocky shore. Delozier, who boarded the ship about 3{ hours after it ran aground on Bligh Reef, said he first saw Hazelwood standing at a window in his cabin with an elbow on a window sill and his hand covering his mouth. Because of the confusion about sending test equipment to the ship, the blood and urine tests were not taken until 10{ hours after the accident, he said. Before Delozier took the stand, a forensic toxicologist testified that Hazelwood's blood and urine tested positive for alcohol. Michael A. Peat, of Sacramento, Calif., said Hazelwood had a level of 0.061 percent of alcohol in his blood and 0.094 percent in his urine. He said the blood and urine tests almost never result in the same figures and did not explain the significance of the amounts found. The blood alcohol test was under the Alaska state limit of 0.10 for driving a vehicle, but over the federal limit of 0.04 for operating a commercial vessel. Ironically, Delozier acknowledged that he had been drinking the night before the accident at the same Valdez bar where Hazelwood is alleged to have gotten drunk earlier in the same day. DeLozier said he had only two light beers and did not consider himself intoxicated but conceded that someone talking to him might have smelled beer on his breath. ``Mr. Delozier, are you sure you weren't smelling your own breath?'' Chalos asked of the confrontation with Hazelwood. ``Absolutely,'' Delozier responded.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Soul singer Ike Turner, former husband of Grammy-winning singer Tina Turner, has begun serving a prison sentence for cocaine convictions. Superior Judge Robert Altman sentenced Turner, 58, to four years in state prison Friday. Turner had asked to be admitted to a rehabilitation program instead, but Altman refused, noting Turner already had entered several such programs. Prosecutor Ralph Mayer said, ``He's not the type of criminal that's in any way violent ... He's just a 20-year abuser of the drugs who should have been caught a long time ago.'' A Superior Court jury convicted Turner last month of driving under the influence of cocaine and being under the influence of cocaine, both misdemeanors. The panel deadlocked 8-4 in favor of acquittal on two felony charges, transportation of cocaine and possession of cocaine for sale, forcing a mistrial. Turner then pleaded guilty, avoiding another trial, Mayer said. The charges stem from an Aug. 19, 1987, arrest by sheriff's deputies who stopped Turner after his car was traveling erratically in West Hollywood. Deputies found crystallized cocaine in the car.

Tenor Vladimir Popov, more jittery than when he sings in the world's great opera houses, was sworn in as a U.S. citizen, eight years after he defected from the Soviet Union. ``I've been before thousands of people,'' he nervously told a naturalization official in halting English before taking the oath Friday, ``but this is more.'' Popov, who lives in Wentworth, N.H., flew in from Washington for the ceremony and planned to return in time to appear as the lead when Verdi's ``Aida'' opens today at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. With his wife, Lucy, their three children and other relatives excitedly looking on, Popov took the oath in the court of U.S. District Judge Shane Devine. He was the only new citizen taking the oath. Afterward, Popov turned to his relatives, puffed out his chest and smiled as they applauded. Popov, 42, a native of Moscow, defected while studying in Milan, Italy, in 1982, the only time he was allowed out of the Soviet Union.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Harolyn is cq in 5th graf
DOC.TEXT: Luciano Pavarotti offered a low-calorie recipe as he announced ``Pavarotti Plus,'' a televised concert he and four other opera singers will give on Feb. 28. Because the tenor usually is dieting, the first ingredient was a surprise: ``Three pounds of pasta.'' Then, ``one spoon of olive oil in a pot to fry, three spoons tomato paste, garlic, parsley. ``You put a slice of bread into the pot and you eat it and throw away the three pounds of pasta.'' On the PBS ``Live from Lincoln Center'' presentation from Avery Fisher Hall, Pavarotti will sing with baritone Leo Nucci _ ``I'm a good cook. He's a very good cook,'' Pavarotti said _ and sopranos Carol Vaness, Leona Mitchell and Harolyn Blackwell. Pavarotti has been battling sciatic nerve pain and recently spent a month in a clinic near Parma, Italy.

The beautiful Lena Olin may be riding high with an Oscar nomination for her role in ``Enemies, A Love Story,'' but don't suppose that she's happy. ``I can't imagine how someone can be content on this earth,'' the Swedish actress said in an interview in the March 8 issue of Rolling Stone. ``I know some people are, but I can't understand. I hate in scripts _ and in life _ when people try to simplify: `Oh, I'm SO happy.' Some say we have to make movies like that to give people a break. I don't think that's true. It's a relief to go to movies or theater that give a real sense of life.'' Olin was nominated for her portrayal of a Holocaust survivor who eventually commits suicide in ``Enemies.''

Actress Tracy Pollan said she and her husband, Michael J. Fox, are engaged in ``a never-ending effort to keep life simple.'' ``Michael and I both have our fantasy of the way life will be,'' Pollan, who appears next week in the ABC miniseries, ``The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys,'' said in the March 5 issue of US magazine. Pollan and Fox _ who is taking four months off to help raise their 9-month-old son, Sam _ have a house in Los Angeles, but their recently refurbished farm in Vermont will be home, she said. ``And we bought an apartment in New York,'' she said. ``We'll probably be based there and live in Vermont as much as we can. It's all part of the never-ending effort to keep life simple.'' ``I'd love for Sam to go to school in Vermont and just be a kid on a farm and have a real normal childhood,'' she said. ``I don't want him growing up in L.A. We'd work a couple of times a year, and the rest of the time we'd ride horses, cook, take Sam to school.''

Former tennis star Bjorn Borg and his wife, Loredana, lost a $40,000 libel lawsuit against a Swedish gossip weekly that published an article insinuating she was being unfaithful. A civil court ruled Friday that the information Hant i Veckan published about Mrs. Berte-Borg shortly before the couple married in September was not legally ``offensive,'' the national news agency TT said. TT said Mrs. Berte-Borg cried during testimony, telling the court the article ``is an insult to the love that unites Bjorn and me.'' Borg is involved in five legal battles, including a $600,000 libel suit against another Swedish weekly that published allegations by his former girlfriend, Jannike Bjorling, that he used cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Celebrate Former Independence
With PM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Lithuanians took to the streets of two cities on the anniversary of their 1918 declaration of independence and demanded freedoms that were lost when the Kremlin annexed the Baltic state in World War II. About 100,000 people attended a rally Friday in the republic's second-largest city of Kaunas, while 40,000 turned out for a public meeting in the capital, Vilnius, according to a spokeswoman for Sajudis, Lithuania's grass-roots pro-independence group. Leaders of Sajudis addressed the crowds in both cities, renewing the republic's demand for independence, Sajudis activist Romuna Sakoloskejda said by telephone from Vilnius. Lithuania's parliament last week approved a resolution declaring ``unlawful and invalid'' the 1940 act that incorporated their republic with neighboring Latvia and Estonia into the Soviet Union. They demanded talks with the Kremlin on restoring Lithuanian independence. On Thursday, the Parliament of neighboring Latvia also condemned the annexation and voted to restore the national anthem and red-and-white flag of independent Latvia, replacing the Communist hammer and sickle emblem. Lithuania, a hilly region on the Baltic Sea about the size of West Virginia, was under Russian rule before World War I and occupied by the German army during the war. It became the first Baltic state to declare independence from both Russia and Germany on Feb. 16, 1918, and its example was soon followed by Latvia and Estonia. But all three Baltic states enjoyed only about two decades of independence before being swallowed up and incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940, after the 1939 Hitler-Stalin pact carved Eastern Europe into spheres of influence. The Soviet Union tried to diminish the local culture by promoting immigration of Russians to the Baltics, but Lithuanians still make up about 80 percent of their republic's population. Lithuania has spearheaded the Baltic drive for independence from the Soviet Union. Its Communist Party broke with Moscow in December. The Lithuanian moves initially drew sharp criticism and warnings from Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but the Lithuanian party's move to break with Moscow won it public support at home. Lithuania's parliament faces an election Feb. 25, and the outcome will be a major factor in future relations with Moscow. Gorbachev has promised more autonomy for the 15 Soviet republics. During a visit last month to Lithuania, he announced that a law is being written that under certain conditions would allow a republic to secede from the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Hopes Bar Group Won't Use Abortion `Litmus Test'
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh is concerned that the American Bar Association will use a resolution endorsing abortion rights to produce a litmus test for screening judicial nominees. But the president of the ABA says the hotly debated resolution adopted Tuesday in Los Angeles will not affect the way the bar group evaluates the qualifications of prospective federal judges. Thornburgh said in an interview Friday that the resolution could result in ``a litmus test on judicial nominees.'' ``If one arm of the ABA is saying something and another arm of the ABA is evaluating judicial candidates, you want to know what's the connection between the two arms,'' he said. But L. Stanley Chauvin, the ABA president, said the resolution will not touch the ABA's Standing Committee on Federal Judiciary decisions on rating prospective candidates for federal judgeships. ``That wasn't the purpose of the resolution,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``It will not have anything to do with it. ``As far as our relationship with Gen. Thornburgh and the Justice Department, it is as though it never passed,'' said Chauvin, who voted against the resolution along with John J. Curtin Jr., the ABA president-elect. Adopted by a 2-1 margin following acrimonious debate, the resolution puts the ABA in opposition to the Bush administration on abortion rights. Under Thornburgh, the Justice Department has asked the Supreme Court to overturn its landmark 1971 decision that legalized abortion. Thornburgh has expressed other concerns about the ABA's judicial screening panel, which conservative critics have charged was used by liberals to weed out people with views the committee found unacceptable. Thornburgh last spring got from the ABA an agreement to delete language from its guidelines stating that political and philosophical views would not be considered, except as they bore on other factors. ABA officials denied the views of candidates were considered, but Thornburgh threatened to cut the organization out of judicial screening unless it agreed to change the guidelines. On Friday, Thornburgh denied he was again threatening the ABA with exclusion from the judicial-selection process. ``We want to hear from the ABA,'' he said. But Thornburgh expressed concern that the members of the judicial-screening committee might feel compelled to enforce ABA policy on abortion when interviewing prospective candidates. Thornburgh said that, as an ABA member, he objected to the resolution because ``this view doesn't reflect my views.'' ``I am concerned that the association would squander its expertise to express its views in areas where they have no particular expertise,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Lift Navigator Requirement For Alaska-Siberia Flights
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government Friday rescinded its requirement that Alaska flights to Siberia have a Soviet navigator aboard, again opening the door for flights across the Bering Strait. The change was announced the same day Federal Aviation Administration and Soviet of Civil Aviation officials met in Washington, D.C., to sign a memorandum of cooperation promoting civil aeronautics and air commerce between the United States and Soviet Union. The agreement sets up air corridors between Anchorage, Gambell, King Island and Nome, and the Siberian communities of Provideniya, Magadan, Anadyr and Khabarovsk. The Soviets also announced they will upgrade the airport at Provideniya and give it international status. The decision lifting the navigator requirement applies to all carriers, including Nome's Bering Air. While Bering Air's twin-engine commuter planes have made scores of flights into Siberia since their first flight to Provideniya in 1988, the airline balked when the Soviets required a Soviet navigator be aboard each flight. Bering Air owner Jim Rowe said the $12,000-per-flight cost would be prohibitive and the airline stopped flying to Siberia in November. Rowe was in Washington, D.C., on Friday and could not be reached, his office said. The small airline charges $2,500 for each charter to Siberia, and about $250 for a one-way trip. ``This is the first significant step in a two-part effort to begin regular commercial air service between Alaska and the Soviet Union,'' Sen. Ted Stevens said in a news release. ``It's welcome. We've been working toward this for a long time.''

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Terrorism Down Overall, but Iran Not Letting Up
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials believe international terrorism is declining although attacks by Iranian-sponsored Shiite groups are on the increase. ``Iran believes terrorism is a legitimate part of foreign policy,'' said an American official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Preliminary figures show incidents of international terrorism declined by about 25 percent last year from the 1988 total of 856, according to the official. The figures to be released in the State Department's annual report on terrorism next month also show a decline of about 27 percent in the number of fatalities from terrorist acts _ from 660 to 485. Exact numbers on overall incidents were not available. Counterterrorism experts attribute the 1989 decline to better airport security, more commitment by governments to bring suspected terrorists to trial and a drop in violent activities of Palestinian groups. Fatah, the largest faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has kept a pledge leader Yasser Arafat made in December 1988 to refrain from terrorist attacks, said the U.S. official, who predicted Fatah would continue that promise. Two groups that may not remain as inactive as they were in 1989 are the Fatah Revolutionary Council headed by Abu Nidal and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Commanded led by Ahmed Jebril. Abu Nidal's group has been paralyzed by a revolt that led the Libyan-based leader to order dozens of followers killed over the past two years, PLO sources say. However, experts agree the group still poses a threat and that some Abu Nidal operatives have joined the Syrian-based PFLP-GC. FBI and intelligence officials believe the PFLP-GC carried out the December 1988 bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Scotland that killed 270 people. However, the U.S. official said evidence collected in the multinational police investigation isn't sufficient to bring charges. Jebril is thought to have carried out the Pan Am attack under contract with Iran, which has been accused of sponsoring dozens of terrorist attacks around the world. Iranian-sponsored terrorism has increased in the six months since the death of revolutionary leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The State Department issued a warning earlier this month that pro-Iranian extremists could be planning an attack against Americans in Europe to coincide with the 11th anniversary of the Islamic revolution that brought Khomeini to power.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Caution of Possible Climate Disruption
DOC.NOTE: Eds: El Nino is pronounced el-NEEN-yo
DOC.TEXT: Government scientists say changing water temperatures in the tropical Pacific Ocean may be signaling the start of a new El Nino that could cause powerful climate changes worldwide. Current conditions resemble those of 1986, a relatively mild version of El Nino, which has caused widespread devastating weather in the past. ``The current situation deserves very close attention,'' the federal Climate Analysis Center said in a statement Friday. The El Nino in 1982-83 led to weather changes that were blamed for 1,500 deaths and billions of dollars in damage across the globe. ``We don't want to say something is developing that could be like that, because that was exceptional,'' Dr. Vernon Kousky of the climate center said in a telephone interview. The 1982-83 El Nino was blamed for worsening the devastating drought in Africa, causing severe winter storms to come ashore in California, spawning the first typhoon to strike French Polynesia in 75 years _ followed by five more in five months _ deluging Peru and Ecuador with torrential rains and promoting the worst drought in two centuries in Australia. The United Nations estimated overall damage at between $2 billion and $8 billion. Scientists suggest that was a once-in-a-lifetime event, however. The El Nino in 1986-87 was closer to average, bringing some weather changes but not the massive damage of the earlier event. Formally called El Nino-Southern Oscillations, or ENSOs, these events are characterized by unusually warm water conditions in the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean and by changes in air pressure over different parts of that ocean. Water temperatures near the international dateline have risen 1 and 2 degrees Fahrenheit above normal. While that may seem small, the great amount of energy needed to warm such a large mass of water can make it a significant increase. Years ago, when such changes tended to be first noticed by South American fishermen around Christmas, the phenomenon was given the name El Nino, which is Spanish for child, a reference to the baby Jesus. Current conditions are similar to those prior to the 1986 event, said Kousky. But, he added, ``I can't really say how firm it looks. ... There is nothing to say this will hang in there tough and continue on. We're just monitoring it carefully.'' If it does build into a full-fledged El Nino, the impact could be felt worldwide. The problem is relocating warm water from one side of the Pacific Ocean to the other. Normal conditions include strong easterly winds, which move the warm surface waters of the ocean toward Asia and allow cooler waters to rise up from the depths along the coast of South America. But when an ENSO occurs the easterly winds diminish or are replaced by westerlies, and the warm water sloshes back toward the Americas. That puts more rain and cloudiness in the central Pacific, where it normally isn't, said Kousky, and the heating strengthens the jet stream and upsets the normal wave patterns. A disruption in the normal jet stream can cause changes in weather almost anywhere on the globe. El Ninos have been recorded periodically for many years. Evidence of the effects of El Ninos can be traced, in fact, back to 1532 when an unusually wet season apparently helped Pizarro and his Conquistadores cross normally desert areas in what is now Peru.

DOC.HEAD: Institute Protests Reported Seizure of Two Weekly Newspapers in Nepal
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute said it protested to the government of Nepal over the reported seizure of editions of two weekly newspapers reporting on a campaign for democracy. ``We strongly urge that journalists in Nepal be allowed to pursue their profession without further harassment, fear and intimidation,'' Peter Galliner, the institute's director, wrote in a letter released Friday. The letter to Nepal's home minister, Niranjan Thapa, said the institute was concerned about reports that police on Tuesday seized editions of the weeklies Saptahik Simarsha and Saptahik Nepali Awaaj. The two newspapers gave extensive coverage to the campaign for multiparty democracy in the Himalayan country, a constitutional monarchy. These actions directly contravene international agreements such as Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which guarantees the right of journalists to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through the news media regardless of frontiers. The institute, which has offices in London and Zurich, is an independent organization of nearly 2,000 leading publishers and editors in more than 60 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Consultant Sentenced In `Ill Wind' Probe
DOC.TEXT: A defense consultant described as a major figure in the Pentagon procurement scandal will have to spend up to 27 months in prison and pay a $10,000 fine for participating in a six-year scheme to bribe a government official. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton in Alexandria, Va., sentenced Thomas E. Muldoon on Friday to 27 months in prison and also ordered him to serve three years of supervised probation following his release from prison. Muldoon, 60, of Rockville, Md., was convicted in December of participating in the conspiracy to funnel $80,000 in bribes to Jack A. Sherman, a civilian Marine Corps contracting official. Muldoon, described by prosecutors as a major figure in the Pentagon procurement scandal, received one of the longer sentences in the long-running investigation that has been nicknamed ``Operation Ill Wind.'' He could have received a 70-year prison sentence and fined up to $1.04 million for eight convictions of conspiracy, bribery, interstate travel in the aid of racketeering and false claims. A jury found Muldoon guilty of funneling the bribes to Sherman through two defense consultants for Lee Telecommunications and the Whittaker Corp. subsidiary that took over the company in 1986. Sherman, who is serving an 18-month term, testified that he arranged to receive the bribes in return for helping Lee obtain lucrative Marine Corps electronics contracts. Sherman testified that he received $25,000 from Muldoon. Two other defense consultants also served as conduits for the bribes, according to testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Maryland Publisher Named to NATO Post
DOC.TEXT: Philip Merrill, chairman of Capital-Gazette Communications, has been named to the highest ranking U.S. position in NATO. The post, assistant secretary-general of NATO for defense support, is currently held by former Sen. Mack Mattingly, R-Ga. He has held the job for three years and will leave in mid-March. Merrill, 55, served in the Department of Defense from 1981 to 1983 as counselor to the Under-Secretary of Defense for Policy. Since 1983 he has served as a member of the Department of Defense Policy Board. In 1988, the Secretary of Defense awarded him the Medal for Distinguished Service, the highest civilian honor given by the department. Before purchasing Capital-Gazette Communications in 1968, Merrill served as a special assistant to the Deputy Secretary of State, and had worked in the White House on national security issues. ``At a time when the political, economic and military relationships in Europe are being transformed, I cannot imagine a more interesting and exciting place to be than NATO headquarters in Brussels,'' Merrill said. Merrill said his wife, Eleanor, would take over as publisher in his absence and would divide her time between Brussels and Annapolis. Mrs. Merrill currently is associate publisher. Capital-Gazette Communications Inc. publishes The (Annapolis) Capital, the Maryland Gazette, the Bowie Blade-News and the Crofton News-Crier, as well as The Washingtonian and Baltimore magazines.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Hits Japan's Southern Islands
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake hit Japan's southern islands today but no injuries were reported, the Central Meteorological Agency said. The agency said the quake had a preliminary reading of 6.3 on the Richter scale and was centered 12 miles under the seabed off the coast of Amami Oshima island, 940 miles southwest of Tokyo. The quake was also felt on Yakushima and Tenegashima islands, 625 miles southwest of Tokyo. There was no danger of tidal waves nor any reports of death, injury or damages, according to the agency. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy an earthquake releases. Each increase of one number on the scale means the ground motion is 10 times greater. On the Richter scale, a six can cause severe damage in populated areas. A seven is a ``major'' quake, capable of widespread heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Judges Regain Posts Lost After Martial Law
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-four judges forced out for political reasons during the 1981 martial-law crackdown regained their old jobs and President Wojciech Jaruzelski apologized for their firings, TV news reported. It said the provincial judges were sworn in Friday by Jaruzelski, who declared martial law to suppress the independent Solidarity movement. Throughout Poland, judges, journalists, professors, doctors and others suspected of sympathizing with the opposition were fired. Others resigned rather than undergo a ``verification'' of their loyalty to Communist authorities in the Dec. 13, 1981 crackdown. After Solidarity was legalized and the non-Communist government led by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki took power last year, formal efforts began to re-hire some of those who lost their professions. ``There is a feeling of satisfaction, but there is also a feeling of the old bitterness remaining,'' Judge Tadeusz Pokrzywa told the main evening TV news program after he was sworn back in. Jaruzelski, who been increasingly accepting blame for martial law and its failure to restore Poland's economic and social stability, apologized to the judges at the ceremony. ``The president's apology made today in this room had a great impression on me,'' said Pokrzywa, from the southeastern province of Rzeszow. ``In connection ith that, I accept it with full satisfaction.''

DOC.BYLINE: African Monkey Linked to Branch of AIDS Epidemic ^By DANIEL Q. HANEY
DOC.TEXT: A disease closely related to the AIDS virus can almost certainly be traced back to an African monkey, which may have given it to people by biting them, a researcher said. Dr. Vanessa M. Hirsch of Georgetown University said Friday the West African epidemic of HIV-2 disease most likely comes from the sooty mangabey, a nondescript charcoal-gray monkey that is now endangered. The virus causes no outward signs of disease in the monkeys. But when humans contract the disease, it causes a serious illness that is similar to acquired immune deficiency syndrome, although less fatal. Hirsch said she believes HIV-2 was transmitted from monkeys to people within the past century through a bite or some other close contact. HIV-2 is in the same family of viruses as HIV-1, the virus responsible for the AIDS epidemic elsewhere in Africa as well as Europe and the United States. Many kinds of African monkeys naturally harbor relatives of the human AIDS virus. And while the chances of transmission from animals to people are slim, this likely has happened in the past and could occur again. Hirsch presented her findings Friday at a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Many experts believe that HIV-1 spread from animals to people, as well. According to one theory, it moved into a small, geographically isolated pocket of humans in Africa; the disease became epidemic only in recent years when those people moved to cities. ``The evidence is highly suggestive of transmission from monkeys to man of HIV-2,'' said Dr. Louis N. Martin of the Delta Regional Primate Research Center at Tulane University. ``But where did HIV-1 come from? We don't know.'' Hirsch said there are two reasons to think that HIV-2 came from sooty mangabeys. The monkey virus and HIV-2 are about 75 percent alike, and the monkeys live in the same area where HIV-2 is rampant. She said the animals are quick to bite, and people in West Africa keep them as pets and for food. ``I would say it's very dangerous to own any kind of African primate,'' Hirsch said. She said the sooty mangabey virus also was probably the cause of an AIDS-like illness in macaque monkeys in the United States. Macaques are Asian monkeys and do not naturally harbor their own relative of the AIDS virus. A virus known as SIV, or simian immunodeficiency virus, was first isolated at the New England Regional Primate Center in 1985, and it has become an important stand-in for studying human AIDS. Macaques that catch this virus quickly grow sick and die. They are now used as models to test possible ways to treat or prevent AIDS in people. For instance, researchers at the New England primate center have found evidence that a potential medicine known as CD4, which is intended to draw the virus away from its usual targets in the bloodstream, appears to wipe out the virus in monkeys. Preliminary studies of this approach are now being conducted in people. Other researchers at the Delta primate center have found that vaccines made from killed monkey virus may be effective in protecting animals from infection with the virus. Experts say this work is among the most promising signs yet that an AIDS vaccine for people is possible.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Praise, Some Questions Linger About Drug Summit
DOC.TEXT: Amid the applause for President Bush's role at the Colombia drug summit, questions linger over the meeting's achievements and the deliberate avoidance of areas of dispute. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Judiciary Committee, praised Bush on Friday for ``his courage and leadership,'' but called the president's drug policies misdirected and geared too much toward military assistance. ``This continues our policy of attacking the drug traffickers but doing too little to stop coca growing by farmers, which is the root problem,'' Biden said. He said the United States should focus on crop development, economic assistance, debt relief and trade policies that do not undermine legitimate exports such as coffee and flowers. The summit communique signed Thursday by Bush and the leaders of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru proclaimed sweeping goals, such as replacing coca-growing economies, attacking the production and trafficking of drugs and reducing the demand by users. The document didn't say how those goals would be achieved, however, and controversial subjects such as the extradition of drug suspects and increased U.S. military involvement in the drug war were largely ignored. There also was no discussion of any specific amount of increased aid from the United States, though the Andean nations clearly want more assistance and relaxed trade policies. National drug policy director William Bennett said many of the blanks would be filled in during negotiations with the summit countries. ``I'm not saying we won't have more difficulties from here on. We will,'' he said. Still, he said the summit had been of ``transcendent importance.'' ``It was the first time the four countries faced up to all the problems,'' Bennett said, calling it important for the South American leaders to talk about the ``moral dimensions'' of a coca economy. Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson called it ``a meeting in which nobody talked in stereotypes or cliches.'' Bennett said there was ``a lot of good-natured sparring.'' Bush gave no hint he would beef up the $2.2 billion, five-year Andean aid program already on the table. ``We're going to stay with that figure for now,'' the president said Thursday before returning to Washington. Bush's attendance provided a dramatic gesture of support for Barco and his unrelenting battle against the drug lords. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, called Bush on Friday to congratulate him. Rangel said it was ``a significant first step in the global effort to control the drug trade'' and the communique provided ``a valuable framework for future cooperative efforts.'' Rangel, whose committee will hold a hearing Feb. 28 about the summit outcome, made clear he believes the administration has a long way to go. ``I hope your entire Cabinet will become energized by your historic mission,'' Rangel said in a letter to Bush. ``The heads of the executive departments must develop the kinds of creative strategies that will be necessary'' to reduce the demand for drugs.

DOC.HEAD: New Cigarette Brand Aimed at Female Tractor Pull Fan
DOC.NOTE: EDS: RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator
DOC.TEXT: She's young, she's white, she parties, she thinks tractor pulls are cool. She's just what the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. is looking for. A marketing plan to test a new brand of cigarettes called ``Dakota'' targets women in the 18 to 20-year-old range who like to watch ``Roseanne'' and evening soap operas on TV and aspire to marry in their early twenties, according to a story published in today's Washington Post. Until that trip to the church, this smoker is content to spend her free time ``with her boyfriend doing whatever he is doing,'' according to The Post, which obtained the company's marketing proposals for ``Dakota.'' Reynolds, which plans to begin test marketing of the cigarette in Houston in April, said the Dakota is not intended to be solely for women. ``Different products are designed to different categories of consumers,'' the company said in a statement. ``Dakota is no different. It is not a male brand or a female brand.'' The marketing studies say Dakota is designed to ``replace Marlboro as the brand of choice among female smokers 18-24.'' Marlboro is produced by Philip Morris Companies Inc. A man on a horse sells Marlboros. The Post reported Reynolds confirmed its plans to test market the cigarettes but got testy when asked about the marketing study. ``Reynolds does not know what these documents contain,'' the company said in a statement. ``Reynolds does not know if they are authentic or fabricated. ... If they are authentic, they represent stolen, proprietary information belonging to R.J. Reynolds and which would be of great value to our competitors.'' The company already has had plans for a new brand of cigarette go up in smoke this year, when public uproar led Reynolds to abandon introduction of ``Uptown,'' which was targeted at blacks. The marketing plan obtained by the Post draws this profile of the preferred Dakota smoker: _Education: High school, but no more. _Employment: ``Work is a job, not a career.'' _Interests: ``Partying with friends; dancing, going to clubs and bars; cruising; watching television; shopping at the mall.'' _Live Entertainment: ``Drag races; motocross, motorcycle races; hot rod shows; cycle shows; tractor pulls, monster trucks; wrestling, tough man competitions.''

DOC.HEAD: Reputed Colombian Drug Kingpin Named in New Indictment
DOC.TEXT: The reputed leader of the Medellin drug cartel was indicted by a statewide grand jury on cocaine-smuggling charges, but authorities concede that bringing him to justice won't be easy. Pablo Escobar Gaviria, last reported at large in Colombia, was indicted Friday with 13 others on charges they helped smuggle more than 8,000 pounds of cocaine through Florida. Escobar already faces federal drug charges in Miami, where he is one of 15 co-defendants of Manuel Noriega, and in Jacksonville. ``What expectation does ... the state of Florida have of prosecuting Pablo Escobar in this country? I just don't know what the odds would be at this point,'' Florida Department of Law Enforcement agent Manuel Pondakos said Friday. ``But it's not a lost hope,'' he said. ``I think we can get our hands on him and he'll be brought back here.'' Agents said the nine-count racketeering and conspiracy indictment returned Friday is the culmination of a 15-month investigation. The cocaine was said to be worth $82 million. Another major defendant arrested Friday is James M. Timonere, a Tarpon Springs attorney. Agents alleged he was ``soldier in the Colombian drug organization,'' helping to hide profits from drugs smuggled into the St. Petersburg area and shipped to New York and other large cities. ``He also leased motor vehicles and laundered money for the organization,'' Florida agent Connie Smith-Patrick alleged of Timonere. ``He also stored cocaine.'' Timonere was in the Pinellas County jail Friday night on $250,000 bond. Other defendants included U.S. citizens from Florida, Alabama and Arizona, and foreign nationals from Colombia and Belize. Authorities have also seized more than $1.6-million worth of property, including boats, cars, homes and cash, as part of their investigation. The state indictment only adds to the federal charges Escobar already faces. Escobar was named in the 1988 federal drug-trafficking indictment that led to the arrest of Noriega. That indictment accused Escobar, as head of the cartel, with bribing Noriega to turn Panama into a transit and processing point for Colombian cocaine. In March 1989, a federal grand jury in Jacksonville, based on testimony in the trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas, indicted Escobar and other cartel leaders for drug smuggling and for organizing the assassination of Colombian Justice Minister Rodrigo Lara Bonilla on April 29, 1984. The indictment also said Escobar and Fabio Ochoa Vasquez directed the Feb. 19, 1986, slaying of former Drug Enforcement Administration informant Barry Seal. Escobar and other alleged cartel leaders, including Jorge Ochoa Vasquez, were also named in a sweeping August 1986 indictment in Miami which laid out the organization's operations.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say They Were Satisfied with Access to Bases
DOC.TEXT: The head of a delegation of Soviet lawmakers says his group is satisfied with its access to U.S. military bases and that the Soviet Union will be more forthcoming when Americans return the visit. Vladimir L. Lapygin, a member of the Supreme Soviet Presidium, spoke at a news conference Friday after meeting with the House Armed Services Committee to discuss ways to assure a smooth transition to a more peaceful coexistence. ``Let's decide about some specific issue to get from words to deeds,'' Lapygin told committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis. The 10-member group, on a 12-day tour, has visited military bases, Los Alamos National Laboratories, NORAD, a Minuteman II missile site and the Strategic Air Command in Nebraska. Today the group was to visit the Tactical Air Command at Langley Air Force Base in Virginia and an Army chemical weapon facility at Fort McClellan, Ala. On Sunday, they planned to visit the Kennedy Space Center and Walt Disney World in Florida. Lapygin said some troop levels must be maintained despite mutual concerns about how to ease the return of soldiers to civilian life and convert war industries to peacetime use. Aspin mentioned some areas of possible cooperation, including the conversion of industries and precautions against the accidental launch of missiles.
DOC.HEAD: Feds Approve Plan To Keep D&H Running
DOC.TEXT: The Interstate Commerce Commission has voted unanimously to continue service on the ailing Delaware & Hudson Railway for another week while a bankruptcy trustee tries to negotiate the sale of the nation's oldest continually operated railroad. ``I think we're all of one mind that the service should be maintained,'' ICC Chairman Edward J. Philbin said at a hearing Friday. The ICC voted 4-0, with one commissioner absent, to allow three railroads to run on D&H tracks: the New York, Susquehanna & Western, which operates the D&H under earlier ICC orders; Lackawanna Valley Railroad Corp.; and North Shore Railroad Co. Under the plan, the railroads will be subsidized by the states of New York and Pennsylvania; two shippers; two Canadian railroads; and a third unidentified railroad, said Charles H. White Jr., counsel for the bankruptcy trustee. He identified the shippers as General Electric Corp. and International Paper Co. The two Canadian railroads, Canadian National and Canadian Pacific, are interested in buying the D&H. White estimated the subsidies would amount to $500,000 or more a month. The D&H in June 1988 filed for court protection from its creditors under the federal bankruptcy laws. The line has debts of about $100 million.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says China Bid To Join GATT on Hold
DOC.TEXT: Progress on a Chinese application to join an international group aimed at expanding world trade has been slowed because of questions about China's commitment to economic reforms, the State Department says. It said Friday that a number of members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), including the United States, have expressed concern about measures China has taken ``which restrict market access and are incompatible with GATT principles.'' ``We believe these questions need to be adequately addressed before further action is possible on China's application,'' the department said in a written response to press questions. At the same time, State said it was looking forward to the eventual inclusion of Taiwan in GATT's membership because of the island's importance in the global trading system. The department added that the United States has maintained a consistent policy on GATT membership for both China and Taiwan over the years. ``We have told both parties that we want eventual access for both on meaningful terms agreed upon by GATT members,'' it said.

Imelda Marcos' new attorney, trying to repair the image of the former Philippine first lady, asks that people compare her with Nancy Reagan. ``Suppose Mrs. Reagan were abducted from her home in California and taken to the Philippines and charged in the Philippines with crimes she allegedly committed in the U.S.,'' the attorney, Gerry Spence said Friday. ``How do you think Mrs. Reagan would feel?'' Spence made his remarks after a federal court hearing on the racketeering indictment that charged Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, Ferdinand Marcos, with embezzling more than $100 million from the Philippine treasury to buy art and Manhattan real estate. They also were charged with defrauding banks of $165 million in loans. Marcos died in exile in Hawaii on Sept. 28 at age 72. Spence of Jackson Hole, Wyo., who had represented the family of Karen Silkwood, was hired by Mrs. Marcos as part of changes in her defense team that included the dropping of two other attorneys.

East Germany will tear down a 600-foot section of the Berlin Wall near the Brandenburg Gate and allow completely unhindered passage between the two sides of the city there, West German television said. Since November, the East Germans have created numerous passage points through the Berlin Wall but have retained nominal checks of passports or identity cards. The section at the Brandenburg Gate will be the first section without any official controls. ``The Berlin Wall at the Brandenburg Gate will be torn down,'' the ZDF television network said Friday. ``East German border troops will start the work on Monday.''

Keith Haring, whose cartoon-like drawings appeared in public spaces from New York City's subways to the Berlin Wall, has died of AIDS. He was 31. Haring, who had been diagnosed with the AIDS virus more than a year ago, died early Friday in his downtown Manhattan apartment, said an assistant, Margaret Slabbert. Active in AIDS fund-raising, Haring returned from a European trip a month ago and fell ill soon after. Haring's work, characterized by human and animal figures in an energized setting, was admired worldwide and brought him a lucrative business.
