A disease closely related to the AIDS virus can almost certainly be traced back to an African monkey, which may have given it to people by biting them, a researcher said. Dr. Vanessa M. Hirsch of Georgetown University said Friday the West African epidemic of HIV-2 disease most likely comes from the sooty mangabey, a nondescript charcoal-gray monkey that is now endangered. The virus causes no outward signs of disease in the monkeys. But when humans contract the disease, it causes a serious illness that is similar to acquired immune deficiency syndrome, although less fatal. Hirsch said she believes HIV-2 was transmitted from monkeys to people within the past century through a bite or some other close contact.

DOC.HEAD: Opportunity Is Where You Find It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on assignment
DOC.TEXT: Hal Rosenbluth's 51st-story office looks down over City Hall, far away from the dusty, brown North Dakota prairie. But he thinks the two fit together. The 37-year-old chief executive got interested in North Dakota when he decided to help its drought-stricken farmers. Now he's become a fan of the state, and his friendship has led to a thriving business and the promise of more to come. Rosenbluth Travel is the nation's fourth-largest travel agency, a 98-year-old business that writes airline tickets for corporate giants ranging from Eastman Kodak to General Electric. But Rosenbluth's idea of a great vacation is someplace where you're overdressed if you wear anything other than a T-shirt with a stain on it. ``He is a very down-to-earth, non-pretentious person,'' says Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D. The two men and their wives struck up a friendship after Rosenbluth opened a data-processing office in Linton, N.D., in 1988, when drought threatened to drive many families there off the farm. They have united in a promotion and recruitment effort they say could spur several Rosenbluth clients to open new businesses in North Dakota. ``It's so genuine, It's so refreshing, pure,'' Rosenbluth said during a recent interview in his office. ``I had never carried on a conversation for more than 15 minutes, I think, until I went out there.'' Folks in Linton, a town of about 1,000 in central North Dakota, find it easy to talk to Rosenbluth. ``Before our first meeting I was nervous,'' said Sharon Jangula, the coordinator for Rosenbluth's data-processing office. ``I really didn't know what to expect, a stuffed shirt, hard to talk to, strictly business type person. I was really surprised.'' Rosenbluth's 2,300 employees are called ``associates.'' To become one, you must be ``nice'' _ friendly, outgoing and willing to provide demanding clients with ``elegant service.'' Managers are taught that a good supervisor is a good servant. Each new employee at any of the agency's 265 offices round the world is brought to Philadelphia for seminars that end with tea in the board room. Rosenbluth and other managers serve the tea and cakes. Associates are encouraged to think of ways to improve the company's service. One employee's suggestion led to Rosenbluth Travel's new telecommunications service for the deaf. ``That's one of the few ways you get dismissed is if someone suppresses an idea,'' Rosenbluth said. His management style may sound corny or impractical, but you can't argue with success. Rosenbluth went to work for the company in 1974 after earning a degree in criminology from the University of Miami. The former steamship ticket office his great-grandfather opened in 1892 had $20 million in billings. Bored as a vice president, Rosenbluth left the front office after a year to work as a reservation agent. His management ideas were born in after-hours talks with the other agents. By 1975, Rosenbluth's billings had grown to $300 million. They hit $1.1 billion last month and are still growing, the company says. Out of its success came a social conscience. The agency contributed to Philadelphia charities, but the sight in 1988 of struggling farmers and parched Midwest fields on the television news sparked something in Rosenbluth's imagination. Determined to help, he contacted U.S. Agriculture Department officials to find out what area was hit hardest. They pointed him to North Dakota, and state officials pointed him to Linton. The company rented space in a tractor dealership and hired 40 part-time employees to punch information into the company's computer at $5 an hour. To some farm wives, Rosenbluth's jobs were the difference between losing the farm or taking a job an hour away in Bismarck. He expected costs in North Dakota to be less, although he insists he never considered the potential savings. Wages alone are 20 percent to 25 percent less than in Philadelphia. He found a strong work ethic, practically no turnover and ``nice people'' that fit his corporate style. ``I said to myself, this is something we need to wake up to,'' Rosenbluth said.

DOC.HEAD: Restructuring Your Way to a Higher Stock Price
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: With the expansionist 1980s behind most U.S. companies and the leaner and more conservative '90s under way, corporate restructuring may well become more popular as a way to increase the price of a firm's stock. Junk bond financing is just about on hold and fewer takeovers are getting done, so it's harder for companies to boost their stock prices by making acquisitions. But buying back shares, divesting underperforming units or taking other restructuring steps is an easier and sometimes cheaper alternative. When Marriott Corp. announced in December it was restructuring by selling most of its restaurants and buying back more stock, company officials said enhancing shareholder value _ Wall Street's catchword for raising the firm's stock price _ was among their goals. It doesn't always work, and when it does, it can take time. The day the Marriott restructuring was announced, the company's stock fell $1 a share to $33.62{. Marriott's shares have traded lower since then, but the company has been subject to the same doldrums that have eroded prices for most issues on Wall Street this year. Investors were more enthused when International Business Machines Corp. announced a $1 billion stock buyback in October. They immediately bid the computer giant's shares up $2.37{ to $104.12{. IBM is currently trading at about that level. How much a restructuring affects a company's stock price depends on a number of factors, including the kind of move undertaken, how much money is involved and whether the shares themselves are directly involved, as in a buyback. Conditions on Wall Street are also a variable. There is nothing new about restructurings, but analysts have predicted there will be more of them in the coming months and years now that the takeover boom has ended. Companies are now working from within, rearranging and streamlining their businesses, trying to improve their profits and, consequently, the price of stock. If they decide to repurchase stock, the price often goes up under the law of supply and demand. But some firms are forced into restructuring by the threat of hostile takeover attempts. The buyout binge may be over, but a few companies have become the targets of investors who want a better return on their holdings _ in other words, a higher stock price. Georgia Gulf Corp. had to formulate a recapitalization plan to try to fend off Texas investor Harold Simmons, who holds about 9 percent of the chemical company's stock. Simmons began playing a cat-and-mouse game with Georgia Gulf last summer, presenting management with a list of suggestions on how to raise their share price. The company says its recapitalization plan, which provides for a cash payment to stockholders, is worth up to $55 a share. Simmons, dissatisfied with the recapitalization, has launched a $1.1 billion _ at $45 a share _ hostile bid and wants to unseat the Georgia Gulf board. The company's stock is currently trading below Simmons' bid. Simmons' strategy _ considered corporate raiding in some quarters _ is similar to the approach Carl Icahn used at Texaco Inc. starting in late 1987. Icahn, then Texaco's biggest shareholder, fought the oil company's management for more than a year, charging they were not doing enough to raise its stock price. Icahn proposed a takeover bid and tried unsuccessfully to unseat Texaco's board. The oil giant ended up with a major restructuring that included the sale of billions of dollars worth of assets and the payment of a special dividend to stockholders. Now Icahn is the largest shareholder at USX Corp., and is expected to rock the boat there, too.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Say `What Recession?'
DOC.TEXT: If the economy is headed for a period of pain and retrenchment, some stubborn optimists in the stock market evidently haven't gotten the word. Over the first seven weeks of 1990, the financial news has been almost unrelentingly negative _ recession forecasts, a sudden rise in interest rates, and the dramatic failure of a prominent Wall Street firm. The stock market joined in the gloomy chorus last month with a selloff that chilled followers of the ``January barometer,'' which is supposed to signal the likely course of stock prices over the rest of the year. But with all those excuses to lose its nerve, the market has lately rebounded instead, and now stands only about 6 percent below the record high it reached as the new year began. The latest demonstration of the markets' resiliency came this past week, when barely a ripple of selling followed news of the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the firm that reigned as ``junk-bond'' king through most of the 1980s. That was hardly the only instance. Analysts also note that the market has been faced with a barrage of increasingly downbeat appraisals of the business outlook. For example, Maury Harris, economist at PaineWebber Inc., this month said he believed the odds of a recession had increased to about two in five, or 40 percent, from one in three previously. At about the same time, the economists S. Jay Levy and David Levy in Chappaqua, N.Y. increased their recession-probability rating from 50 percent to 60 percent. Among other factors, both cited the surprise jump in interest rates, which has added to an already worrisome list of credit problems facing business planners and consumers. Said the Levys: ``The economy has financial vulnerabilities that are now just beginning to impact nonfinancial economic activity. ``Overindebtedness has reduced, or ended, business at a number of retail firms. Construction companies are building fewer houses because they cannot obtain financing. Financial institutions' willingness to fund real estate development is diminishing, the result of lately having been burned too many times.'' The stock market, however, is not making the kind of recession forecast it has made in advance of many past business slumps. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 12.61 at 2,635.59 in the past week, remains just a decent rally's distance shy of its Jan. 2 peak of 2,810.15. Other readings for the week showed the New York Stock Exchange composite index down .64 at 183.75; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market up .17 at 429.01, and the American Stock Exchange market value index off 2.02 at 358.77. Volume on the Big Board averaged 148.57 million shares a day, against 154.98 million the week before. Attempts to explain the stock market's steady showing generally fall into two categories. On one side, there's the bullish view that investors, in the aggregate a traditionally knowledgeable group, can see beyond any short-term economic weakness to better days ahead. In the other camp are those who believe stock traders are missing the usual signs of trouble, their vision obscured by the long bull market of the '80s. To some of this persuasion, the problem was only worsened by Drexel Burnham's demise and the markets' unruffled response to it. As junk bonds full further from favor and credit worries mount, these observers say, stocks are less and less likely to get support from takeover news and speculation. Even before the Drexel news broke, analyst Greg Smith at Prudential-Bache Securities observed, ``the stock market continues to react to takeover stories as though little has changed. I would like to see market reactions that indicate investors understand the takeover binge has been severely diminished as a positive stock market influence.''

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Courts Playing Increased Role in American Business
DOC.TEXT: Bankruptcy once conjured up images of outraged creditors plundering what's left of businesses that can't pay the bills, a notion rooted in medieval Europe. In late 20th century America, however, bankruptcy has taken on an entirely new meaning as a protective remedy that allows troubled companies to keep operating while they work out their financial problems under a judge's supervision. Bankruptcy itself has become a huge business, fed in part by failures such as that of financial giants Drexel Burnham Lambert and Integrated Resources Inc. this past week. The latest names join a long list of other big business that have recently found refuge in the bankruptcy court system, including Eastern Airlines and the Campeau Corp. retailing empire. Such moves have placed an extraordinary amount of power in the hands of judges, entrusted with the fates of companies that employ hundreds of thousands of people and owe billions in debts. More money passes through bankruptcy courts than all other courts combined, bankruptcy attorneys say. Figures compiled by the American Bankruptcy Institute, a Washington group of attorneys, show the number of bankruptcy filings nearly doubled to 643,000 last year compared with five years earlier. Most filings represent sincere attempts by businesses in financial trouble to delay or stretch out repayment of onerous debts under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code, which gives companies a respite from creditors while they restructure and attempt to rehabilitate themselves. The code was liberalized in 1978, partly to give businesses more flexibility in turning to the Chapter 11 strategy. Attorneys trace the bankruptcy boom to that reform, which in many cases has been exploited by large, financially solvent companies facing potential ruin, not necessarily because of pressure from lenders. Texaco Inc., for example, resorted to Chapter 11 three years ago, not from heavy losses in its oil business, but because of a $10.5 billion court judgment awarded to smaller rival Pennzoil Co. Manville Corp. and A.H. Robins Co. exited bankruptcy court in 1989 as healthy companies after years under Chapter 11 protection because of product-liability lawsuits that they claimed threatened their existence. ``Chapter 11 as it's now functioning is proving to be a fairly hospitable resort for big companies,'' said Frank Kennedy, a University of Michigan professor and noted authority on bankruptcy law. ``Other countries don't have anything like rehabilitiation. Our bankruptcy laws are unique in providing hospitality.'' Many business veterans have found American bankruptcy law to be a lifeline in squalls of financial trouble. Sanford Sigoloff, an executive known as a turnaround artist for helping steer building products retailer Wickes Cos. through a sucessful bankruptcy five years ago, is one of the system's most articulate defenders. ``There are lots of Chapter 11s in this country and a large percentage of them meet all or part of their obligations over time and come back,'' said Sigoloff. ``The system, when used as designed, is outstanding.'' Bankruptcy stems from the Italian ``bancorotto'' or ``broken bench.'' In medieval Italy, where skilled craftsmen did business from benches in guild halls, those who defaulted on debts faced the wrath of suppliers, who would smash the bench and rifle the craftsmen's tools as partial compensation. Protection against bankruptcy is largely an American legal innovation, based on the theory that if businesses had a reprieve from sudden shortages of cash or credit, for whatever reason, they and the country would ultimately benefit because jobs would be saved and the economy would continue to grow. ``For the businessman, it's a time to renew the company,'' Sigoloff said. ``For the creditors, it's an opportunity to have a common forum and return the company to health.'' In Drexel's case, however, the Chapter 11 filing appeared to be largely a formality to briefly prolong the life of the company, which had been devastated by legal problems and a depression in the market for its main business, high-risk junk bonds. Many legal experts say the Drexel case illustrates another side to the U.S. bankruptcy law _ that it is not a magic bullet for resurrection. Without public trust or a marketable product, both of which Drexel quickly and dramatically lost, bankruptcy court becomes a trough where the scraps of a business are thrown, to be distributed among its many creditors. ``That's the kind of business so tied to confidence that it's difficult to reorganize,'' said Harry Dixon, an Omaha lawyer who chairs the American Bankruptcy Institute. ``Any company that has that problem, Chapter 11 won't solve.'' In other business news this past week: _The government said a 30 percent trade-balance improvement in December helped the United States narrow the deficit to $108.6 billion, the smallest in five years. But private economists said the figure masked a troubling surge in dependence on foreign oil and other products this year that could dramatically widen the deficit, the most visible symbol of U.S. economic weakness. _Big Three carmakers reported a severe plunge in 1989 earnings because of costly incentives to woo buyers and a depression in the auto industry. Workers at General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. got sharply reduced profit-sharing bonuses. Chrysler's workers gone none. _Perrier recalled its famous sparkling water worldwide after traces of cancer-causing benzene were found in some shipments. The French company, which traced the contamination to a dirty filter, faces multimillion-dollar losses, potentially huge liability claims and an embarassing humiliation over a product it had peddled as pure from the source.

DOC.HEAD: With All the Bad News About Junk Bonds, Maybe Now Is a Good Time to Buy
DOC.TEXT: Just when it looked like things couldn't get any worse for the junk bond market, the house of Drexel came tumbling down in a stunningly swift collapse. It was the kind of news that gets the pulse racing in some vulture buyers and other long-term investors. The junk market has been reeling for months from defaults, credit downgrades of benchmark issues, requirements that ailing thrifts sell their holdings and a virtual boycott by mutual funds and others. Then last week's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing by the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. removed the firm that built the $200 billion market virtually from scratch. For many, it was a fitting comeuppance for the cocky investment bank and its paper prodigy, which promised such riches that many buyers seemed to forget why the bonds were called ``junk.'' But a number of stout-hearted money managers who invest for the long haul rather than the quick turn believe there are juicy pickings in the junk pile. ``If nothing else, the Drexel bankruptcy has created an opportunity for people that can truly analyze the creditworthiness of the individual bonds and can determine those that are junk and those that aren't junk,'' says Steven Case, senior consultant at Berg Fiduciary Consultants. Junk bulls caution that the market is likely to remain shaky for months as buyers remain scarce and hard-pressed investors _ everyone from thrifts to what remains of Drexel itself _ sell their holdings. The heady enthusiasm for double-digit yields that dominated the go-go years is out. But anyone willing to do a sober review of junk bond issuers _ checking cash-flow, the schedule of debt maturities coming due and need for asset sales _can find good values. ``That is what's slowly taking place,'' says Dan Baldwin, who manages close to $1 billion in high-yield assets at Chancellor Capital Management in New York. ``It's going back to credit fundamentals.'' Baldwin and others say the negative publicity about the market has obscured the fact that there are at least three levels of junk out there. Roughly 35 percent of all junk bonds come from companies that are operating profitably and are traded actively by a number of securities firms, Baldwin says. Bonds issued by Turner Broadcasting System Inc. and Kroger Co. _ the Cincinnati retailer that made good _ yield around 12 percent, more than two percentage points above investment-grade corporate bonds. A similar amount of bonds have been issued by companies that can meet their interest payments, but few market makers deal in these issues so liquidity is problematic, he says. At the bottom is the stress tier, perhaps 25 percent of the market, where issuers are in default or unlikely to be able to meet future debt payments, Baldwin says. Yields here can range from 16 percent to more than 30 percent, assuming interest actually is paid, and paid in cash rather than more junk. ``The prices have gone down so low and yields are so attractive, it's very attractive relative to equities,'' Baldwin says. Peter W. Thayer, president of Gateway Investment Advisers in Cincinnati, is a long-time equity investor who shunned junk bonds in the past but is giving the market another look. A buyer willing to wait two to four years for a return can assemble a $20 million portfolio of bonds from a dozen companies, Thayer says. At current prices, the investment should pay off handsomely even if a few of the companies fail, he says. For the small investor, it isn't a bad time to put some money into high-yield mutual funds because customer redemptions in the wake of Drexel's bankruptcy filing may depress fund prices, Thayer adds. ``You should just buy them and forget them for a few years.'' For the real vulture, the market's current distress is like an appetizing heap of corpses. David J. Breazzano, who manages about $100 million for T. Rowe Price Associates of Baltimore, is interested only in true ``distressed credits,'' or companies that have filed for bankruptcy protection. These bonds trade mostly for as little as 20 cents to 50 cents on the dollar. Few people deal in these bonds, though, so when an investor has to sell, the price often drops fast. ``If somebody can absorb size, he can buy it below market, substantially below,'' Breazzano says. The vulture buyer may have to wait through two to three years of bankruptcy court proceedings, but if he's done his homework on the company, he can be pretty sure of a payback. As Breazzano says, ``Everything, even a bankrupt bond, has value at a price.''

DOC.HEAD: The MBA _ Still Considered `The Ticket'
DOC.TEXT: Until last week, 23-year-old Jarl Ginsberg, was an options trader at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. But when the company's parent filed for bankruptcy court protection in the largest collapse of any Wall Street firm, Ginsberg was forced to consider his alternatives. Getting a master's of business administration would give him ``credentials and credibility,'' and it would buy him time while the industry limps back on its feet. The shine on the MBA degree, the yuppie ticket to bigger and better things that has been coveted for more than a decade, has yet to tarnish. Despite fresh and massive layoffs on Wall Street, businesspeople and students alike still say the degree makes a difference. Business schools anticipate no drop in applications, though students are shifting their studies away from risky investment banking in favor of consulting and more traditional areas like corporate finance. Many new MBAs have yet to chip away at the loans they took out to foot the degree. A few are considering drastic career changes. One 30-year-old investment banker who graduated from Columbia University's business school two years ago owes nearly $25,000 on college loans. But job prospects have dimmed so astonishingly that he is preparing to apply to law schools. ``Career paths within banking are fairly restricted now,'' he said, speaking anonymously so he wouldn't officially violate his company's ``don't-talk-to-the-press'' policy. ``It's time to look beyond banking.'' What drove hordes of people to the financial services industry via business school was the promise of financial rewards that practically knew no bounds. Recruiters visiting the Columbia campus a few years back were offering starting salaries of $75,000 and ``the unspoken promise of $250,000 five years out,'' one recent grad remembers. Today, financial companies are not even showing up to talk to students, let alone offer them jobs. At New York Univeristy's Stern School, ``all companies are cutting back and some are canceling their schedules'' to interview for summer internships, said Howard Leifman, assistant director of the school's office of career development. At Columbia, director of placement and career services Elizabeth Katsivelos said there haven't been any ``excessive cancellations.'' But she did note that more students are showing an interest in consulting and manufacturing. In 1986, the go-go days of Wall Street, 31 percent of Columbia's MBA grads went to brokerage houses and investment firms. Last year, the number dwindled to 16 percent, and Katsivelos called further declines possible. Some insiders predict only a mere 10 percent of the Drexel people will actually land jobs in financial services in New York. More than 5,000 Drexel employees were expected to lose their jobs. According to a study of recent MBA graduates from the prestigious Wharton School in Philadelphia, those accepting jobs in the Northeast have dropped more than 7 percent, while those moving to the South jumped 56 percent. For those willing to pack it all in and move, many will find themselves trapped by real estate they can't readily unload. Cooperative apartments in Brooklyn Heights, which offers a bird's-eye view of Wall Street, are either being deeply discounted or taking months to sell. At the peak of the city's real estate boom a few years ago, a modest, two-bedroom apartment sold for $225,000 in a less fashionable Brooklyn neighborhood. Local realtors now tell the owners they'll have to drop to about $190,000 if they want a quick sale. ``You're stuck with property you've paid a lot of money for,'' one homeowner complained. For those who do manage to land on their feet, the question becomes just how solid the foundation will be. Do they have any chance of earning their previous salaries? One 28-year-old trader, who earned $100,000-plus at a Wall Street firm, has been unemployed since September. His prospects are even bleaker now that he's competing with another few thousand Drexel jobless. Though he received a generous severance package, there's only money left to cover living expenses for his family and the mortgage on his designer duplex loft for another eight months. Then, of course, there's a certain amount of guilt to be dealt with after riding the wave of greed and materialism. Some of Wall Street's unfortunate said they were embarrassed they didn't see the end coming. ``I feel responsible for not anticipating things better,'' said one.

DOC.HEAD: Multibillionaire Texan Takes Aim At Leading Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Barnes, head of the St. Petersburg Times, bristles at a Texas tycoon's attempt to acquire a prominent newspaper that was set up to be forever independent. ``What you're seeing is people who think everything can be measured in dollars,'' says Barnes, 50, of a bid led by Fort Worth billionaire Robert M. Bass to acquire control of the Times Publishing Co., owner of the newspaper and the Congressional Quarterly. A Bass-led partnership, which bought a minority stake in mid-1988, offered $270 million for a controlling share, a deal rejected Friday by trustees who control the company. The Bass investors also are suing for a bigger share of dividends they claim aren't fairly distributed. What paved the way for a takeover fight was a feud that started long ago in the family of the late Times titan Nelson Poynter, who ran the newspaper for 30 of its 105 years. Poynter engineered a unique way to keep a profitable daily newspaper in the hands of journalists, free from control of outsiders or even his family. He established a nonprofit journalism school, the Poynter Institute, which through a complex system is the major stockholder of the newspaper and receives 83 percent of the dividends. In a special centennial issue in 1984 the Times said of its ownership: ``As corny as it sounds, how one of ... America's largest daily newspapers became the property of a school is the story of one man's commitment to corporate excellence and local control. ``Nelson Poynter's gift _ valued in the hundreds of millions of dollars _ has been called both a noble gesture and a tax dodge.'' Poynter carved family scars as he brought his dream to life. Ten years after his death in 1978, disgruntled heirs said they felt they weren't getting a fair share of the dividends. They sold their minority interest to Bass and now are part of his Poynter-Jamison Ventures Ltd. partnership. In its suit, the Bass group values the company at $450 million and alleges management is cheating shareholders. Bass and his partners own 40 percent of the common stock but only receive 5.7 percent of the company's dividends. Barnes, who won't disclose the company's worth, calls the suit ``meritless and wrong'' and vows to ``respond as forcefully as we know how to do. ``They're accusing us of doing what we assert we do. They call it a breach of fiduciary trust. This is a fight about dividend flow and whether they get the 6 percent they bought or the 40 percent they'd like,'' Barnes said. Both sides have been lining up high-powered attorneys for what could be a long and bitter fight. Barnes believes an emphasis on profits would sacrifice journalistic excellence. ``Journalism is our strength. We also have excellent lawyers,'' he said. ``I don't intend to lose.'' The other side thinks economics and good journalism mix. Bass, 41, a renowned takeover dabbler with artful acquisitions to his credit, wants the paper because it is widely respected and financially sound, says spokesman David Bonderman. ``Barnes acts like it's the Holy Grail; that nobody could have an interest in journalistic integrity if they had an economic stake,'' Bonderman said. ``The only ones like that are the St. Pete Times and Pravda. And even Pravda seems to be learning its lesson.'' Barnes doesn't take kindly to the Soviet Communist Party newspaper analogy. ``If they so value the journalistic aspect, how can they compare us to Pravda?'' he asks. ``We're not talking about little old ladies,'' Barnes said. ``We're talking about corporate raiders from Texas. I think there's an intimate relationship between good journalism and the dollars it costs to provide it ... You can't have it both ways.'' The Bass group has said it will guarantee editorial integrity of the paper, and claims the buyout plan would strengthen the institute financially. The newspaper Poynter envisioned wouldn't have to worry about debt, or ownership by investors or a large newspaper chain that could influence content. He centralized control of the newspaper in the hands of one person by arranging for the institute shares to be voted by the chief executive officer of the Times Publishing Co. That power went first to Times editor Eugene Patterson, who picked Barnes as his successor when he retired in 1988. Barnes is chairman of the institute, board chairman and chief executive officer of both the Times Holding Co. and the Times Publishing Co. and editor, president and chief executive of the newspaper. When Nelson Poynter took over the paper and its parent from his father Paul in 1947, the stock was allocated with the idea that Nelson would have voting control and his sister, Eleanor, would have a greater income flow, said Merritt Gardner, an attorney who represented her before her death in 1987. It didn't work out that way. Eventually, Nelson Poynter called in the redeemable, non-voting stock Eleanor held, leaving his sister with 40 percent _ or 200 shares _ of voting stock and only 6 percent of the dividends. Poynter wound up with 60 percent of the voting stock _ or 300 shares _ and 3,000 shares of preferred stock he didn't redeem. That gave him 94 percent of the dividends. Later, some shares went to Poynter's widow, Marion, who receives about 11 percent of the dividends. Voting stock provides power; non-voting stock brings dividends. The Bass group got its entree by buying the 200 shares of voting stock owned by Poynter's nieces, Mary Alice Jamison Griffin and Ann Poynter Jamison Parker. The sisters, daughters of Eleanor, said they were forced to sell to settle estate taxes after their mother died.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Fires Thousands, Issues Severance Package
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. gave thousands of fired workers skimpy severance payments but offered cut-rate deals on computer equipment as it headed into oblivion after reshaping corporate America in the 1980s. The bulk of Drexel's 5,300 employees were turned loose Friday into a slumping securities industry that already has witnessed tens of thousands of layoffs since the 1987 stock market crash. Drexel's parent company filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law Tuesday when it defaulted on some debt and banks refused to lend money. The company then began liquidating its businesses, including the once-powerful securities firm. ``It has been a historic week,'' said Kathleen Camilli, a Drexel money market economist who is forming a research firm with a co-worker. ``Just think, 10 years from now I'll look back and say I worked for Drexel Burnham. And that firm no longer exists.'' On Friday, Drexel workers finished packing boxes, unscrewed computer equipment from desks to buy at fire-sale prices and left the firm's downtwon headquarters, many for the last time. ``It's a beautiful day, isn't it?'' one Drexel executive said, pointing to a drizzly, gray sky overhead. ``It's like the day King Kong invaded Manhattan.'' Drexel spokesman Steven Anreder said an unspecified number of employees _ from investment bankers to secretaries _ would remain temporarily to finish pending business. Drexel is transferring some business to other firms and liquidating its portfolio of junk bonds and other securities. Under the severance plan, salaried workers are to get a week and a half's pay for each year of completed service, plus two weeks' pay. Unsalaried workers are to get just one week's pay per year, plus one week, employees said. The maximum is 24 weeks' pay for 15 or more years at the firm. The payments are coming out of the securities firm's remaining assets, which are not covered by the parent's bankruptcy filing. ``We deeply regret this short notice of termination to you, but we made Herculean efforts to obtain additional capital, which we believed would be available, and anticipated a refinancing of our debt obligations as has been done in the past,'' the letter said. ``Unfortunately, this did not occur. ``With the filing of the petition in bankruptcy by our parent company, a loss of confidence by the public, our investors and customers has resulted in our inability to conduct our business and compelled us to close down our operations.'' The bulk of Drexel's high-yield bond division in Beverly Hills, Calif., was fired. The operation long headed by Michael Milken was largely responsible for the firm's rise to prominence. About 1,000 Drexel clients handled by Milken used the risky debt securities to expand. Some used them to raise money for hostile raids on much larger firms, a phenomenon that altered American business in the 1980s. Drexel's demise was due in part to the collapse of the junk-bond market last fall and to the firm's agreement to plead guilty to securities crimes and pay $650 million to the government. Milken left Drexel after he was indicted on related charges. Also Friday, officials confirmed that Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. was expected to acquire about 28,000 Drexel brokerage accounts with assets of as much as $5 billion. The accounts are held by current and former Drexel employees, their relatives and small institutions. A Drexel junk-bond holder filed a class-action lawsuit charging a Drexel controlling company, Milken, chief executive Frederick H. Joseph and others with fraud, deceit, misrepresentation and securities law violations in junk-bond deals. The lawsuit, filed in Delaware Chancery Court, claims Milken ``lured in'' thousands of investors and then engaged in secret transactions.
